In return, they can come in on Grass- and Electric-types like Tapu Bulu, Zarude, and Thundurus-T that force out Slowking. Slowking forms a strong pivot core with Moltres, with Moltres pressuring Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu and Slowking checking foes such as Keldeo. Slowking appreciates entry hazard control from teammates such as Excadrill, Mandibuzz, and Rotom-H. Skarmory is also a good teammate for Slowking, as it checks Zarude easily and helps against Mamoswine, Conkeldurr, and Scizor. Its Whirlwind also synergizes with Future Sight, heavily damaging shared checks like Thundurus-T or outright KOing Fighting-types. Hippowdon acts as a switch-in to Rotom-H, Raikou, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon for Slowking.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind enables Slowking to become a dangerous offensive threat and set up on common Pokemon such as Nihilego and Moltres while retaining its longevity. After a boost, it is able to survive moves such as Dark Pulse from Choice Specs Hydreigon and stomach attacks such as Nidoking's Thunderbolt and Salamence’s Hurricane. Scald helps Slowking threaten switch-ins such as Hydreigon and enemy Slowking with burns. Psyshock helps against Chansey, opposing Slowking, Calm Mind Primarina, and Galarian Slowbro. Colbur Berry improves Slowking's matchup against Conkeldurr and Mamoswine, though it still has watch out for Facade from the former if it's below 66% HP.

Calm Mind Slowking fits best on balance, semi-stall, and stall teams as a wincon that maintains crucial defensive utility against Pokemon such as Mamoswine and Azelf. Nihilego and Chansey are useful Stealth Rock setters that check Thundurus-T and Hydreigon. Nihilego is more offensively potent and provides Knock Off support, whereas Chansey has more longevity and can also provide cleric support instead of setting Stealth Rock. However, while teams using Calm Mind Slowking want cleric support, keeping Slowking burned helps it set up in front of Chansey and Swampert without fear of Toxic. Quagsire provides an Electric immunity and checks Pokemon like Swords Dance Scizor and Belly Drum Azumarill. Its Haze support also alleviates Slowking's matchup against Calm Mind Reuniclus. Defensive Salamence and Skarmory are great assets for their ability to answer Grass-types like Zarude and Zarude while providing Defog support. They also ensure that Slowking does not get overwhelmed by foes such as Conkeldurr and Swords Dance Excadrill. Umbreon provides additional insurance against Mamoswine and Energy Ball Azelf while having the option to provide Wish support. It also enjoys Slowking's ability to set up on threats such as Cobalion and Keldeo. Calm Mind Slowking can have problems against Teleport Slowking, which can bring in Pokemon that threaten it such as Hydreigon, so counters to Slowking like Zarude are great teammates.

Skarmory.overview: Skarmory is one of the key defensive pillars of UU thanks to its sky-high Defense, reliable recovery, and amazing defensive typing, checking dangerous offensive threats like Excadrill, Zarude, Scizor, and Gyarados with ease. Skarmory has a bevy of utility moves. Spikes wears down defensive threats like Hippowdon and Chansey for its team, and Skarmory can set Spikes easily thanks to its defensive utility and good matchup versus Excadrill. Furthermore, Whirlwind prevents Pokemon like Dragon Dance Gyarados and Swords Dance Scizor from setting up, while Iron Defense alongside Body Press allows Skarmory to improve its matchup versus threats like Azumarill, Swords Dance Scizor, and Conkeldurr. Skarmory can even run Defog on stall teams thanks to its great matchup against entry hazard setters like Excadrill and Hippowdon. These traits, in addition to its synergy with top defensive picks like Amoonguss, Slowking, and Chansey, allow Skarmory to fit on a wide range of archetypes ranging from bulky offense to stall. However, Skarmory has an extremely vulnerable Special Defense stat, making it a Steel-type that can't check specially offensive Fairy- and Psychic-types like Hatterene, so it faces competition from other Steel-types like Celesteela. Common threats like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Moltres also limit Skarmory's consistency due to its passivity. Skarmory also often struggles to fit all the moves it likes at once. For example, it becomes much more vulnerable to Conkeldurr and Azumarill without Brave Bird, but it struggles to pressure Mamoswine without Body Press, while Iron Defense sets become extremely passive and unable to punish Defog users such as Moltres and Salamence.
Skarmory.comments:
Other Options

Skarmory can compress both Spikes and Defog on more defensive teams, acting as an emergency Defog option and opening up moveslots for other teammates. Skarmory can replace its attacking moveslot to fit both, or even other combinations of utility moves. It is still able to beat Excadrill as long as it keeps Rocky Helmet. However, these sets are very team specific. Skarmory can attempt to compress entry hazards by running both Spikes and Stealth Rock, but it struggles to fit Stealth Rock over more valuable options like Whirlwind or Toxic and pairs well with Stealth Rock setters like Nihilego anyway.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Common Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H all are unbothered by Skarmory and can use it to gain momentum with Volt Switch. Thundurus-T can also boost with Nasty Plot as it forces Skarmory out.

Fire-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fire-types like Chandelure and Moltres come in easily on Skarmory and force it out. Skarmory must also be wary of Pokemon like Celesteela, Salamence, and Azelf due to them commonly running Fire-type coverage.

Strong Special Attackers: Powerful special attackers like Keldeo, Primarina, and Hydreigon can all break through Skarmory due to its poor special bulk. Hatterene in particular completely walls Skarmory, denying its entry hazards and ignoring Whirlwind and Toxic with Magic Bounce.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Body Press utilizes Skarmory's amazing Defense to hit many opposing Pokemon hard, devastating the likes of Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Zarude. It also keeps Hydreigon from coming in freely. Alternatively, Brave Bird lets Skarmory hit Conkeldurr, Keldeo, and Amoonguss super effectively and deal solid damage to Azumarill and Gyarados. Spikes wears down common defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Amoonguss, and Hippowdon. Skarmory has plenty of opportunities to set Spikes up against Pokemon that typically cannot threaten it, like Jirachi and Tangrowth. Whirlwind synergizes well with Spikes, forcing chip damage on switch-ins like Primarina. It also prevents setup sweepers like Gyarados and Belly Drum Azumarill from setting up. Alternatively, Toxic cripples threats like Moltres and Thundurus-T that typically have free entry on it, and hinders Defoggers like Salamence and Mandibuzz from removing Spikes in the long run. Skarmory can run Defog on stall teams thanks to its ability to handle entry hazard setters like Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Swampert. Rocky Helmet allows Skarmory to punish pivoting attempts from Swampert, Jirachi, and Zarude, prevent Excadrill from freely using Rapid Spin, and wear down threats like Azumarill, Diggersby, and Gyarados quickly. The given Speed EVs allow Skarmory to outspeed Azumarill and Conkeldurr.

Skarmory best fits on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams that appreciate its Spikes support and walling capabilities. Chansey makes an excellent partner for Skarmory, taking on dangerous special attackers like Hydreigon, Moltres, and Thundurus-T, while Skarmory handles physical attackers like Excadrill and Diggersby. Slowking similarly checks Moltres and special Salamence, and it also acts as a secondary check to Conkeldurr and Mamoswine with Colbur Berry. Additionally, its Future Sight alongside Skarmory's Whirlwind can hinder offensive Pokemon like Thundurus-T. Stealth Rock setters like Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Excadrill form great entry-hazard stacking cores with Skarmory. Diancie beats Hippowdon, Moltres, and non-Grass Knot Thundurus-T; Nihilego also beats the aforementioned threats and can hinder Scizor with Knock Off to make it vulnerable to Spikes; and Excadrill can pressure Hatterene and remove opposing entry hazards without compromising Skarmory's own Spikes. Bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth make good secondary checks to Tapu Bulu and Conkeldurr so Skarmory doesn't get overwhelmed checking them. They also can absorb Knock Off for the team, allowing Skarmory to preserve Rocky Helmet and chip down Jirachi. Zarude and the aformentioned Grass-types can help take on strong Electric- and Water-types like Rotom-W and Primarina as well. Powerful wallbreakers like Keldeo, Thundurus-T, and Zygarde-10% all appreciate Skarmory's Spikes wearing down checks like Tangrowth and Chansey. On stall teams, Quagsire can provide an Electric immunity to block Volt Switch and check Thundurus-T. It also can handle setup sweepers that can bypass Skarmory like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Scizor. Umbreon acts as a primary check to Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados, secondary check to Mamoswine, and way to beat Chandelure. Galarian Weezing counters Conkeldurr and can provide Defog support to prevent Skarmory from being worn down into range of Mamoswine's Icicle Crash.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
Iron Defense allows Skarmory to better check Pokemon such as Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Scizor by boosting its Defense, and it increasing Body Press's damage makes Skarmory more threatening in front of foes such as Hippowdon and Mandibuzz. Roost maintains Skarmory's health and keeps it steadfast against strong attackers like Conkeldurr and Zygarde-10%. Spikes allows Skarmory to support its team, easily setting them up against common Pokemon such as Amoonguss, and the additional chip damage is helpful against Pokemon like Keldeo. Alternatively, since Skarmory has great matchups against entry hazard setters like Excadrill and Hippowdon, Defog is useful to consistently remove their hazards while forcing them out. Rocky Helmet is helpful to punish Excadrill's Rapid Spin and other physical attackers like Zarude and Diggersby. Safety Goggles is an alternative option to allow Skarmory to fully counter Amoonguss, setting up Iron Defense or Spikes without needing to use a teammate as sleep fodder. However, this forces Skarmory to avoid taking Knock Off from foes like Mamoswine and Scizor in order to ignore Spore. 96 Speed EVs allow Skarmory to outspeed Azumarill.

Iron Defense Skarmory fits on balance and stall teams for handling physical threats such as Scizor while either setting Spikes to wear down foes for its teammates or reliably negating common entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Swampert. Spikes Skarmory complements other hazard setters like Nihilego and Hippowdon excellently. Both teammates check dangerous threats like Thundurus-T and Moltres, and they also help maintain hazards against hazard removers Skarmory cannot handle, like Salamence. Teammates such as Slowking and Chansey form excellent defensive cores with Skarmory thanks to their ability to check dangerous special attackers like Keldeo and Hydreigon. Slowking can act as a wincon on stall teams with Calm Mind, while Chansey can act as a cleric. Tangrowth provides additional support for Skarmory to ensure Zygarde-10% or Rotom-W does not overwhelm it. Tangrowth also absorbs Knock Off so Skarmory does not have to risk its own Rocky Helmet or Safety Goggles. Articuno can be paired with Skarmory on hazard stacking semi-stall teams to bleed the PP of hazard removers such as Salamence and Mandibuzz. Alternatively, Articuno can pair up with Defog Skarmory in a double Defog core, keeping entry hazards off almost indefinitely. Quagsire can check Rotom-H while providing backup against Dragon Dance Salamence. In return, Skarmory helps Quagsire against the Grass-types in the tier and threats like Gyarados. Hatterene enjoys Spikes pressure chipping Pokemon like Excadrill and Skarmory being a reliable check to Scizor. Hatterene's Magic Bounce also helps Skarmory avoid being worn down by opposing entry hazards. Other offensive teammates include Calm Mind Slowking and Galarian Slowbro, which enjoy Spikes support wearing down threats like Amoonguss and Hippowdon while checking foes like Zarude and Diggersby.

Entei.overview: Sacred Fire, a nice Speed tier, and decent bulk all lend themselves to Entei's success in UU. Sacred Fire's burn chance is Entei's claim to fame, making it immensely frustrating for even Fire-resistant foes like Rhyperior and Salamence to switch into. Entei is able to outspeed many key threats in the metagame, like Nidoking, Gyarados, and Buzzwole. Good bulk alongside a pure Fire typing grants Entei a decent amount of defensive utility and makes it a short-term check to Pokemon such as Jirachi and Zarude. Entei's biggest drawbacks are its Stealth Rock weakness and lack of longevity, which is exacerbated by Flare Blitz recoil. Entei also struggles with various bulky Water-types in the tier, namely RestTalk Primarina and Rotom-W. It struggles during long games due to its low-PP moves and can be awkward to build around due to its demand for team support.
Entei.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots gives Entei more opportunities to switch in and lessens the need for entry hazard removal, but it stops Entei from breaking through Pokemon as efficiently. A set consisting of Substitute, Calm Mind, Protect, and Lava Plume with Leftovers and Pressure can act as a wincon for bulkier teams and stall out defensive Pokemon, but it suffers from a lack of setup opportunities and a Stealth Rock weakness.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Pokemon such as Keldeo, Seismitoad, and Rotom-W can come in on any of Entei's Fire-moves and proceed to OHKO it. Defensive Water-types such as Primarina and Mantine easily take hits from Entei and retaliate with Scald.

Dragon-types: Salamence can take any attack from Entei outside of Stone Edge and heavily damage it, while Zygarde-10% outspeeds and OHKOes Entei with Thousand Arrows; however, both Dragon-types do not appreciate a burn from Sacred Fire, and Salamence is OHKOed by Stone Edge. Physical Kommo-o is crippled by a burn from Sacred Fire but can switch into Entei and use it to set Stealth Rock or cripple it with Toxic, while Clangorous Soul Kommo-o uses Entei as setup fodder.

Rock-types: Rhyperior and Nihilego can force out Entei and set up entry hazards, while Lycanroc-D can revenge kill it. However, none of them appreciate a burn, and Nihilego and Lycanroc-D take large amounts of damage from Entei's attacks.

Residual Damage: Entei is easily worn down by Stealth Rock, Flare Blitz recoil, and status.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Sacred Fire spreads burns and discourages Pokemon such as Gyarados and Kommo-o from switching in, but it has low PP and cannot be used liberally. Flare Blitz scores 2HKOs on Pokemon that Sacred Fire misses out on, such as Hatterene and Chansey. It also has perfect accuracy for cleaning. Stone Edge hits Mantine and Moltres, which would otherwise come in easily on Entei. It is also Entei's best way to hit Water-types such as Milotic and Azumarill. Extreme Speed is chosen to revenge kill faster threats such as Azelf and Choice Scarf Krookodile. Inner Focus ignores Intimidate from foes like Krookodile and Salamence.

Entry hazard removal is necessary for Entei to properly function as an early-game wallbreaker. Pokemon such as Salamence, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel are highly recommended; Rotom-W can also lure in Grass-types and pivot into Entei with Volt Switch. Grass-types such as Zarude and Amoonguss are also ideal partners, as they check bothersome Water- and Rock-types such as Primarina and Rhyperior and support Entei with U-turn and Spore, respectively. Since it struggles against Dragon-types like Kommo-o, Entei greatly appreciates Fairy-types like Hatterene and Azumarill; Hatterene can also dissuade Stealth Rock with Magic Bounce. RestTalk Primarina forms a solid defensive core with Entei and can take hits from opposing Rock-, Ground-, and Dragon-types when Entei is locked into Sacred Fire, and it's also able to pivot into foes such as Keldeo. Similarly, while Togekiss cannot deal with Rock-types, it can take on Dragon-types with ease, in addition to providing utility with Heal Bell and paralyzing Pokemon such as Nihilego and Lycanroc-D with Thunder Wave. Choice Scarf Jirachi, Raikou, and Lycanroc-D can revenge kill faster foes that threaten Entei, such as Keldeo, Azelf, and Mienshao.

Suicune.overview: Despite its average movepool, Suicune is a decent setup sweeper due to its astounding bulk and valuable defensive typing that allow it to check distinguished threats such as Rhyperior. With Pressure, Calm Mind, and its superb bulk, Suicune is able to stall out threatening walls such as Aegislash and Chansey. However, Suicune is held back by the prevalence of Water-resistant Pokemon in the tier such as Keldeo, Mantine, and especially Zarude; Keldeo can simply ignore Suicune's Special Defense boosts with Secret Sword, Suicune struggles to make headway against Mantine, and Zarude especially can use Jungle Healing to cure itself of burns and Power Whip to deal significant damage. In addition, Suicune lacks reliable recovery, forcing it to rely on Leftovers and Rest in order to regain HP. This makes Suicune susceptible to Knock Off, as losing Leftovers would require Suicune to use Rest more often. In addition, its overreliance on Sleep Talk isn't great either, as you rely on RNG to choose the ideal move. Furthermore, Suicune's weakness to Grass- and Electric-type moves is easily exploitable by the common Power Whip Tangrowth, Zarude, and Thundurus-T.
Suicune.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind is another option, as it allows Suicune to PP stall would-be checks such as Quagsire; Ice Beam can also be used over Protect to prevent it from getting walled by Grass-types. However, it makes Suicune extremely vulnerable to passive damage and status and thus less reliable than CroCune. In addition, it is unable to sponge hits from foes like Rhyperior and Mamoswine, effectively taking up the teamslot of a Water-type without offering very much defensive utility. Toxic can be used to subdue Water-immune Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Mantine, and Seismitoad. However, Suicune often doesn't have room to run Toxic due to it suffering from four-moveslot syndrome. If you were to run Toxic, it would likely replace Sleep Talk on CroCune. A set with Calm Mind / Roar / Scald / Rest allows Suicune to be used as a dedicated phazer and stop foes like Calm Mind + Psyshock Galarian Slowbro from setting up; however, this would waste Suicune's sweeping capabilities and requires entry hazard support to be effective.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Raikou and Thundurus-T can easily severely damage Suicune with Thunderbolt, even after a Calm Mind boost. Rotom-W can chunk it with Volt Switch and bring in a powerful wallbreaker that can force it out.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude pose an immense threat to Suicune with Horn Leech and Power Whip due to Suicune's lackluster Defense and poor Speed. Heavy-Duty Boots variants of Zarude, in particular, completely counter Suicune, as they can switch into Scald without fear due to Jungle Healing.

Water-immune Pokemon: As Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, it can't damage Water-immune foes such as Mantine and Gastrodon; Suicune struggles with Gastrodon especially, as it can force Suicune to use Rest more often due to Toxic. Both of these Pokemon also have access to Haze and Clear Smog, making it difficult for Suicune to set up for a late-game sweep, as they result all of its stat boosts. Despite this, Suicune can still annoy both through Pressure stalling.

Knock Off and Trick Users: Knock Off removes Leftovers, preventing Suicune from regaining passive recovery over the course of a battle and forcing it to use Rest more often. Trick users such as Jirachi and Rotom-W can force Suicune into being Choice-locked.

sets.name: CroCune
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to become a threatening bulky sweeper. Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, which it can use to spread burns and sweep. Rest allows Suicune to easily recover HP while also curing any status conditions. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being too passive during sleep turns either by letting it continue to boost its special stats or attack foes. Suicune's Speed investment allows it to outspeed Aegislash.

As Suicune is a sweeper, it fits best on balance teams. Pokemon such as Kommo-o and Salamence are essential teammates for Suicune, as they threaten Grass-types like Zarude that pose a tremendous threat to Suicune. Salamence can also provide Defog support for Suicune and its teammates, which they appreciate. Suicune also appreciates Electric-immune teammates such as Nidoqueen and Rhyperior, with the former having the ability to set up Toxic Spikes to help Suicune stall opposing Pokemon like Seismitoad, and the latter providing counterplay to foes such as Nasty Plot Togekiss as well as Stealth Rock support. However, neither of them can handle Thundurus-T after a Nasty Plot boost. Suicune also appreciates teammates like Assault Vest Tangrowth and Amoonguss, which can help check threats like Keldeo; Tangrowth can also help check Thundurus-T, while Amoonguss can provide sleep support with Spore. Pokemon that can sponge Knock Off such as Buzzwole and Heavy-Duty Boots Zarude are also treasured on Suicune's team, as Suicune despises losing its Leftovers. Zarude is especially appreciated, as it can also threaten KOs on Water-resistant foes such as Gastrodon and Seismitoad, which would otherwise completely wall Suicune.

Swampert.overview: An excellent typing, a plethora of utility moves such as Toxic, Yawn, and Stealth Rock, and good matchups against the tier's entry hazard removers like Excadrill, Tentacruel, and Mandibuzz make Swampert a solid hazard setter. Good matchups against top threats like Jirachi, Krookodile, and Lycanroc-D contribute to Swampert's great defensive utility. Flip Turn also lets it be a slow pivot, limiting its passivity, making progress against walls such as Chansey, and bringing in slower teammates like Conkeldurr to wallbreak. However, many of the tier's threats hinder Swampert. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Zarude threaten to OHKO it, while powerful wallbreakers like Conkeldurr and Azumarill take advantage of its lack of reliable recovery to break through it. Swampert is also very vulnerable to status and Knock Off, especially from Pokemon it should check like Excadrill and Nihilego, which make it much less effective as a tank. Swampert also competes for a team slot with fellow hazard setter Ground-types Excadrill and Krookodile, which keep up offensive pressure more consistently.
Swampert.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band set with Liquidation, Earthquake, Ice Punch, and Flip Turn takes advantage of Swampert's solid Attack while also dealing with the Dragon- and Grass-types of the tier more effectively. Ice Beam can be used on the defensive set for a similar purpose, but this forces Swampert to sacrifice one of its utility moves. Scald can potentially burn foes like Skarmory that Swampert otherwise struggles against, but it is hard to slot into Swampert's moveset over its other utility moves. High Horsepower is a good alternative to Earthquake if Swampert is being run alongside Tapu Bulu, since Grassy Surge weakens Earthquake, but is an inferior pick otherwise. A physically defensive EV spread with a Relaxed nature allows Swampert to tank powerful physical attacks from foes like Mamoswine, Lycanroc-D, and Excadrill, but it makes Swampert more vulnerable to powerful special attackers like Thundurus-T and Azelf.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Zarude, Tangrowth, and Tapu Bulu can easily scare Swampert out with their 4x super effective STAB moves, though the latter two do not like the potential of being inflicted by Toxic. Swampert similarly fears Grass-type coverage, leaving it unable to deal with Gyarados's Power Whip and properly check Thundurus-T until it scouts for Grass Knot.

Dragon-types: Salamence and Hydreigon both either resist or are immune to Swampert's STAB moves and can force it out, though Swampert can cripple these Pokemon with Toxic.

Toxic: Pokemon like Excadrill and Rotom-H that struggle to deal with Swampert otherwise can use Toxic to cripple it, drastically worsening its longevity.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Thanks to Swampert's lack of reliable recovery, Pokemon like Conkeldurr, Choice Specs Primarina, and Azumarill can overwhelm it and take it out easily.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Earthquake deals massive damage to entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Tentacruel. Flip Turn makes progress against foes like Zarude and Salamence while also bringing in teammates like Conkeldurr and Azumarill safely. Toxic cripples walls such as Tangrowth that force out Swampert. Yawn instead can shut down offensive powerhouses that may threaten Swampert's teammates and force switches, allowing Swampert to generate even more momentum. 112 Special Defense EVs allow Swampert to tank powerful special hits from foes like Thundurus-T and Salamence, while 144 Defense EVs prevent Swampert from getting 2HKOed by Excadrill and Zygarde-10%. A Sassy nature is used so that Swampert can underspeed defensive Celesteela and thus absorb its Leech Seed before pivoting out to a teammate.

Slow wallbreakers, such as Conkeldurr and Mamoswine, greatly appreciate Yawn crippling enemies and Flip Turn giving them safe entry against Pokemon like Hydreigon and Amoonguss. Offensive pivots such as Thundurus-T, Azelf, and Zarude form VoltTurn cores with Swampert while also overwhelming foes that Swampert can't handle, such as Roserade and Hydreigon. Tapu Bulu gives Swampert much-appreciated additional recovery through Grassy Terrain. In turn, Swampert can help deal with Poison-types such as Nidoking, Nihilego, and Tentacruel, which threaten Tapu Bulu. Wish recovery from clerics such as Umbreon and Jirachi is also great for its longevity. Swampert greatly appreciates teammates like Skarmory and Moltres that can check the Grass-types that it fears so much. The former also forms an entry hazard stacking core with Swampert, while the latter forms a VoltTurn core with it. Entry hazard removers like Tentacruel, Excadrill, and Mandibuzz stop Spikes from punishing Swampert's longevity.

Torkoal.overview: Torkoal is the primary sun setter in UU, using its great physical bulk to switch into Pokemon like Scizor and Zarude and set up sun while also providing role compression as a Stealth Rock setter and entry hazard remover. Torkoal serves as a great partner for sun wallbreakers like Venusaur, Darmanitan, and Chandelure by providing utility with moves such as the previously mentioned Stealth Rock alongside Yawn, Toxic, and Rapid Spin. However, Torkoal struggles with longevity, as it needs to use Heat Rock over Heavy-Duty Boots to provide more sun turns for its teammates, meaning every time it comes in it risks taking significant chip from entry hazards like Stealth Rock. It also has a lack of recovery, making it vulnerable to common enemy leads like Excadrill and Krookodile. Torkoal is also a momentum sink, meaning that the player will have to either switch directly into their sun sweepers like Venusaur and Darmanitan, potentially forcing them to take damage, or sacrifice Torkoal to bring them in safely. Torkoal is also passive, often requiring status to stop Pokemon like Primarina from setting up on it. It is also weak to common Pokemon like Zygarde-10%, Nihilego, and Nidoqueen, meaning Torkoal appreciates defensive support from other Pokemon like Chansey to help it set sun more reliably throughout the game. Lastly, the presence of Hippowdon and its ability to set sand means Torkoal struggles to reliably keep up sun.
Torkoal.comments:
Other Options

Explosion can act as a last-ditch option to deal heavy damage to an opposing Pokemon and generate momentum for a teammate; however, it is hard to fit over better utility options, and Torkoal's low Speed and weakness to common attacking types means it can be KOed before using Explosion. Thanks to its low Speed, Torkoal can also be run on Trick Room teams, utilizing a powerful sun-boosted Eruption. However, Torkoal is weak to chip and entry hazard damage caused by switching in too many times if it is running Choice Specs over Heavy-Duty Boots, weakening Eruption as a result. Lastly, when Trick Room is over, Torkoal can be easily used as setup fodder or KOed by an opposing Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Rock-types: Rock-types like Nihilego, Rhyperior, and Lycanroc-D can all hit Torkoal for super effective damage, with the latter two not caring about its sky-high Defense, limiting the ability to set sun in the future due to Torkoal's lack of momentum or reliable recovery. The former two can also set up Stealth Rock, limiting the amount of times Torkoal can come in.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Krookodile, Nidoking, and Diggersby also can hit Torkoal for super effective damage, limiting Torkoal's ability to set sun in the future. The former two are also able to set up Stealth Rock against Torkoal, limiting the amount of times it can come in. Krookodile can also hinder Torkoal with Taunt, preventing it from punishing setup sweepers with Toxic or Yawn. Hippowdon is Torkoal's biggest enemy, being able to reset sun with its Sand Stream and easily set Stealth Rock in front of it.

Water-types: Water-types such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Azumarill all can threaten Torkoal with their powerful Water-type attacks. However, if the sun is up, the power of these moves will be halved, and Torkoal will be able to switch out into Venusaur, forcing them out in return.

Special Attackers: Due to Torkoal's average Special Defense, strong special attackers like Moltres, Hydreigon, and Salamence all can nail Torkoal for heavy damage. They can also use the sun to boost their Fire-type attacks and hit Fire-weak Pokemon like Venusaur even harder.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Thanks to Torkoal's great physical bulk, it can set up Stealth Rock against Pokemon it can force out with Lava Plume like Tapu Bulu, Skarmory, and Zarude, allowing wallbreakers like Venusaur and Darmanitan to power through their defensive answers more easily. Lava Plume limits Torkoal's passivity thanks to its Base Power boosted by the sun and 30% chance to burn the foe. Rapid Spin prevents Pokemon like Darmanitan from being heavily chunked by Stealth Rock. Toxic puts Pokemon like Rotom-H, Swampert, and Hydreigon on a timer, forcing them out. Yawn allows Torkoal to force opposing Pokemon out such as setup sweepers like Gyarados that can attempt to set up on it while also giving a free switch for a teammate, but Toxic is preferred for its ability to inflict more damage throughout the game. Rest + Sleep Talk can be used to boost Torkoal's longevity, especially when paired with Stealth Rock setters like Swampert to free up the moveslot. Heat Rock should always be run to maximize the amount of sun turns, allowing sun sweepers like Venusaur and Darmanitan to break through opposing teams more easily.

Powerful sun sweepers like Venusaur, Darmanitan, and Chandelure all act as great partners to Torkoal, as they appreciate its entry hazard support and removal as well as sun boosting their moves to clean through teams. Venusaur in particular is a fantastic partner for Torkoal, as sun activates Chlorophyll and turns its Weather Ball into a strong Fire-type attack for Steel-types like Scizor, Jirachi, and Celesteela. Venusaur also appreciates Torkoal's ability to put answers to it like Moltres and Chandelure on a timer with Toxic. In return, Torkoal appreciates Venusaur breaking through Rock-types like Rhyperior and Lycanroc-D, Ground-types like Hippowdon, and Water-types like Primarina, Slowking, and Azumarill. Meanwhile, Darmanitan can use the sun to boost its incredibly powerful Flare Blitz and revenge kill threats like Nihilego and Nidoking that threaten Torkoal. It can also bring in Torkoal safely with U-turn. Chansey can provide a defensive stop to Pokemon that threaten Torkoal such as Nihilego and Chandelure while also being able to provide momentum with Teleport to bring in Pokemon like Venusaur and Chandelure safely. Swampert also acts as a defensive stop to threats like Salamence and Nidoqueen and frees up Stealth Rock for Torkoal. Hatterene can act as a secondary entry hazard control option, alleviating the pressure from Torkoal while also dealing with Pokemon like Salamence. It also appreciates its Mystical Fire being boosted by the sun, allowing it to break through Pokemon like Celesteela and Assault Vest Tangrowth more easily. Skarmory and Celesteela provide intergral defensive support against Hippowdon for sun teams. Setup sweepers like Autotomize Celesteela appreciate having their Fire-type coverage boosted by the sun to break through defensive answers like specially defensive Celesteela more easily.

Crawdaunt.overview: Sporting a high Attack stat, Adaptability, and high-Base Power moves, Crawdaunt is an extremely powerful wallbreaker in UU capable of weakening or KOing even the bulkiest walls. Access to a strong priority move in Aqua Jet also allows it to bypass its low Speed and pick off targets such as Entei and Mienshao. After a Swords Dance boost it can take out even physically defensive Tangrowth and Skarmory. However, Crawdaunt is extremely slow, being outsped and KOed by common threats such as Salamence and Hydreigon. It also suffers from poor bulk and weaknesses to common typings, limiting its opportunities to switch in and set up. The omnipresent Zarude and Hydreigon resist both of Crawdaunt's STAB attacks limiting its ability as a wallbreaker. Finally, Crawdaunt suffers competition with Azumarill, which has an easier time setting up due to its superior defensive typing, although Crawdaunt's STAB Knock Off is a relevant advantage that lets it break the likes of Amoonguss and Tangrowth more easily.
Crawdaunt.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band provides Crawdaunt with a lot of immediate power to muscle through Pokemon such as Amoonguss more easily and it makes it easier to revenge kill threats like Thundurus-T with Aqua Jet. However, being Choice-locked makes it easy to take advantage of Crawdaunt and a Life Orb-boosted attack still hits hard enough to 2HKO Skarmory with Crabhammer. Close Combat can be ran over Swords Dance to let Crawdaunt threaten Zarude and Hydreigon on the switch. Liquidation can be used over Crabhammer on the Swords Dance set due to its better accuracy, but it's much weaker, failing to 2HKO foes like maximum HP Primarina.

Checks and Counters

Faster Water-resistant threats: Due to its low Speed, Crawdaunt is forced out by anything faster that can take a boosted Aqua Jet like Gyarados, Rotom-W, and Salamence.

Grass-types: Both Amoonguss and Tangrowth can usually switch into Crawdaunt, though they both fear a +2 Knock Off. Tapu Bulu resists Crawdaunt's STAB combination, allowing it to pivot into it multiple times and threaten to OHKO back. Zarude outspeeds Crawdaunt and resists a boosted Aqua Jet, allowing it to revenge kill Crawdaunt with ease.

Fighting-types: Though it would prefer to not switch in, Keldeo resists Crawdaunt's STAB combination and can OHKO it back. Conkeldurr is able to revenge kill Crawdaunt with Mach Punch.

Residual Damage: Since Crawdaunt is frail and slow, damage from entry hazards, status such as poison and burn, Rocky Helmet, and Life Orb recoil can cut into its longevity even more.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance boosts Crawdaunt's attack to monstrous levels, being able to OHKO walls like Celesteela and Amoonguss at +2. It even has a chance to KO physically defensive Tangrowth after a boost, with a guaranteed KO if Tangrowth has taken any chip. Aqua Jet allows Crawdaunt to hit frailer faster foes and potentially clean a weakened team, OHKOing Thundurus-T at +2. Life Orb is used to boost Crawdaunt's power and is preferred despite the recoil.

This set is intended to be used as an early- or mid-game wallbreaker, with Swords Dance allowing Crawdaunt to break through defensive cores with more ease. Crawdaunt should try to set up against slower foes that it forces out such as Chansey and Galarian Slowbro. Pivots such as Mienshao, Jirachi, and Zarude can help Crawdaunt switch in. Chansey can also handle threats to Crawdaunt like Primarina and Thundurus-T while utilizing a slow Teleport to safely bring in Crawdaunt. Crawdaunt struggles against faster threats that can take a boosted Aqua Jet, such as Zarude, Keldeo, and Hydreigon, so checks to these are good partners. Amoonguss, for example, can switch into Keldeo and Zarude, while Fairy-types like Togekiss can check Hydreigon. Pokemon that can spread paralysis such as Jirachi and the aforementioned Togekiss can help Crawdaunt bypass its low Speed. Sticky Web support from Ribombee is also useful for the same reason. This set also appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Rhyperior and Excadrill.

Salamence.overview: Salamence is a very versatile defensive and offensive presence. Its typing, natural bulk, and Intimidate allow it to check common threats such as Excadrill, Zarude, and Conkeldurr. It's also a solid Defogger, matching up well against entry hazard setters such as Excadrill, Skarmory, and Cobalion. Salamence can utilize its solid Special Attack, decent Speed tier, and powerful moves like Hurricane and Draco Meteor as a strong special attacker, or it can sweep teams with Dragon Dance and Moxie. That, coupled with coverage in Flamethrower and Earthquake, makes Salamence difficult to predict and revenge kill. However, its reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots means Salamence does not appreciate Knock Off from Pokemon it’s supposed to check, such as Tangrowth and Krookodile. Bulky Fairy-types like Hatterene and Primarina can easily take a hit and KO Salamence, while many other threats like Jirachi, Gyarados, and Nidoking carry Ice-type coverage. Offensive threats such as Thundurus-T and Nihilego outspeed it, and Dragon Dance sets are also vulnerable to revenge killers with priority such as Mamoswine and Lycanroc-D. Salamence also faces fierce competition from Hydreigon; Hydreigon's higher Special Attack stat alongside Dark-type STAB moves lets it better deal with popular defensive stalwarts such as Slowking and Aegislash, and it has greater item versatility by virtue of its neutrality to Stealth Rock. However, Salamence has a far better matchup against Pokemon such as Conkeldurr and Tapu Bulu, and it's able to outspeed and revenge kill opposing Hydreigon.
Salamence.comments:
Other Options

An Intimidate Dragon Dance set using Roost over Outrage can work on Magneton teams to check problematic answers to Excadrill such as Zarude while remaining offensively potent. Fire Blast over Flamethrower on the special attacking set gives Salamence more power against Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash; however, it is less reliable and the additional power is often unneeded. Lum Berry can give Salamence more room to set up on Pokemon like Swampert and Tangrowth, but it doesn't carry as much consistent utility as Life Orb. Dragon Tail on the defensive set over Dual Wingbeat lets Salamence spread residual damage with entry hazards, though this is less functional than Toxic against foes like Azumarill. Choice Scarf alongside Moxie can give Salamence surprising sweeping potential, as it doesn't require a setup turn to outspeed targets such as Keldeo and revenge kills sweepers such as Gyarados. Choice Specs improves Salamence's wallbreaking ability and can lure Rhyperior in to nail it with Hydro Pump.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Pokemon such as Azumarill, Primarina, and Hatterene take advantage of Salamence's lack of coverage for them, having the bulk to take a hit and either set up or KO Salamence. Though a niche option, Diancie completely walls any special attacking variants of Salamence, has the bulk to survive a +1 Earthquake from Dragon Dance sets, and can KO Salamence or use it as a free chance to use Heal Bell.

Rock-types: Without Draco Meteor, special Salamence struggles to relieve Stealth Rock pressure from Nihilego, though it must be wary of Earthquake. Lycanroc-D can OHKO offensive variants of Salamence with -1 Stone Edge after minimal chip damage and easily revenge kill it with Accelerock, though Lycanroc-D cannot switch into Salamence safely.

Walls: Pokemon like Chansey and Slowking can handle special Salamence with their massive special bulk and use it for momentum with Teleport. However, the two cannot reliably tank hits from Dragon Dance sets. Umbreon and Mandibuzz have the natural bulk to survive Salamence's special attacks and take advantage of Dragon Dance sets with Foul Play. Celesteela is an especially detrimental defensive threat because it completely walls Dragon Dance sets without Fire Blast.

Mamoswine: Mamoswine is the most consistent revenge killer against Salamence, as Ice Shard OHKOes any set.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
Draco Meteor helps Salamence revenge kill Hydreigon and deals solid damage to neutral targets like Swampert, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H. Hurricane 2HKOes Assault Vest Tangrowth and has a significant chance to OHKO Amoonguss after Stealth Rock. It also prevents Slowking from switching into Salamence. Defog can be used over either STAB move, though this sacrifices neutral coverage against Pokemon like Nihilego and Azumarill. Flamethrower is solid coverage against Pokemon such as Jirachi and Aegislash and can finish off weakened targets such as Tapu Bulu and Heracross without risking a Hurricane miss. Roost alongside Heavy-Duty Boots makes Salamence harder to wear down by threats like Jirachi and Zarude. Intimidate makes Salamence a more reliable switch-in to threats such as Conkeldurr and Excadrill while making them easier to pivot around.

This set fits on bulky offense and balance teams for its wallbreaking capabilities against Pokemon like Amoonguss and important defensive utility against other foes like Conkeldurr. Swampert and Excadrill are able to break through Salamence's checks like Diancie and Nihilego, provide Stealth Rock support to soften up defensive Pokemon such as Celesteela, and capitalize on support against Tangrowth. Excadrill also pressures Hatterene and Togekiss and provides Rapid Spin support so Salamence can drop Defog. Aegislash is a very effective partner that is able to break through Slowking and check Diancie. Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine takes advantage of Salamence removing potential roadblocks such as Amoonguss and Skarmory, and they threaten Stealth Rock setters Salamence has troubles against like Chansey and Nihilego. Zarude, Slowking, and Cobalion are effective pivots to safely bring Salamence into foes such as Hydreigon and Tangrowth. Slowking in particular provides slow pivoting with Teleport so Salamence can safely enter on Grass-types, as well as providing a stronger backbone against Conkeldurr with Colbur Berry. Rotom-W also acts as a pivot to bring Salamence in on Tangrowth and can check Mamoswine and Celesteela. Azelf can handle faster Pokemon such as Nihilego and Lycanroc-D.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
At +1 Speed, Salamence outspeeds revenge killers like Azelf, Thundurus-T, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. At +2 Speed, it blows past even faster revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Zarude. +1 Outrage destroys many neutral targets like Rotom-W, Rotom-W, and Krookodile, though there is always the risk of Fairy-types like Azumarill and Primarina revenge killing Salamence. +1 Dual Wingbeat OHKOes targets such as Conkeldurr, Tapu Bulu, and Amoonguss after Stealth Rock. Dual Wingbeat also has the benefit of hitting Keldeo through Substitute, though risking a burn from Scald is not ideal. Earthquake OHKOes Aegislash and Jirachi at +2. Fire Blast can be used instead to lure in and break through Skarmory and increase Salamence's chances for a Moxie sweep. Life Orb can be used to OHKO Pokemon such as Aegislash with +1 Earthquake and Primarina with +2 Dual Wingbeat. It can also be used alongside a Naive nature to ensure that Fire Blast OHKOes Skarmory after Stealth Rock. However, Salamence's Stealth Rock weakness and Life Orb recoil will quickly put it into range for Lycanroc-D's Accelerock. Moxie helps Salamence get multiple boosts to KO bulky targets like Aegislash and makes it more difficult to revenge kill.

This set fits on offense and hyper offense teams as a wallbreaker or late-game cleaner with Moxie. Excadrill is an excellent lead that sets Stealth Rock to wear down bulky Pokemon such as Rotom-W and provides Rapid Spin. Sticky Web from Ribombee lets Salamence outspeed foes such as Nihilego. Celesteela walls this set, so early-game wallbreakers such as Nasty Plot Thundurus-T and Azelf are decent options. They also appreciate Salamence's ability to threaten Chansey. Other teammates that overwhelm physically bulky Pokemon such as Quagsire and Skarmory, such as Gyarados and Aegislash are valuable assets to this set. They also heavily benefit Salamence by overwhelming checks like Amoonguss and Primarina. Pivots such as Jirachi and Zarude can position Salamence to set up on Pokemon like Tangrowth. Mamoswine is a consistent revenge killer against Salamence, so teammates that KO it such as Azumarill are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Dual Wingbeat is a reliable STAB move that helps against threats to defensive teams such as Substitute Keldeo. Toxic can be used instead to cripple Stealth Rock setters such as Rhyperior and wear down wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T, though Salamence becomes much more passive against Conkeldurr. Flamethrower wears down Steel-types like Excadrill and Celesteela, though Earthquake can be used to KO Nihilego while retaining coverage for the former. Earthquake Intimidate alongside the additional HP investment makes Salamence a more sturdy switch-in to Conkeldurr, Zarude, and Gyarados, although it has to be wary of the latter's Ice Fang. Maximum Speed investment is needed to make Salamence less passive against offensive threats such as Hydreigon and Krookodile.

This set is suited for stall teams to relieve entry hazard pressure from setters like Excadrill and Krookodile and check dangerous Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Conkeldurr. Other entry hazard setters such as Necrozma and Nihilego are significant threats, so Chansey and Jirachi can help outlast them while also providing their own Stealth Rock support. Umbreon can check Pokemon Salamence can't handle by itself like Mamoswine and Gyarados, and it heavily appreciates Salamence’s support against Fighting-types. Quagsire keeps Salamence from being overwhelmed by opposing Dragon Dance Salamence and Lycanroc-D and benefits from Salamence checking Grass-types. Knock Off support from teammates such as Nihilego is very beneficial so that Salamence can outlast threats such as Aegislash. Bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth are useful switch-ins into special attackers such as Primarina and Thundurus-T. Amoonguss and physically defensive Tangrowth are also good switch-ins to Knock Off. Hatterene can ease Salamence's role as a hazard remover with Magic Bounce.

Jirachi.overview: Jirachi's wide movepool, great utility options like Healing Wish, and amazing ability in Serene Grace make it a potent and versatile force in UU. Serene Grace gives Iron Head a high chance to flinch slower foes like Hydreigon, making Choice Scarf Jirachi extremely difficult to deal with for offensive teams. Additionally, Jirachi's above average bulk and great defensive typing allow it to check threats like Nihilego and Hatterene. Jirachi can fulfill a wide variety of roles on teams, whether it's revenge killing threats like Azelf with Choice Scarf, serving as a potent progress maker with its SubToxic set that can get through typical checks such as Amoonguss and Hippowdon, healing its team with Wish, or providing great utility in the form of Stealth Rock and Healing Wish. However, Jirachi's reliance on Leftovers for checking Pokemon like Salamence and Hatterene makes it susceptible to Knock Off from Nihilego and Tangrowth. Jirachi has only average offensive stats, making it very reliant on Iron Head flinches to make progress against foes it lacks coverage for, with common defensive staples like Skarmory, Excadrill, and Amoonguss walling it regardless.
Jirachi.comments:
Other Options

Thunder is an option on Jirachi's Stealth Rock set to spread paralysis and allows Jirachi to beat Moltres and Skarmory, but it is difficult to fit over more useful moves.Jirachi can utilize a special attacker set with Meteor Beam to lure in and remove common switch-ins like Moltres and Rotom-H. However, this set struggles to cover everything. Jirachi can use Calm Mind sets to sweep on hyper offense teams, but these also struggle to choose their coverage. Jirachi can utilize a mixed set, which can notably KO Amoonguss with Psychic while nailing Hatterene with Iron Head, but it lacks in power compared to other offensive Psychic-types like Azelf. Jirachi can run Stored Power sets with Calm Mind and Weakness Policy to accumulate many boosts and sweep, but these sets struggle to get past Swords Dance Scizor and defensive Celesteela and can be ineffective without many boosts.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure take very little from Jirachi's attacks and can force it out with their powerful STAB attacks. Jirachi especially dislikes a burn from Moltres's Flame Body. However, none of them like Jirachi using Trick to remove their Heavy-Duty Boots.

Steel-types: Celesteela takes very little from Jirachi's attacks and can wear it down with Leech Seed + Flamethrower. Scizor walls Jirachi without Fire Punch and can use it as setup fodder or force it out. Excadrill also walls Jirachi and can devastate it with Earthquake. Cobalion and Skarmory can set entry hazards in front of Jirachi and chip it with Rocky Helmet recoil, though they dislike Trick and Thunder Wave.

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Rotom-W, Seismitoad, and Swampert take very little from Jirachi's attacks and can cripple it or decently damage it. Slowking only fears Trick from Jirachi and can cripple it with a Scald burn.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Zarude, Krookodile, and Hydreigon offensively threaten Jirachi and force it out. Zarude and Choice Scarf sets of the latter two can revenge kill non-Choice Scarf Jirachi, with Choice Scarf Zarude outspeeding Choice Scarf variants as well. Mandibuzz and Umbreon don't mind Iron Head much and can wear it down with Foul Play. The latter also uses Inner Focus to block flinches and freely pass Wish to its teammates.

Knock Off: Pokemon carrying Knock Off like Tangrowth and Azelf can remove Leftovers to cripple defensive Jirachi, especially sets without Wish. Choice Scarf Jirachi becomes a much worse revenge killer without its item and can struggle to use Trick and Healing Wish effectively.

Residual Damage and Status: Due to Jirachi lacking reliable one-turn recovery, it is prone to getting worn down by entry hazards like Spikes as well as Rocky Helmet users like Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Jirachi also hates burns and paralysis from Pokemon like Moltres and Chansey, with paralysis making it hard to outspeed threats like Excadrill and leverage U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Jirachi is a potent revenge killer, outspeeding threats like Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and +1 Dragon Dance Gyarados. Iron Head can OHKO Pokemon like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D and, in conjunction with Serene Grance, possibly break through Pokemon like Hydreigon and Primarina with flinches. U-turn gets momentum against switch-ins like Skarmory and Excadrill as well as Pokemon it may not have coverage for like Gyarados and Thundurus-T. Trick lets Jirachi cripple Scizor and defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Slowking, but losing Choice Scarf compromises Jirachi's ability to revenge kill Pokemon like Azelf and Zarude, so it should be used wisely. Ice Punch is an option to nail Thundurus-T and Salamence, while Thunder Punch more reliably beats Gyarados and Azumarill. Zen Headbutt lets Jirachi slam Amoonguss, Keldeo, and Conkeldurr. However, locking into coverage moves leaves Jirachi open to threats like Scizor and Excadrill. Jirachi can utilize Healing Wish late-game to give a teammate another chance to sweep or defensively answer a threat.

Choice Scarf Jirachi fits on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its revenge killing capabilities and Healing Wish. Zarude makes an excellent partner for it, completely blanking Slowking and Hippowdon, threatening Excadrill, and absorbing status and Knock Off. Amoonguss can also absorb Knock Off and can check faster threats like Choice Scarf Zarude. Wallbreakers like Thundurus-T, Conkeldurr, and Hydreigon can be brought in via U-turn on checks like Moltres, Excadrill, and Tangrowth. They all can benefit from Healing Wish too. Moltres forms a solid pivoting core with Jirachi, with each bringing the other in on their answers. Moltres also helps check Celesteela, Excadrill, Scizor, and Amoonguss, while Jirachi can revenge kill threats like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Moltres and Excadrill can provide entry hazard control to keep Jirachi from getting worn down. Entry hazard support from Nihilego and Hippowdon helps Jirachi wear down Pokemon like Primarina and Hatterene more easily. Nihilego and Hippowdon can also help check threats like Moltres and Salamence.

sets.name: SubToxic
sets.description:
Jirachi can set up Substitute against Pokemon that are either unable or unlikely to break through it, such as Chansey and Slowking, and Pokemon that it can force out such as Hatterene and Nihilego. Substitute provides Jirachi with a safe opportunity to use Toxic against its checks like Hippowdon, Moltres, and Swampert, or a safety net to repeatedly use Iron Head against Pokemon like Tangrowth and Amoonguss without risk. Fire Punch offers coverage against Steel-types such as Scizor, Cobalion, and Skarmory while boasting a significant 20% burn chance via Serene Grace, which can be used to stack up damage alongside Iron Head flinches to better pressure Toxic-immune Pokemon like Skarmory and Amoonguss. On top of this, a burned Amoonguss is unable to break Jirachi's Substitute in a single hit, turning it into setup bait for later in the game. Toxic pairs fantastically with Substitute and Iron Head, letting Jirachi wear down and break through Pokemon it would otherwise struggle with such as Slowking and Mandibuzz, as well as crippling offensive checks such as Keldeo, Thundurus-T, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. Maximum HP investment provides Jirachi with 101 HP Substitutes, preventing Chansey's Seismic Toss from breaking them, while reducing the chance for Slowking to break them with Scald to a low 12.5%. This HP investment also prevents Rotom-W and Rotom-H from breaking Jirachi's Substitute with Volt Switch.

SubToxic Jirachi fits best on balance teams that can defensively assist it against Pokemon like Scizor, Moltres, and Keldeo, which it can let in short-term, and provide other forms of support such as additional Toxic users and Heal Bell. Teammates that use Toxic reduce the number of setup turns Jirachi requires to break through checks such as Hippowdon. Celesteela and Skarmory are perfect candidates for this role, encouraging Pokemon like Hippowdon, Slowking, and Moltres to switch into them and be poisoned while providing key defensive support against Pokemon like Scizor, Zarude, and Excadrill. Skarmory can also provide Spikes support to further wear down switch-ins to Jirachi like Amoonguss and Excadrill. SubToxic Jirachi mandates partners such as Scizor and Krookodile that can remove Rocky Helmet from common users of it such as Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Scizor is also able to remove the items of other notable Jirachi checks, such as Celesteela and Hippowdon's Leftovers and Moltres's Heavy-Duty Boots, while Krookodile can provide Stealth Rock support. Hippowdon and Excadrill are also fantastic options for Stealth Rock setters that pair well with Jirachi, switching into Knock Off variants of Nihilego so Jirachi can maintain its Leftovers. Hippowdon can help check Cobalion, Excadrill, and Zygarde-10% for Jirachi, while Excadrill can provide Rapid Spin support and a safer initial switch into an potential unrevealed Grass Knot Nihilego. Slowking is also fantastic due to checking various Steel-types such as Celesteela, Cobalion, and Excadrill, which Jirachi struggles with, and various other offensive threats such as Moltres and Salamence. Offensive teammates such as Keldeo and Moltres greatly appreciate Jirachi's ability to overwhelm their shared checks such as Amoonguss and Slowking, and in return they can provide Jirachi with useful pivots into these Pokemon. SubToxic Jirachi also fits well on more defensive balance and semi-stall teams, greatly appreciating Wish support from Umbreon letting it use Substitute more freely, and Heal Bell support from Pokemon like Chansey and Articuno lets it more aggressively switch into Slowking and freely attack Moltres. Umbreon and Chansey can also help check threats to Jirachi such as Moltres and Infiltrator Noivern, while Articuno can keep the field clear of entry hazards from Jirachi's checks such as Skarmory and Hippowdon.

sets.name: Wish + Protect
sets.description:
Wish keeps Jirachi healthy throughout a match, allowing it to check threats like Salamence and Hatterene more reliably. Jirachi can pass Wish to teammates that lack reliable recovery like Swampert. It distinguishes itself from Umbreon in this role thanks to U-turn, which makes passing Wishes easier. U-turn also allows Jirachi to pivot out against threats like Excadrill and Mandibuzz. Protect ensures Jirachi will receive its Wish and nets more Leftovers recovery. It also lets Jirachi scout Choice-locked threats like Zygarde-10% and Hydreigon. 240 Speed EVs let Jirachi outspeed Hydreigon, with the remaining EVs put in Special Defense and HP to better check Pokemon like Salamence and Nihilego.

This set best fits on balance teams, which appreciate Jirachi healing the team with Wish while bringing teammates in safely with U-turn. Wallbreakers that get worn down easily like Mamoswine, Keldeo, and Conkeldurr greatly enjoy Wish, and U-turn can bring them in on targets like Celesteela and Excadrill. Hippowdon, Rhyperior, and Nihilego check threats like Moltres, Thundurus-T, and Rotom-H. The latter two enjoy Jirachi offsetting their lack of recovery with Wish support in return. They can also act as primary checks to Salamence and Noivern to lessen the load on Jirachi. Amoonguss can check Zarude and absorb Knock Off for Jirachi. Moltres also checks Zarude and can beat Steel-types like Scizor and Skarmory that Jirachi lures in. Zarude can bring Jirachi in safely to use Wish against Zarude's checks like Togekiss while also removing Slowking. Rotom-W forms a great defensive core with Jirachi, being able to check threats like Moltres, Autotomize Celesteela, and Starmie. It also enjoys having the freedom to run Defog or Will-O-Wisp over Pain Split. Tentacruel and Excadrill can clear Spikes, while Jirachi can offset their lack of recovery.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
U-turn generates momentum against switch-ins like Scizor and Moltres. Jirachi can easily get Stealth Rock up against many Pokemon it forces out like Nihilego and Mamoswine, making it a decent Stealth Rock setter. Healing Wish is used late-game to enable a teammate's sweep or ability to check a threat. 240 Speed EVs and a Jolly Nature let Jirachi outspeed Hydreigon, with the rest put in Special Defense and HP to better answer Nihilego and Salamence.

This set works best on bulky offense teams, which appreciate Jirachi's supportive capabilities. Salamence is an excellent partner for Jirachi, pressuring Pokemon like Excadrill and Tangrowth. In return, Jirachi helps take on Fairy- and Rock-types like Hatterene, Togekiss, and Nihilego. Amoonguss can absorb Knock Off for Jirachi and check threats like Zarude and Swampert. Wallbreakers like Thundurus-T and Choice Specs Primarina appreciate Jirachi's U-turn getting them in against Pokemon like Celesteela and Moltres. They also appreciate Jirachi providing Stealth Rock to soften up checks like Tangrowth and Slowking. Jirachi can form a potent VoltTurn core with Rotom-H and Rotom-W, as they can force out threats to Jirachi like Moltres and Celesteela. They can also provide Defog support to prevent Spikes from wearing Jirachi down. Late-game sweepers like Swords Dance Scizor and Gyarados appreciate Jirachi's Healing Wish, letting them break earlier in the game and be revived to clean late-game.

Roserade.overview: Roserade is a potent entry hazard setter in the tier due to Spikes and the ability to punish switch-ins such as Salamence, Aegislash, and Jirachi with Sleep Powder. Its solid STAB moves in Leaf Storm and Sludge Bomb allow it to hit a plethora of staples such as Rhyperior, Primarina, and Tangrowth super effectively while also threatening others with Sludge Bomb poisons. Its typing lets Roserade check key Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Primarina, and Amoonguss. Roserade's Defense and Speed leave much to be desired, though, making it easy to revenge kill by many offensive Pokemon such as Krookodile, Lycanroc-D, and Salamence. It is also unable to touch Steel-types such as Celesteela, Jirachi, and Aegislash, barring Sleep Powder. Roserade faces competition with other Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth, which offer better defensive utility against threats like Keldeo, Azumarill, and Krookodile but lack Spikes and are passive, and offense threats like Zarude, Nihilego, and Nidoking, which are more threatening due to better coverage and Speed.
Roserade.comments:
Other Options

A more specially defensive spread can be used to better check foes such as Keldeo, Raikou, and Primarina. Life Orb makes Roserade a greater offensive threat and lets it OHKO threats such as Buzzwole and Necrozma with entry hazard support; this does, however, severely worsen its longevity. Leaf Storm is a powerful move it can run; however, the Special Attack drop makes it easier to take advantage of. Toxic Spikes aids wallbreakers such as Keldeo and Zygarde-10% in breaking down checks like Tangrowth, Primarina, and Buzzwole and generally annoys the opposing team, but Spikes is usually better due to the abundance of Poison-immune Pokemon and Poison-types.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Roserade cannot touch Aegislash, Celesteela, and Jirachi, aside from an inaccurate Sleep Powder, and gives them a free switch or opportunity to set up.

Fire-types: Entei, Rotom-H, and Moltres threaten to OHKO Roserade with powerful Fire-type moves and force it out; however, they do not appreciate switching in on Sludge Bomb.

Psychic-types: Galarian Slowbro, Reuniclus, and Azelf are able to threaten Roserade with their STAB moves and force it out or set up on it. The former two can easily sponge Roserade's attacks, only fearing Sleep Powder. Azelf cannot switch into Roserade directly, but it can outspeed and force it out.

Faster Threats and Priority: Zarude, Salamence, Lycanroc-D, and Krookodile outspeed Roserade and threaten to deal heavy damage to it. Slower Pokemon with priority such as Mamoswine and Diggersby are also able to threaten Roserade.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Umbreon, Galarian Moltres, and Chansey can switch into Roserade, with Chansey also not fearing status due to Natural Cure. Mantine is notable, as it tanks Leaf Storm and removes Spikes with Defog.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description:
Giga Drain provides recovery and make it easier to forgo Synthesis. Sludge Bomb hits Grass-resistant Pokemon like Zarude, Moltres, and Amoonguss while also threatening to poison foes like Mantine and Rotom-H. Roserade is excellent at setting Spikes due to its tendency to force switches. Sleep Powder is preferred to cripple switch-ins such as Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro, although Synthesis can be used to better check threats such as Primarina, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth and more comfortably set Spikes on walls such as Chansey and Mantine. Black Sludge helps Roserade better check Primarina and Rotom-W while also allowing it to passively heal up residual damage. The EV spread allows it to survive two Secret Swords from Choice Specs Keldeo.

Roserade's ability to set up Spikes makes it an excellent partner for powerful wallbreakers such as Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, Salamence, and Gyarados. Krookodile and Nihilego can form an entry hazard stacking core with Roserade, pairing up its Spikes with Stealth Rock. Krookodile also becomes able to switch into a slept Aegislash without getting punished by Toxic, while Nihilego is able to threaten Fire-types like Moltres and Rotom-H. They also remove items like Eviolite on Chansey and Leftovers on Aegislash with Knock Off, letting Roserade wear them down more easily. Due to its weakness to foes like Moltres and Mamoswine, Roserade appreciates Water-types such as Rotom-W, Keldeo, and Primarina; in return, Roserade resists Grass- and Electric-type moves for them. Steel-types such as Jirachi, Celesteela, and Aegislash also make for stellar teammates, as they resist Flying- and Psychic-type attacks that Roserade struggles with. Pokemon such as Moltres, Nidoking, and Buzzwole threaten Steel-types that Roserades struggle with. Entry hazard removers such as Starmie, Rotom-W, and Salamence allow Roserade to stay healthy throughout longer games, although Defoggers like the latter two also remove its Spikes. Faster Pokemon such as Noivern, Mienshao, and Zygarde-10% threaten problematic foes such as Zarude, Krookodile, and Salamence and benefit from Spikes wearing down their checks.

Gastrodon.overview: Gastrodon is an incredible mixed wall for balance teams due to its incredible typing and access to Recover. Its ability in Storm Drain gives it an important Water immunity that allows it to switch into threats such as Rotom-W and scout Keldeo with a Choice item, while Gastrodon's stellar typing lets it reliably switch into most Fire- and Electric-type Pokemon not running specific coverage for it such as Rotom-H, Thundurus-T, and Chandelure. It additionally serves as a consistent answer to Nidoking. Gastrodon, however, carries a quadruple weakness to Grass, leaving it taken advantage of by Grass-type Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Zarude in particular is very problematic as Jungle Healing prevents it from being crippled by Toxic or a Scald burn. Gastrodon is also vulnerable to coverage from threats such as Nihilego with Grass Knot and Gyarados with Power Whip. Gastrodon is also rather passive due to its mediocre attacking stats, it relies heavily on status to make progress in games against bulkier teams, and struggles to stop setup sweepers such as Kommo-o and Gyarados. Gastrodon is also crippled by status, as it bleeds into its longevity, with Toxic specifically forcing it to leave the field often to avoid being taken out by chip.
Gastrodon.comments:
Other Options

Gastrodon can utilize a Curse set to attempt to be on the more offensive end, but it's highly niche due to how hard it is to set up, as well as threats such as Amoonguss, Tapu Bulu, and Tangrowth being able to easily make work of it.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Grass-type Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss take advantage of Gastrodon's 4x weakness to make quick work of it, as it has little to no way to answer them offensively and it folds to their STAB attacks. Zarude counters Gastrodon as it can easily pivot into it and heal off status. Gastrodon also has to be careful of Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados, Nihilego, and Azelf.

Strong Physical Breakers: Wallbreakers such as Mienshao, Diggersby, and Mamoswine can overpower Gastrodon with their powerful attacks.

Setup Sweepers: Galarian Moltres, Gyarados, and Autotomize Necrozma can threaten to break through Gastrodon's defenses after setup but must be wary to not get hit by status in their attempt to set up.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
Gastrodon's main STAB options in Scald and Earthquake allow it to generate offensive presence while on the field, dealing good damage to tier staples like Lycanroc-D and Moltres, with the former having potential to spread burns onto the opponent. Ice Beam pressures Salamence while catching Grass-types off guard, but due to Gastrodon's relatively weak attacking power, it is unable to 3HKO Amoonguss or Zarude. Dropping Scald also gives Gastrodon no way to punish Rotom-H. Toxic allows Gastrodon to passively chip bulkier targets such as Rotom-W and Salamence which otherwise don't care too much for Gastrodon's STAB attacks. Clear Smog is useful for stopping setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, but it makes Gastrodon painfully passive. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Gastrodon to repeatedly switch in without being worn down by hazards, as they remove a large part of Gastrodon's functionality as a defensive Pokemon. Leftovers is an optional item to give Gastrodon passive recovery, but Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred due to how great ignoring hazard chip is. The spread allows Gastrodon to avoid being 3HKOed by Salamence's Hurricane and Nidoking's Earth Power while having enough defense investment to take on physical attackers such as Rhyperior and Barraskewda reliably. Gastrodon can also run a physically defensive spread, allowing it to better check Lycanroc-D, but powerful wallbreakers like Mamoswine and Diggersby can still overwhelm it easily.

Gastrodon belongs on balance and bulky offense teams, where its defensive capabilities shine the most. Grass-types such as Amoonguss are incredible for covering Gastrodon's one weakness, while Gastrodon checks the Fire-types like Moltres that would otherwise threaten them. Both Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can also take on problematic Pokemon like Keldeo and Primarina for Gastrodon, as their powerful attacks can overwhelm it quickly. Zarude in particular enjoys the presence of Gastrodon, as it can bring Gastrodon in on annoying checks to it like Moltres. In return, Zarude can revenge kill wallbreakers like Mamoswine and Diggersby that threaten Gastrodon. Buzzwole and Celesteela can stomach physical attacks for Gastrodon while being solid Grass-resistant Pokemon. Togekiss appreciates Gastrodon taking on Electric-types like Thundurus-T and can take on Grass-types like Zarude in return. It also can function as a cleric to remove status from Gastrodon that would otherwise hinder it. Fire-types such as Chandelure and Rotom-H appreciate Gastrodon's immunity to Water-type moves, as it can switch into those attacks for them. If Gastrodon chooses to run Leftovers, entry hazard removal from the aformentioned Rotom-H and Salamence can help keep Gastrodon from getting worn down by entry hazards.

Hippowdon.overview: Hippowdon is a potent mixed wall in UU thanks to its amazing bulk, solid typing, and reliable recovery. Its naturally high Defense allows it to invest in Special Defense to check Salamence and Thundurus-T while still answering physical attackers like Excadrill, Zygarde-10%, and Cobalion. Hippowdon is a great Stealth Rock setter due to matching up well against common entry hazard removers like Salamence, Mandibuzz, Excadrill, and Tentacruel and easily setting Stealth Rock against Pokemon it walls like Excadrill, Cobalion, and Nihilego without Grass Knot. Utility options, like Toxic to cripple Tangrowth and Rotom-W and Whirlwind to keep setup sweepers like Scizor from setting up on it, limit Hippowdon's passivity. However, Hippowdon is still quite passive, relying on Toxic to cripple the common Grass- and Water-types that beat it; even then, threats like Zarude and RestTalk Primarina don't mind it. Certain setup sweepers like Bulky Swords Dance Scizor and Autotomize Celesteela can use Hippowdon as a free entry point, as well as setup fodder if it forgoes Whirlwind, which usually happens due to Toxic being very difficult to drop. Even Pokemon Hippowdon should check, like Nihilego, Thundurus-T, Rotom-H, and Moltres, can get around it by using coverage moves like Grass Knot or crippling it with Toxic.
Hippowdon.comments:
Other Options

Hippowdon can run a Curse set, but the presence of common Water- and Grass-types keeps this set from succeeding. Ice Fang can hit Salamence and Thundurus-T without Hippowdon relying on Toxic, while Fire Fang threatens Scizor. However, these moves fail to provide the utility Toxic provides. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used on teams without entry hazard removal to stop Spikes from wearing down Hippowdon, but it typically gets hit by Knock Off from switching into threats like Nihilego and Thundurus-T.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Zarude completely walls Hippowdon, ignoring Toxic thanks to Jungle Healing and threatening to KO it. Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu hate Toxic but can threaten Hippowdon with heavy damage. Grass-type coverage on Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Azelf means Hippowdon must scout their movesets before switching in.

Water-types: Offensive Water-types like Keldeo, Azumarill, and Starmie deal massive damage to Hippowdon with their attacks. Rotom-W, Slowking, and RestTalk Primarina can switch into Hippowdon well, though the former two hate Toxic.

Status Moves: Hippowdon gets worn down more easily if crippled by Toxic, with many common threats like Chansey and Swampert carrying this move. Even Pokemon Hippowdon is supposed to check like Moltres, Rotom-H, and Zygarde-10% can fit Toxic to cripple it.

Toxic-immune Setup Sweepers: Sweepers like Autotomize Celesteela, Calm Mind Reuniclus, Iron Defense Skarmory, and Swords Dance Scizor use Hippowdon as setup fodder unless it fits Whirlwind, exploiting its low damage output and their immunities to Toxic.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Earthquake hits threats like Nihilego, Nidoqueen, Raikou, and Excadrill hard. Hippowdon's naturally high Attack also prevents Amoonguss from switching in for free, especially with additional sand damage and Stealth Rock, wearing it down despite Regenerator. Toxic cripples switch-ins like Slowking, Rotom-W, and Tangrowth. It also makes Hippowdon less passive against wallbreakers like Thundurus-T and Hydreigon and lets it beat Defoggers like Salamence and Rotom-W. Whirlwind is an option to phaze setup sweepers like Swords Dance Scizor and Autotomize Celesteela, but Toxic crippling so many answers to Hippowdon makes it too good to pass up most of the time. However, Whirlwind and Toxic can be run together if Hippowdon is used alongside another Stealth Rock setter like Nihilego. Slack Off gives Hippowdon reliable recovery to consistently handle threats like Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Zygarde-10%. Sand Stream helps chip down threats like Chansey and Thundurus-T, though Sand Force can be used if sand damage is detrimental to Hippowdon's team. Leftovers gives Hippowdon passive recovery and lets it spend fewer turns using Slack Off, while Rocky Helmet chips down threats like Cobalion, Scizor, and Diggersby. Rocky Helmet also lets Hippowdon counter lead Excadrill by preventing it from using Rapid Spin, allowing itself to set Stealth Rock. The given EV spread alongside an Impish nature lets Hippowdon OHKO Excadrill with Earthquake, avoid the 2HKO from Zygarde-10%'s Outrage if it has Leftovers, and better check special attackers like Salamence and Thundurus-T. If running Rocky Helmet, 112 Defense EVs are needed to avoid the 2HKO from Outrage.

Hippowdon best fits on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams that appreciate a reliable Stealth Rock setter that is also a sustainable wall. Skarmory forms a great entry hazard-stacking core with Hippowdon, providing Spikes to complement its Stealth Rock while also beating Zarude, Mamoswine, and Scizor; in return, it appreciates Hippowdon beating Defoggers it loses to like Salamence. Nihilego makes a solid partner due to it beating Autotomize Celesteela and serving as a potent Stealth Rock setter, allowing Hippowdon to run both Toxic and Whirlwind. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss check Water-types like Keldeo, Primarina, and Azumarill for Hippowdon, with the latter also handling opposing Tangrowth. Zarude can counter Rotom-W and Slowking and switch into a predicted Grass Knot from Thundurus-T. Entry hazard removers like Mandibuzz and Tentacruel remove Spikes, which wear down Hippowdon. Mandibuzz also acts as a secondary check to Zygarde-10% and can discourage Swords Dance Scizor from boosting with the threat of Foul Play. Moltres and Salamence like Hippowdon's entry hazards and sand chip damage wearing down Slowking, and they remove Scizor, Skarmory, and Zarude for it in return. On stall teams, Umbreon can be used to increase Hippowdon's longevity with Wish and answer Mamoswine and Gyarados, while Articuno can remove status with Heal Bell.

Rhyperior.overview: Rhyperior stands out as an Electric-immune Pokemon and Stealth Rock user, as it is one of the few defensive Ground-types available. It has a stronger offensive presence than Swampert and more defensive utility than Nidoqueen and Krookodile with its typing that allows it to switch into Rotom-H, Galarian Slowbro, and Salamence. Its unique Solid Rock ability also allows it to blanket check a good portion of the metagame, stomaching strong super effective hits like Focus Blast from Thundurus-T and Close Combat from Lycanroc-D. Its STAB moves have reliable coverage for a majority of the metagame, covering Pokemon like Galarian Moltres, Aegislash, and Galarian Slowbro hard and threatening common entry hazard removers such as Salamence and Rotom-H. However, it remains vulnerable to common Grass-, Water-, and Fighting-types such as Zarude, Azumarill, and Keldeo, which threaten to KO it with little to no chip. Powerful wallbreakers like Nidoking, Mamoswine, Conkeldurr, and Hydreigon can muscle past Rhyperior. Regenerator users like Tangrowth and Amoonguss are annoying too, as they can take a majority of Rhyperior's attacks just to heal off with a switch or immediately pressure it with a STAB attack. Rhyperior itself only has Leftovers for passive recovery, leaving it prone to being worn down by entry hazards and wallbreakers like Toxtricity. This means it will not always be able to take strong attacks or answer Pokemon like Salamence or +2 Rotom-H late-game. Rhyperior faces severe competition from other Stealth Rock setters like Excadrill and Nihilego who provide better defensive utility because of their typings and check more relevant threats.
Rhyperior.comments:
Other Options

Roar prevents Pokemon like Galarian Slowbro from setting up on Rhyperior. Smack Down lets Rhyperior pressure Celesteela, Skarmory, and potentially catch Rotom-H and Rotom-W, but it is rather weak and requires careful prediction. Rhyperior can run various coverage moves to solidify certain matchups, since its STAB moves already cover most of the tier. Megahorn can improve its matchup against Psychic-types like Reuniculus while OHKOing Zarude. Ice Punch hits Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Amoonguss.
