High Horsepower can be used over Earthquake to avoid being weakened by Grassy Terrain but is only worth the decreased power and accuracy when Tapu Bulu is on the same team. Poison Jab hits Tapu Bulu, Primarina, and Azumarill and prevents them from easily setting up. However, all extra coverage is matchup-dependent and will not be as consistently valuable as Swords Dance or Toxic. Choice Band Rhyperior can be a strong wallbreaker but is outclassed by Lycanroc-D, which has a better Speed tier to take advantage of its coverage with.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Primarina, Azumarill, and Rotom-W all have the bulk to switch into Rhyperior and can OHKO it with a STAB move. RestTalk Primarina and Pain Split Rotom-W can be especially difficult to wear down.

Fighting-types: Rhyperior is forced out by common Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Conkeldurr. Keldeo can threaten Rhyperior out with 4x super effective STAB moves and proceed to set up or use Flip Turn. Conkeldurr can stomach a hit and regain lost health with Drain Punch.

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Amoonguss and Tangrowth can sponge anything Rhyperior throws at them and heal back with Regenerator or threaten it with a STAB move. Tapu Bulu weakens Rhyperior's Earthquake with its Grassy Terrain and can switch into its moves. Zarude can outspeed and OHKO Rhyperior with Power Whip. Rhyperior also has to be careful of Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Nihilego and Azelf as well.

Status: Pokemon that Rhyperior frequently pivots against such as defensive Salamence and Rotom-H can wear it down with Toxic and make it hard to deal with them throughout the match. This is especially bothersome for Protect Rhyperior.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Stone Edge and Earthquake are Rhyperior's best STAB moves with consistent power, threatening common Pokemon like Rotom-H, Salamence, and Aegislash. Swords Dance lets Rhyperior set up on Pokemon that it can wall like Rotom-H to muscle past slower foes such as Amoonguss and Celesteela. Toxic cripples Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth. Protect allows Rhyperior to scout against Choice Scarf Zarude and Choice Specs Hydreigon and can let it gain more recovery from Leftovers. Rhyperior runs maximum Special Defense investment to take advantage of its typing, being able to switch into moves such as Rotom-H's Overheat and Salamence's Hurricane more comfortably.

Rhyperior tends to fit on bulky offense teams with its amount of resistances in combination with its offensive presence. Rhyperior appreciates entry hazard removal from Tentacruel and Rotom-W to keep it from getting worn down by Spikes. In return, Rhyperior can switch into Rotom-H and check Thundurus-T. Electric-types like Thundurus-T beat opposing Water-types that could break through Rhyperior with ease such as Azumarill and Primarina. Thundurus-T appreciates entry hazard support wearing down checks like Tapu Bulu in return. Bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can help against those Water-types in addition to Keldeo. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are also able to safely pivot into Rotom-W as well as Ground-types like Krookodile and Diggersby that check Rhyperior. Both Tangrowth and Amoonguss benefit from Rhyperior countering Rotom-H and Moltres. Steel-types such as Jirachi and Aegislash appreciate Rhyperior's Fire resistance and ability to check Moltres and Rotom-H too, and, in return, they can check Tapu Bulu. Jirachi can also provide Wish support for Rhyperior so it can be played more aggressively early-game. Tapu Bulu also can provide Grassy Terrain support and check Water-types like Azumarill for Rhyperior.

Tangrowth.overview: Tangrowth's stellar ability in Regenerator, massive defense stat, good defensive typing, and solid offensive presence makes Tangrowth one of the best walls in the tier. Tangrowth typically operates with an Assault Vest set, becoming a mixed wall that can check threats like Primarina and Thundurus-T on the special end and Excadrill and Zygarde-10% on the physical end. Full investment in physical defense lets it check Zygarde-10%, Zarude, and Conkeldurr more reliably. Access to moves like Knock Off, Sleep Powder, and Sludge Bomb let Tangrowth severely cripple defensive Pokemon such as Chansey, Aegislash, and Rotom-H. However, Tangrowth's typing can also hinder it, giving it weaknesses to types like Poison and Fire, forcing it to switch out from threats like Nidoking and Moltres. Tangrowth faces competition from Amoonguss as a defensive Grass-type, as the latter's Poison typing lets it check threats like Primarina, Keldeo, and opposing Tangrowth more reliably; it can also put foes to sleep more reliably thanks to Spore. However, Tangrowth's huge Defense, generally lower passivity, and ability to cripple walls like Chansey with Knock Off are invaluable. Tangrowth hates being setup fodder for Pokemon like Galarian Moltres and Galarian Slowbro, which often force it to switch out against them, and its abysmal Special Defense means its physically defensive set struggles against special attackers like Primarina and Thundurus-T. Finally, Assault Vest Tangrowth is prone to Knock Off from Pokemon it would check, like Azelf, which defeats its role as a special wall.
Tangrowth.comments:
Other Options

Leech Seed is an option to wear down switch-ins like Aegislash, but it is easily avoided by switching out and by pivoting from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Moltres. Other Pokemon like opposing Tangrowth, Hatterene, and Amoonguss are not affected by Leech Seed, making it hard to justify using over Giga Drain's immediate recovery. Stun Spore can be considered to slow down and cripple Pokemon like Nidoking, Salamence, and Tentacruel, but its accuracy is shaky and common Pokemon like Thundurus-T and Amoonguss are immune to it. Sleep Powder can immobilize various switch-ins like Salamence and Moltres, preventing them from taking advantage of Tangrowth, but also has shaky accuracy and isn't as consistently useful as other moves. Rock Slide smacks Moltres while additionally dealing fair damage to foes like Thundurus-T. However, it generally offers far worse coverage than Tangrowth's other moves.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Many of the tier's Steel-types can switch directly into Tangrowth. Skarmory completely blanks Tangrowth and can set Spikes against it for free. Celesteela forces physically defensive Tangrowth out with Flamethrower, while Aegislash can cripple Assault Vest variants with Toxic and destroy physically defensive ones with Shadow Ball. However, the latter two dislike Knock Off.

Poison-types: Nidoking, Nihilego, Amoonguss, and Tentacruel can hit Tangrowth with their respective STAB moves, and Tentacruel can also damage Tangrowth with Liquid Ooze if it ever uses Giga Drain. Since they force Tangrowth out with offensive pressure, the former two can use it to set Stealth Rock. Amoonguss takes little from Tangrowth's moves and only dislikes Knock Off, forcing Tangrowth to switch out; this gives Amoonguss a free opportunity to put one of Tangrowth's teammate to sleep via Spore. Tentacruel can remove Tangrowth's Assault Vest with Knock Off.

Fire-types: Tangrowth is extremely pressured by Fire-types such as Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure and is almost always forced out. The former two can use Volt Switch or U-turn, respectively, to predict a switch and keep momentum, but Tangrowth can stomach a Fire-type attack from them and remove their item with Knock Off in return if needed.

Special Attackers: Even with an Assault Vest, Azelf, Salamence, Hydreigon, and Galarian Moltres can all get past Tangrowth with their powerful super effective STAB attacks.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Power Whip is near-mandatory to beat Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina while also dealing greater damage to the likes of Zygarde-10% and Slowking. Alternatively, Giga Drain allows Tangrowth to sustain its health on the field while dealing good damage to Pokemon like Conkeldurr and Keldeo, though it sacrifices the Primarina matchup. Knock Off is extremely useful for crippling common Tangrowth answers, like Chansey, Aegislash, and Celesteela. Sludge Bomb has a decent chance to poison foes like Salamence and is also Tangrowth's best way to hit Zarude and opposing Tangrowth. Earthquake is used to pressure Pokemon such as Aegislash, Tentacruel, and Nihilego. Focus Blast is another option to hit Hydreigon and Cobalion for heavy damage. Assault Vest boosts Tangrowth's miserable Special Defense stat, allowing it to pivot in on Pokemon it normally can't, such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Thundurus-T.

Tangrowth acts as an effective glue on many playstyles, being a reliable defensive pivot that sponges attacks from scary wallbreakers such as Primarina and Thundurus-T. However, Tangrowth can still be overwhelmed by Choice Specs Primarina and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T, so it can't face them alone. Teammates such as Chansey, Aegislash, and Nihilego appreciate Tangrowth's ability to cripple these offensive threats and help check foes like Moltres, Skarmory, and Salamence in return. Tangrowth can't take Fire- and Ice-type attacks from threats such as Moltres and Mamoswine, so teammates like Slowking and Swampert are appreciated. They also act as secondary checks to Zygarde-10%. Despite the amazing Regenerator, Tangrowth is extremely prone to being weakened by Stealth Rock and Spikes, so entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Salamence prevent it from being too worn down. Moltres scares out Amoonguss and Skarmory for Tangrowth. Cobalion helps act as a secondary check to Zarude since Tangrowth cannot chip it due to having an Assault Vest. It also absorbs Knock Off for it.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Knock Off lets Tangrowth cripple switch-ins such as Celesteela, Mandibuzz, Aegislash, and Chansey. Sludge Bomb helps Tangrowth to not be setup fodder for Gyarados and does heavy damage to Tapu Bulu, Hatterene, and opposing Tangrowth. Sludge Bomb's poison chance also helps Tangrowth potentially cripple switch-ins like Salamence and Moltres. Synthesis provides another method of recovery for Tangrowth, allowing it to check threats like Azumarill easier without switching out or attacking. Earthquake can be used to weaken and pressure Pokemon such as Nihilego and Nidoking for other teammates, scaring them from switching in directly into Tangrowth. Rocky Helmet allows Tangrowth to punish physical attackers like Lycanroc-D, Azumarill, and Zarude.

Tangrowth fits very well on archetypes like bulky offense, balance, and stall, which appreciate its defensive capabilities and the utility it provides. Because of Tangrowth's miserable Special Defense, partners that can take on special attackers for it such as Chansey and Celesteela are very appreciated. Chansey can take on Pokemon like Primarina and Hydreigon and set Stealth Rock; its Toxic wearing down common Tangrowth checks such as Moltres is also very appreciated. Water-types such as Rotom-W and Slowking can take strong Fire- and Ice-type attacks for Tangrowth and check threats such as Chandelure and Mamoswine. Slowking also checks Keldeo for Tangrowth. These Water-types appreciate Tangrowth pivoting directly into Zarude and Tapu Bulu. Excadill and Salamence in particular also work as entry hazard removers, and Tangrowth needs this help to avoid getting too weakened. Ground-types such as Excadrill like having Tangrowth as a teammate, as it can take on Water-types such as Azumarill for them.

Togekiss.overview: Togekiss's typing, Roost, and Nasty Plot make it a bulky wallbreaker and a check to top threats like Zarude, Krookodile, and Kommo-o. It's also an amazing stallbreaker, as it can beat Chansey and Quagsire with flinches thanks to Nasty Plot and Heal Bell. However, Togekiss requires heavy support to break through common Pokemon such as Rhyperior, Aegislash, and Rotom-W. It hates Knock Off, as losing Heavy-Duty Boots greatly reduces its ability to check Pokemon like Buzzwole and Kommo-o with Stealth Rock up. Togekiss is outsped by a majority of offensive Pokemon such as Nidoking and Lycanroc-D. It's also very weak before a Nasty Plot boost and is very passive against offensive teams if it lacks Thunder Wave.
Togekiss.comments:
Other Options

Defog can be potentially run on a more defensive utility set, but Togekiss cannot threaten common Stealth Rock users such as Jirachi and Nihilego. Choice Scarf + Trick can outspeed Pokemon such as Keldeo and cripple walls such as Chansey and Umbreon. However, it is very matchup dependent and means Togekiss has to worry about Stealth Rock. Grass Knot can be used to lure in and nail Rhyperior on the offensive set, but Flamethrower is better due to hitting Steel-types such as Celesteela and Aegislash.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H resist Air Slash and are immune to Thunder Wave, turning Togekiss into setup fodder for them.

Rock-types: Rhyperior shrugs off Air Slash and is immune to Thunder Wave. Lycanroc-D and Nihilego can outspeed and remove Togekiss, though they must watch out for Thunder Wave.

Steel-types: Celesteela and Aegislash can switch into Air Slash and threaten Togekiss out with their STAB attacks. Due to their lower Speed, they can potentially lose to flinches. Faster Steel-types such as Jirachi and Cobalion only fear Thunder Wave.

Poison-types: Tentacruel and Nidoking can outspeed and deal heavy damage to Togekiss. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can take multiple hits with its high special bulk, though must be careful of repeated flinches.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot allows Togekiss to break through bulkier teams by setting up on passive Pokemon such as Chansey, Tangrowth, and Umbreon. Heal Bell gives Togekiss and its team status removal for Toxic Aegislash, Will-O-Wisp Rotom-W, and stall staples such as Chansey and Umbreon. Thunder Wave slows down faster Pokemon such as Nihilego and stacks well with Serene Grace Air Slash. It can also act as an emergency check to Dragon Dance Salamence and Necrozma. Roost allows Togekiss to better check Krookodile, Zarude, and Buzzwole throughout a game. Maximum HP and Speed investment allows Togekiss to better check Pokemon such as Kommo-o and outspeed Buzzwole. A set with Flamethrower and a more offensive spread of 76 HP / 180 SpA / 252 Spe can be used to OHKO offensive Aegislash after a Nasty Plot boost.

Togekiss is a good pick on bulky offense and balance due to its great matchup against stall. Rhyperior and Seismitoad provide an Electric immunity to deal with Thundurus-T and the Rotom formes, can use Stealth Rock, and help weaken Pokemon such as Krookodile. Choice Scarf Krookodile and Aegislash can handle Pokemon such as Nihilego, Galarian Slowbro, and Lycanroc-D, while Togekiss can handle Buzzwole. Knock Off absorbers such as Amoonguss and Buzzwole can help Togekiss keep Heavy-Duty Boots, particularly against Krookodile. Buzzwole appreciates Togekiss slowing down threats such as Nihilego with Thunder Wave, and Togekiss appreciates Buzzwole breaking through Rhyperior, Celesteela, and Chansey. Fire-types like Volcanion and Entei can remove Steel-types such as Aegislash and Celesteela. Volcanion also threatens Rock-types like Rhyperior, while Entei can wear down Pokemon with Sacred Fire burns. Zygarde-10% and Mamoswine help Togekiss break through Poison-types such as Tentacruel and Nidoking. Primarina and Kommo-o greatly benefit from stall teams being worn down to enable cleanup.

Mamoswine.overview: Mamoswine is a very powerful wallbreaker in UU due to its amazing offensive typing that allows it to muscle through common walls like Tangrowth, Hippowdon, and Chansey. Ice Shard also gives it a priority option to threaten many faster threats like Thundurus-T, Zygarde-10%, and Salamence, allowing it to fit on teams as a potent revenge killer. Knock Off provides great utility to punish common switch-ins such as Rotom-H and Rotom-W. Unfortunately, Mamoswine has low defenses, below-average speeed, and a bad defensive typing, making it easy prey for common threats like Scizor, Keldeo, and Rotom-W. Without Thick Fat, it has virtually no defensive utility outside of switching into Electric-type attacks, and even then it cannot always check certain Electric-type threats, like Thundurus-T, which lives an Ice Shard from full and KOes back with Focus Blast. Other Ground-type wallbreakers like Excadrill and Zygarde-10% offer better defensive utility and greater Speed, respectively. Mamoswine is prone to wearing itself down between Life Orb recoil and entry hazards, limiting its ability to wallbreak throughout a game.
Mamoswine.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band can be used for more power without the recoil created by Life Orb, but Mamoswine prefers to be able to switch up its moves. Heavy-Duty Boots is another viable option for Mamoswine's item that prevents it from being worn down by entry hazards and Life Orb recoil while still retaining some wallbreaking power. Mamoswine can be used as a Stealth Rock setter but removing any of Mamoswine's four main moves severely limits its wallbreaking potential. Freeze-Dry is an option to OHKO Quagsire and nearly OHKO Swampert with Life Orb as well as better pressure Rotom-W. The utility offered by Knock Off is generally better, though, as it does nearly the same amount of damage as Freeze-Dry to Rotom-W, and Mamoswine can already nearly 2HKO Gastrodon and Quagsire with Earthquake. A Choice Scarf set allows Mamoswine to outspeed its typical fast checks like Zarude and Lycanroc-D, but this set faces a lot of competition from Diggersby, which also has access to U-turn to pivot out of unfavourable matchups.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Mamoswine struggles to break through Skarmory, as it can stomach multiple Icicle Crashes and recover any lost health with Roost while also forcing it out with Body Press. However, Skarmory does need to be careful of taking on Mamoswine if it has taken lots of chip, as a flinch from Icicle Crash can lead to it being KOd. Colbur Berry Slowking also is a strong answer to Mamoswine, being able to take Knock Off and Earthquake well and KO it back with Scald. Swampert and Umbreon can trade damage with Mamoswine, but they can get overwhelmed between having their Leftovers removed and switching in and taking entry hazards.

Rotom-H and Rotom-W: Both Rotom-W and Rotom-H are immune to Earthquake and resist Ice, making it difficult for Mamoswine to break through them. Additionally, both of these Pokemon can typically force Mamoswine out with STAB attacks or status moves, though they need to be wary of Knock Off on the switch.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: UU has many threats like Cobalion, Gyarados, and Keldeo that are faster than Mamoswine and threaten to KO it with super effective attacks. Mamoswine is also weak to multiple priority attacks, allowing Scizor, Azumarill, and Conkeldurr to KO it after minimal chip.

Residual Damage: Since Mamoswine typically needs Life Orb to be effective, it will get worn down quickly, especially if it has to switch into Stealth Rock or Spikes.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Icicle Crash and Earthquake are a devastatingly powerful STAB combination, easily KOing common walls like Amoonguss, Primarina, and Mandibuzz. Ice Shard can threaten many faster threats like Thundurus-T and Zarude, and it can also OHKO offensive Salamence and Zygarde-10%. Knock Off is used to punish and cripple switch-ins like Rotom-H and Rotom-W, allowing Mamoswine or another teammate to break past them more easily later. Oblivious keeps Mamoswine from having its Attack lowered by Intimidate Salamence. Thick Fat in an option that offers better protection against Rotom-H and ensures it can take a Flamethrower from Moltres. Life Orb is preferred, as it allows Mamoswine to safely 2HKO almost anything in the tier, including Celesteela and Chansey. However, Never-Melt Ice also is an option to retain a powerful Icicle Crash while not wearing itself down with Life Orb, but this comes at the cost of a much weaker Earthquake, missing out on a 2HKO on Slowking, even after Stealth Rock. An Adamant Nature maximizes Mamoswine's wallbreaking potential.

Mamoswine best functions on offensive teams that provide it many opportunities to wallbreak. Late-game cleaners like Azelf appreciate Mamoswine's early-game wallbreaking and can deal with faster threats like Cobalion and Keldeo as well as walls like Skarmory. Azelf also wears down Slowking, allowing Mamoswine to break through it easier. Pivots like Zarude, Rotom-W, and Slowking lure in Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss and then pivot to Mamoswine for a more favorable matchup; Slowking in particular provides slow pivoting with Teleport to get Mamoswine in safely. Mamoswine is vulnerable to priority moves from Conkeldurr, Scizor, and Azumarill; Amoonguss can switch into most of their attacks. Entry hazard support from Cobalion and Nihilego can wear down Pokemon like Skarmory and Umbreon for Mamoswine to break past them more easily. Counterplay against Scizor is essential to keep Mamoswine from being revenge killed by Bullet Punch; the aformentioned Cobalion and Rotom-H serve as solid checks to it. Similarly, entry hazard control from Excadrill and Tentacruel can remove opposing entry hazards that would wear Mamoswine down. Primarina helps overwhelm Celesteela and Slowking for Mamoswine and takes on Keldeo.

Rotom-Heat.overview: Rotom-H's Defog, Nasty Plot, well rounded stats, and unique typing grant it a place in the metagame, either as a defensive Defogger and switch-in to Pokemon like Celesteela and Moltres or a fierce Nasty Plot wallbreaker capable of overwhelming checks like Primarina after some chip damage. It distinguishes itself from Rotom-W by breaking through Grass-types like Amoonguss. Its typing also gives it the resistances to check Pokemon like Celesteela, Moltres, and Mamoswine. However, Rotom-H lacks reliable recovery, meaning it can get overwhelmed when trying to check multiple foes like Moltres + Mamoswine. Pokemon it wants to switch into like Mamoswine and Tangrowth can remove its Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, and most entry hazard setters, including Swampert and Nihilego, can beat it, though Swampert fears Toxic. It has slight four-moveslot syndrome, as it wants Defog, Pain Split for recovery, and Toxic to cripple Pokemon that otherwise wall it like Gastrodon. It's also weak to Azumarill's Aqua Jet and outsped by various threats, such as Keldeo, Nihilego, and Excadrill, the latter of which can ignore Levitate because of Mold Breaker and hinder Rotom-H.
Rotom-Heat.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf + Trick cripples common Rotom-H answers like Chansey and Rhyperior and revenge kills +1 Gyarados. However, Trick sacrifices another valuable moveslot, and using Choice Scarf hampers Rotom-H's longevity by leaving it vulnerable to Stealth Rock. Will-O-Wisp can be used on the pivot set, as it cripples physical attackers like Krookodile, but Toxic is more useful against defensive answers like Swampert and Slowking.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey walls Rotom-H with its enormous special bulk, wears it down with Toxic, and keeps itself healthy with Soft-Boiled, but it has to be wary of Pain Split due to the huge amount of HP Rotom-H receives.

Rock-types: Lycanroc-D and Nihilego outspeed and OHKO Rotom-H. Nihilego is also a reliable switch-in to even +2 Rotom-H, but it is scared of Discharge's paralysis chance. Rhyperior can take +2 Overheat with relative ease and OHKO back with Stone Edge. Nihilego and Rhyperior can also set Stealth Rock in front of Rotom-H.

Ground-types: Swampert, Quagsire, and Gastrodon wall Rotom-H lacking Toxic. Krookodile, Nidoqueen, and Mamoswine block Electric-type moves, including Volt Switch, and hit hard with their coverage moves, but they dislike taking Overheat.

Water-types: Keldeo outspeeds and OHKOes Rotom-H. Primarina and Rotom-W can take unboosted Discharge and OHKO Rotom-H back. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can revenge kill Rotom-H with Aqua Jet. However, none of them except Rotom-W want to risk switching directly into Volt Switch or Discharge, and Rotom-W is 2HKOed by +2 Discharge.

Knock Off: Rotom-H hates Knock Off, as it loses its Heavy-Duty Boots and becomes susceptible to Stealth Rock. Common Pokemon like Krookodile force Rotom-H out because of this, while Pokemon it normally would check like Mamoswine and Tanrgowth can also hinder it.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Overheat and Volt Switch have good synergy, letting Rotom-H hit hard and then pivot. Toxic cripples most defensive answers to Rotom-H, such as Swampert, Hydreigon, and Rhyperior. Defog can be used against Pokemon Rotom-H forces out like Amoonguss, Jirachi, Celesteela, and Moltres. Pain Split serves as Rotom-H's only recovery tool, taking advantage of checks that can consistently recover their HP such as Assault Vest Reuniclus and Chansey. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Rotom-H get onto the field safely and more frequently. Maximum Speed Evs are used to outspeed Nidoking and nail it with a powerful Overheat.

Rotom-H fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate its ability to pivot and form a VoltTurn core with Pokemon like Zarude, remove entry hazards for teammates, and break through walls like Amoonguss. Amoonguss and Zarude make for great partners, destroying Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Gastrodon, Rhyperior, and Excadrill. In return, Rotom-H takes care of Steel- and Flying-types like Celesteela and Moltres. Krookodile is another exceptional teammate, as Rotom-H brings it in safely against foes like Nihilego and Assault Vest Reuniclus. Rotom-H also pressures Celesteela for Krookodile, and together they deal with Aegislash for teammates like Lycanroc-D and Nihilego. Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi cover Rotom-H's weakness to Rock-types like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Rotom-H can remove Steel-types like Celesteela and other checks like Amoonguss and Moltres for them. Wallbreakers that are frail or slow, like Thundurus-T and Primarina, appreciate Rotom-H bringing them in safely against Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Salamence. Tangrowth and Skarmory are secondary Ground-type answers that ease the pressure on Rotom-H to deal with Pokemon that ignore Levitate like Zygarde-10% and Excadrill.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot lets Rotom-H break through traditional checks such as Kommo-o. It also offsets Overheat's Special Attack drop, allowing Rotom-H to still threaten checks like Primarina. At +2, Discharge does big damage to Fire-resistant targets like Rotom-W and Salamence. Discharge's 30% paralysis chance is also great for crippling Nihilego and Salamence. Pain Split grants Rotom-H some longevity, giving it more opportunities to set up with Nasty Plot. Heavy-Duty Boots also gives it more setup opportunities. Maximum HP investment is more valued than Special Attack to take on Moltres and Jirachi better; Rotom-H can still OHKO foes like Celesteela, specially defensive Aegislash, and Assault Vest Tangrowth at +2. However, maximum Special Attack can be run to KO specially defensive Primarina after Stealth Rock and even bulkier foes like Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and Reuniclus.

Nasty Plot Rotom-H shines in bulky offense and offense teams, where its powerful boosted hits remove or weaken walls, paving the way for other teammates to clean. VoltTurn support is appreciated, for this set lacks Volt Switch to keep momentum. Jirachi can provide safe opportunities for Rotom-H to set up against Steel-types like Aegislash and Celesteela. Krookodile makes for a reliable teammate, as it removes Nihilego and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and sets up Stealth Rock to weaken checks, while Rotom-H takes out Celesteela, Amoonguss, and Tapu Bulu. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth switch into Water-types like Rotom-W, Primarina, and Keldeo for Rotom-H, with Amoonguss also acting as a Knock Off absorber. Zarude is a an amazing teammate, destroying Ground-types such as Gastrodon, Excadrill, and Swampert, keeping momentum with U-turn, and revenge killing Pokemon that threaten Rotom-H such as Nihilego and Hydreigon. Rotom-H in return removes Grass- and Steel-types like Tangrowth and Cobalion. Wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D and Diggersby love Rotom-H destroying Pokemon like Skarmory and Amoonguss. They can in return obliterate Chansey.

Rotom-Wash.overview: Rotom-W's typing and Levitate allow it to be an effective pivot that comes in against notable threats such as Mamoswine, Moltres, Pelipper, and Celesteela. Rotom-W can act as an effective entry hazard remover due to its great matchup against common entry hazard setters like Rhyperior and Krookodile. Other utility options like Pain Split and Will-O-Wisp allow it to make progress even when the opponent switches to its checks and counters. Its Choice Scarf set is also notable for addtionally providing solid speed control while still acting as a Ground-type immunity and hazard removal. Sadly, Rotom-W's poor HP stat in conjunction with its reliance on Leftovers and Pain Split for recovery holds back its ability to act as a reliable pivot and exacerbates its vulnerability to poison, burn, and Stealth Rock damage. While Rotom-W does have some useful resistances, it needs to be healthy or used with prediction to pivot against foes that can potentially dent it greatly, such as Ground-types that have a strong secondary STAB move like Nidoking and Diggersby.
Rotom-Wash.comments:
Other Options

Rocky Helmet has the benefit of punishing the likes of Jirachi for spamming U-turn or contact moves, though losing the passive recovery from Leftovers is not ideal. Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature makes Rotom-W a more effective pivot against Keldeo and Mamoswine, but the loss in Speed hampers it against foes like Nidoking and Chandelure. Nasty Plot + Pain Split turns Rotom-W into a wallbreaker, but it still has immense problems with Grass-types. This set also sacrifices Volt Switch in favor of Thunderbolt or Discharge, which makes the matchup against Grass-types even worse. Rindo Berry can be used if the team is too weak to Dragon Dance Gyarados, as it can prevent an OHKO from +2 Adamant Power Whip and provide a safety net against Tapu Bulu if Will-O-Wisp misses.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Rotom-W cannot deal any significant damage to the likes of Tangrowth and Amoonguss aside from burning them. Though Tapu Bulu dislikes Will-O-Wisp, it can still threaten Rotom-W with Horn Leech to restore health. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to disregard status completely. However, all of them lose momentum to Volt Switch as they switch in. Rotom-W also must watch out for Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados and Azelf.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o only dislikes status from Rotom-W and is able to freely set up with Clangorous Soul. Zygarde-10%'s Thousand Arrows ignores Levitate, meaning it heavily punishes teams that solely rely on Rotom-W to deal with Ground-types. Salamence outspeed and nails Rotom-W with a powerful Draco Meteor.

Seismitoad and Gastrodon: Seismitoad and Gastrodon shut down Rotom-W nearly completely if it is not carrying Toxic. Seismitoad can cripple Rotom-W with Toxic and is the only Stealth Rock setter that is immune to both Hydro Pump and Volt Switch, and Gastrodon does not care much about Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch is required so Rotom-W can gain momentum against Grass- and Dragon-types such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o while bringing in teammates like Chandelure and Primarina to threaten them. Hydro Pump destroys common entry hazard setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile. Pain Split is Rotom-W's only recovery move and gives Rotom-W more utility against bulkier teams, though it can be easy to play around. Will-O-Wisp cripples Amoonguss, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Tangrowth. Other status moves can be used over Will-O-Wisp; Toxic limits Seismitoad and Gastrodon's longevity better, whereas Thunder Wave cripples Noivern and Kommo-o. Defog is an alternative option because Rotom-W has several opportunities to remove hazards, such as when facing Celesteela and Jirachi, while having a good matchup against many of the entry hazard setters. Leftovers is Rotom-W's primary way of standing up to repeated U-turn and Stealth Rock damage. Maximum Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed and OHKO Nidoking as well as potentially cripple offensive Kommo-o with Will-O-Wisp.

Rotom-W fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate its ability to check Mamoswine and Moltres. U-turn users such as Zarude and Moltres form VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W that can be difficult to stop, as Rotom-W threatens their checks such as Rotom-H and Rhyperior. Rotom-W appreciates Moltres's ability to pressure Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Wallbreakers such as Buzzwole, Entei, and Nidoking appreciate Rotom-W's Volt Switch allowing them to pressure defensive cores relying on Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth. Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude can help remove Seismitoad and Gastrodon and patch any weaknesses against Zygarde-10%. Zarude also forms a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W and appreciates Rotom-W sponging Krookodile's Knock Off if its item is still required, this being particularly important for Choice Scarf variants.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom is effective at revenge killing targets like Krookodile, Entei, and Lycanroc-D with Hydro Pump. Volt Switch helps Rotom-W offensively threaten foes such as +1 Gyarados, Keldeo, and Starmie. Thunderbolt can be used over Volt Switch to apply more reliable pressure against foes like Mantine and Galarian Moltres, although Volt Switch is more consistent. Defog allows Rotom-W to remove entry hazards before being KOed or as it forces out Pokemon like Mantine and Moltres. Pain Split over Defog gives Rotom-W more longevity. However, finding other options for entry hazard removal can be challenging and create more strain on teambuilding. Trick is vital because it cripples defensive pivots such as Chansey, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth. However, Rotom-W should only use Trick after the additional Speed is no longer necessary, as it will no longer be able to outspeed threats such as Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10%. Choice Scarf allows Rotom-W to revenge kill threats such as Lycanroc-D and Krookodile as well as maintain momentum against other Pokemon that would otherwise outspeed and deal massive damage such as Salamence. The additional speed also helps Rotom-W scout and maintain momentum against unfavorable matchups such as Zarude and Roserade more reliably.

Choice Scarf Rotom-W fits best on offense, balance, and bulky offense teams that appreciate its role compression as a Ground-immune offensive pivot and revenge killer that provides momentum and emergency entry hazard removal. Other pivots such as Mienshao form a potent VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as they overwhelm each other's checks; Mienshao deals with Chansey and Zarude, while Rotom-W deals with Moltres and Nihilego. Entry hazard setters such as Jirachi, Nihilego, and Krookodile wear down targets for Rotom-W. The former is able to form a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, while the latter two can cripple Pokemon such as Aegislash and Salamence with Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Entei, Nidoking, and Mamoswine are fantastic partner that break through Pokemon Rotom-W grants them safe entry on, such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Galarian Slowbro. Hatterene deals with Pokemon that would otherwise take advantage of Rotom-W like Seismitoad and Kommo-o. Hatterene's Magic Bounce also assists Rotom-W in its role as entry hazard control and makes Rotom-W more comfortable with running Pain Split. Rotom-W's role compression means it can struggle against Entei and Jirachi in the long-term, so teammates such as RestTalk Primarina, Aegislash, and Moltres help relieve pressure.

Azelf.overview: Azelf is a versatile Pokemon that can take advantage of its incredibly high Speed tier and wide movepool to provide a powerful offensive presence and fast support. Nasty Plot and a variety of coverage moves such as Fire Blast, Energy Ball, and Dazzling Gleam allow Azelf to hit nearly the entire tier for super effective damage, OHKOing most of it at +2. Access to Knock Off and U-turn also makes it a great offensive pivot that can threaten tier staples like Aegislash and Tangrowth. Despite Azelf's elite Speed, common Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude easily revenge kill it. Azelf does not have much bulk and lacks recovery, leaving it worn down quickly and making it difficult to set up with Nasty Plot. It also needs pivot support to get in safely, as it typically cannot directly switch into any attack. Azelf struggles to fit all the moves it needs on its Nasty Plot set, as without Energy Ball Azelf struggles to break Slowking and Swampert, whereas without Dazzling Gleam it is completely walled by Hydreigon and Mandibuzz. Thundurus-T gives Azelf large competition as a special wallbreaker and pivot, having more power, a better typing, and no 4MSS. However, Azelf's high Speed allows it to better threaten Pokemon like Keldeo and Nihilego.
Azelf.comments:
Other Options

Azelf can be used as a suicide lead due to its great Speed tier and access to Stealth Rock and Taunt. While this allows Azelf to always get Stealth Rock up with a Focus Sash, Pokemon like Excadrill and Krookodile, which possess better defensive utility and Rapid Spin or a stronger Knock Off respectively, can typically do this job better. Azelf can also be a Choice Band user with its great Speed tier and wide physical movepool, boasting options like Knock Off, U-turn, Zen Headbutt, Ice Punch, Explosion, and Trick. However, it is usually unable to OHKO its foes and outclassed by Pokemon like Azumarill, which provides priority and is much stronger. Azelf can run a Choice Scarf to be the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the tier, taking Choice Scarf users like Mienshao by surprise and hindering switch-ins like Hatterene with Trick.

Checks and Counters

Choice Scarf Users: Common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, Zarude, Jirachi, and Mienshao outspeed and threaten Azelf with super effective STAB or coverage moves.

Priority Attackers: Azelf does not have great defenses and will be 2HKOed by most priority attacks, including Accelerock from Lycanroc-D and Aqua Jet from Azumarill. Additionally, more powerful priority attacks like a boosted Quick Attack from Diggersby will KO Azelf after minimal chip damage.

Dark-types: Galarian Moltres and Mandibuzz can OHKO Azelf, and Azelf cannot do much back it unless it is running Dazzling Gleam. Umbreon walls Azelf almost completely without Dazzling Gleam. Choice Scarf Hydreigon can easily revenge kill Azelf, though other sets must watch out for Dazzling Gleam.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
After a Nasty Plot, very few Pokemon other than Chansey and Umbreon can withstand a hit from Azelf. Psyshock is the preferred STAB option to OHKO Nihilego and Tentacruel without a boost, and it also hits Chansey considerably harder than Psychic. Fire Blast OHKOes defensive Celesteela and Assault Vest Tangrowth at +2. It also covers many key threats such as Jirachi, Skarmory, and Excadrill. The last move is dependent on Azelf's team; Energy Ball is able to nail Slowking, Swampert, Azumarill, and Rhyperior for super effective damage. Meanwhile, Dazzling Gleam is an option to OHKO Hydreigon, 2HKO Salamence, and hit Galarian Moltres and Mandibuzz super effectively while also maintaining coverage for Krookodile. It also prevents Umbreon from completely walling Azelf. Since Azelf will typically be hitting its foes for super effective damage, Expert Belt is enough to OHKO nearly everything. Life Orb can be used to increase Azelf's damage output more consistently on targets that it cannot hit super effectively, like Hatterene and Moltres, but the chip damage adds up quickly and leaves Azelf more vulnerable to revenge killers with priority like Lycanroc-D.

Nasty Plot Azelf is best used on hyper offense builds that can offer it support, although it can also fit on certain balance teams as a late-game wincon. An entry hazard setter like Nihilego, Excadrill, or Krookodile helps weaken foes like Chansey and Primarina into KO range of +2 Azelf. Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to boost Azelf's ability to clean through teams, as Sticky Web invalidates common Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude as revenge killers. It also ensures Azelf does not lose any Speed ties with Zygarde-10%. A pivot like Zarude can get Azelf in safely against Pokemon like Amoonguss. A wallbreaker like Azumarill or Mamoswine can help punch holes in the enemy team, significantly weakening them for Azelf to sweep later. Other sweepers like Gyarados and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can be used on hyper offense teams to cover a wider range of threats, including Swampert, Slowking, and Galarian Moltres, which Azelf cannot easily beat.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
U-turn lets Azelf to pivot away from switch-ins and escape counters like Umbreon and Galarian Moltres. Knock Off offers important utility to cripple defensive switch-ins like Chansey, Mandibuzz, and Hatterene. Psychic is the preferred STAB option for its greater power, threatening Thundurus-T more while OHKOing Conkeldurr and Life Orb Mienshao. Psyshock is an option over Psychic to guarantee the OHKO on Nihilego and deal additional damage to specially defensive foes like Chansey and Primarina. Flamethrower allows Azelf to threaten Jirachi, Excadrill, and Aegislash. Energy Ball is an option over U-turn on Expert Belt sets to offer greater coverage and threaten Swampert and Azumarill. While Timid is the preferred nature, a Naive nature can be used to deal more chip damage with U-turn and Knock Off at the expense of some survivability.

Offensive pivot Azelf best fits on balance and offense teams that appreciate a fast pivot and revenge killer. Strong wallbreakers like Azumarill and Mamoswine appreciate Azelf's pivoting and deal with Umbreon. An entry hazard setter like Excadrill, Skarmory, or Roserade syncs well with the switches that Azelf's momentum forces, providing additional damage for it and its teammates to break through defensive cores like Tangrowth + Chansey. Offensive pivots like Zarude and Thundurus-T form a strong pivoting cores with Azelf. Zarude can bring Azelf in on Amoonguss and Tangrowth, while it can bring Zarude in on foes like Swampert and Krookodile. Thundurus-T can threaten Primarina and Mandibuzz for Azelf, while Azelf can wear down threats like Aegislash for Thundurus-T. Strong Fighting-types like Mienshao and Conkeldurr can remove Dark-types like Umbreon and Zarude. Primarina is a great partner for Azelf, as it threatens Pokemon like Krookodile and Galarian Moltres. In return, Azelf helps remove their common Grass-type checks like Amoonguss and Tangrowth after they are sufficiently chipped. Many Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude can outspeed and threaten Azelf, so a defensive teammate like Amoonguss or Tangrowth can be used to take hits from these foes.

Excadrill.overview: Excadrill has insanely valuable role compression as an Electric-immune entry hazard setter and remover. It has the typing to check many threatening foes like Nihilego, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro. Mold Breaker allows Excadrill to bypass abilities like Levitate from Rotom-W and Magic Bounce from Hatterene to KO them or set Stealth Rock. Excadrill can also be a potent late-game cleaner with a Swords Dance + Rapid Spin set, boosting up to break through walls like Chansey and Amoonguss and clean through weakened teams. Excadrill can also utilize a suicide lead set on hyper offense teams to pave the way for dangerous sweepers like Celesteela and Thundurus-T. However, Excadrill is extremely vulnerable to the tier's Water-, Grass-, and Fighting-type Pokemon like Keldeo, Zarude, and Conkeldurr, all of which can easily take advantage of it due to their higher Speed or access to priority. Excadrill struggles to bypass common threats like Skarmory, Hippowdon, Moltres, and Celesteela. Skarmory and Hippowdon are especially troublesome, as Excadrill struggles to keep entry hazards removed against the most prevalent setters in the tier. Furthermore, Excadrill's defensive stats are lackluster without investment, which hinders its role as a Steel-type when checking threats like Hatterene and Hydreigon.
Excadrill.comments:
Other Options

On Hippowdon teams, Excadrill can use Sand Rush over Mold Breaker to be the fastest threat in the tier, though sand isn't a prominent archetype in UU and Excadrill fails to beat Celesteela and Skarmory anyway. Choice Scarf allows Excadrill to revenge kill threats like Azelf and be the fastest entry hazard remover in the tier, but it is typically undesirable to be locked into any of its moves. Sand Force alongside Choice Band on Sand teams turns Excadrill into a very dangerous wallbreaker, but like Choice Scarf this set struggles because Excadrill hates being locked into any of its moves.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres resist Excadrill's STAB combination, with the former two also being immune to Toxic. However, Moltres dislikes getting hit with Rock Tomb from suicide lead variants. Thundurus-T outspeeds Excadrill and nails it with Focus Blast. Salamence can switch into Excadrill and lower its Attack with Intimidate.

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Swampert and Slowking can take a hit from Excadrill and retaliate with a super effective attack. Gyarados can use variants without Toxic as setup fodder. Azumarill and Keldeo can revenge kill Excadrill easily.

Grass-types: Tangrowth's massive physical bulk allows it to wall most Excadrill variants, though it has to be careful when taking on Swords Dance sets, as they can break through it with an Iron Head flinch, and Tangrowth needs chip damage to KO Excadrill back. Zarude's natural bulk lets it pivot into Excadrill; it does not fear Toxic because of Jungle Healing and forces it out due to its higher Speed. Dhelmise can block Rapid Spin attempts from Excadrill and threaten it back.

Fighting-types: Cobalion and Keldeo outspeed and force out Excadrill. Conkeldurr has enough physical bulk to take an Earthquake and recover its health with Drain Punch or OHKO Excadrill with Mach Punch if at full health.

Faster Threats: Faster threats like Krookodile, Zygarde-10%, Hydreigon, and Lycanroc-D all outspeed and threaten Excadrill. However, none of these Pokemon want to switch into it, barring Krookodile, which can in a pinch.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Earthquake and Iron Head provide fantastic coverage for Excadrill, slamming common threats like Jirachi, Nihilego, and Mamoswine. Rapid Spin lets Excadrill clear entry hazards thanks to matching up well against other entry hazard setters like Nihilego and Chansey. Stealth Rock can be run for more role compression thanks to Excadrill pressuring entry hazard control like Rotom-W and Hatterene. Additionally, Excadrill can set up Stealth Rock against threats like Jirachi and Nihilego because of its typing. Toxic is an alternative option to cripple defensive checks like Tangrowth, Slowking, and Moltres, though finding another Pokemon to run Stealth Rock can strain teambuilding. Additionally, Toxic is useless against other Excadrill answers like Skarmory and Amoonguss. Mold Breaker bypasses Levitate from Rotom-W, Rotom-H, and Hydreigon, allowing Excadrill to severely damage them with Earthquake while also allowing Excadrill to circumvent Hatterene's Magic Bounce. Maximum Attack investment lets Excadrill threaten Amoonguss and Primarina as much as possible, though maximum investment in Special Defense in an option to better check threats like Hatterene, Rotom-W, and Galarian Slowbro via directly switching in.

Excadrill both removing and setting entry hazards gives it a place on many bulky offense and balance teams. Thundurus-T is a great partner that can remove Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres that hinder Excadrill. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into Water- and Grass-types like Azumarill and Zarude for Excadrill. They also scare out Hippowdon. Fighting-type checks like Salamence and Slowking provide great support against threats like Cobalion and Conkeldurr, with Salamence also beating Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth as well as helping Excadrill keep entry hazards off the field thanks to it beating entry hazard setters it struggles with like Skarmory and Swampert. Salamence also beats bulky variants of Swords Dance Scizor. Other entry hazard setters like Nihilego and Cobalion can cover setting Stealth Rock for Excadrill, freeing up a moveslot to run Toxic. They also appreciate Excadrill threatening Aegislash for them. Fast offensive threats like Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and Salazzle appreciate Excadrill's support and can deal with faster threats like Thundurus-T and Hydreigon. The latter two also check Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Skarmory.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance boosts Excadrill's Attack to sky-high levels, letting it overwhelm the sturdiest of physical walls like Tangrowth and Amoonguss with its STAB moves if Stealth Rock is up. In conjunction with Mold Breaker, it can break through Quagsire's Unaware. Rapid Spin lets Excadrill compress entry hazard removal alongside boosting its Speed, making it a dangerous late-game threat, as faster threats like Zygarde-10% can no longer revenge kill it. Rock Slide is an option to slam Moltres, which otherwise counters this set, and hit Thundurus-T and Celesteela, but it only should be used if the team can fit entry hazard removal elsewhere. Leftovers makes Excadrill harder to wear down, further facilitating its sweeping attempts.

Excadrill best fits on offensive teams that give it ample opportunities to wallbreak. Pivot support from Zarude, Thundurus-T, and Slowking can bring Excadrill in safely to set up against their checks like Togekiss, Chansey, and Aegislash. Notably, Slowking is a slow pivot, providing Excadrill with a free switch with Teleport. Slowking and Thundurus-T are also great at taking advantage of Celesteela and Skarmory, both of which wall Excadrill. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can provide a key defensive backbone for Excadrill, taking on threats like Conkeldurr, Hippowdon, and Azumarill. Entry hazard support from Nihilego and Swampert is key in helping Excadrill break through physical walls like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Early-game wallbreakers like Hydreigon and Conkeldurr can weaken walls like Celesteela and Moltres for it to cleanly sweep late-game. Other Steel-types like Celesteela and Jirachi can make up for Excadrill's frailty by checking threats it normally would like Aegislash and Hatterene.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
Excadrill is a great suicide lead for hyper offense teams thanks to Mold Breaker, allowing it to set up Stealth Rock against Hatterene and pressure Rotom-W with Earthquake. Rapid Spin supports its team against opposing Stealth Rock setters like Nihilego and Swampert. Excadrill also keeps Sticky Web off the field thanks to its amazing matchup against Ribombee, which normally hinders many hyper offense teams. Rock Tomb heavily damages Thundurus-T and Moltres and slows down faster threats like Zarude for its teammates to set up on. Alternatively, Steel Beam allows Excadrill to retain momentum after setting up Stealth Rock, preventing Defoggers like Mandibuzz from removing Stealth Rock. A Focus Sash guarantees Excadrill can survive a hit and get up Stealth Rock before fainting.

This Excadrill set fits best on hyper offense teams, allowing teammates to come in and sweep after setting up Stealth Rock. Deadly setup sweepers like Thundurus-T, Gyarados, and Celesteela all appreciate entry hazard support wearing down checks like Chansey, Skarmory, and Nihilego. Thundurus-T takes advantage of the Flying-types Excadrill lets in like Skarmory and Celesteela, while the latter two also appreciate Excadrill removing opposing Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin, preventing chip damage so they can sweep more easily. Rapid Spin support also allows Gyarados to run items like Mystic Water instead of Heavy-Duty Boots. Spikes leads like Scolipede can form an entry hazard stacking core with Excadrill.

Conkeldurr.overview: Guts Conkeldurr is one of UU's most devastating wallbreakers. Once burned by Flame Orb, it can evade status from defensive staples like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Knock Off and Facade offer virtually perfect coverage alongside its powerful Drain Punch or Close Combat, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores like Chansey and Quagsire. STAB Mach Punch is also a great tool, functioning as a strong priority attack that can threaten faster Pokemon like Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Hydreigon. Conkeldurr is a bit weighed down by its proneness to being worn down from Flame Orb, however. This is made a larger problem by its poor Speed, which allows the tier's many faster threats like Keldeo and Salamence to overwhelm it, as well as its iffy defensive typing, which doesn't give it many notable resistances and leaves it open to Pokemon like Moltres, Togekiss, Primarina, and Salamence. Moreover, sand chip from Hippowdon wears down Conkeldurr. Conkeldurr also faces competition from Fighting-types like Keldeo, who offers comparable power in addition to greater Speed and an additional Water-typing.
Conkeldurr.comments:
Other Options

A Bulk Up set with investment in Special Defense can function as a solid bulky sweeper that can absorb status. Conkeldurr could hold Assault Vest to more easily switch into Scald from Pokemon like Raikou and Quagsire while also checking special attackers such as Nihilego. However, this often prevents it from being able to maximize its offensive potential, and it is still quite prone to being worn down.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Defensive Salamence is a particularly good check to Conkeldurr because of its ability to always take a hit from full HP thanks to Intimidate, allowing it to switch into Conkeldurr and threaten it with Dual Wingbeat. Skarmory's massive physical bulk lets it switch into a weaker attack from Conkeldurr and nail it with Brave Bird. Togekiss and Crobat can also be a solid checks, 4x resisting Conkeldurr's STAB moves and revenge killing it. Moltres resists Mach Punch and can power through Conkeldurr with Hurricane.

Psychic-types: Slowking and Galarian Slowbro can take Knock Off from full HP while severely damaging Conkeldurr with STAB Psychic-type attacks. Necrozma and Azelf outspeed and pressure Conkeldurr with their powerful attacks.

Fairy-types: Although it takes hefty damage from Facade, bulky Primarina can restore its health as it dents Conkeldurr with Draining Kiss, while its Choice Specs sets can outrun and OHKO it outright. Azumarill outspeeds Conkeldurr, resists Mach Punch, and can KO it with Play Rough. Hatterene can trade with Conkeldurr and restore health with Draining Kiss.

Faster Pokemon: Conkeldurr's low Speed and Flame Orb use leave it quite vulnerable to being overwhelmed by faster Pokemon like Tapu Bulu, Nidoking, and Thundurus-T.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Drain Punch can be used as Conkeldurr's primary STAB move, giving it more longevity and a safe attacking option. However, Close Combat is also an option for its massive damage output, crushing defensive staples like Celesteela and Skarmory. Facade heavily damages various Pokemon that resist its STAB attacks, including Nidoqueen, Amoonguss, and Primarina. Knock Off nails foes such as Galarian Slowbro, Chandelure, and Slowking. It also removes items from switch-ins like Salamence, Togekiss, and Moltres, crippling them heavily. Mach Punch is a strong priority move that can pressure faster foes like Hydreigon, Excadrill, and Zarude while picking off weakened threats in general. An Adamant nature is preferred in order to maximize Conkeldurr's wallbreaking potential.

Conkeldurr generally fits well on more offensively oriented builds. Some balance teams appreciate the offensive pressure it offers, too. Due to Conkeldurr's tendency to wearing itself down, it appreciates Grassy Terrain support from Tapu Bulu for passive recovery. Tapu Bulu also checks faster threats to Conkeldurr like Primarina and Azumarill. Conkeldurr struggles to break through physical walls like Tangrowth and Hippowdon in the short term, so teammates who can threaten these like Moltres and Zarude are appreciated. Entry hazard setters like Nihilego and Swampert can wear down checks like Skarmory with Stealth Rock for Conkeldurr to muscle through easier. Nihilego can also check many revenge killers to Conkeldurr like Togekiss, Salamence, and Crobat. Slow pivots like Chansey, Slowking, and Mandibuzz can help bring Conkeldurr into play against threats like Excadrill, Zarude, and Lycanroc-D. Slowking can also provide Future Sight support to further amplify Conkeldurr's wallbreaking power. Late-game cleaners like Thundurus-T and Scizor are able to clean up after Conkeldurr softens up the opposing team. In return, it can pressure Flying-types like Togekiss and Salamence. Faster teammates like Choice Scarf Hydreigon can revenge kill threats to Conkeldurr like Azelf and Salamence.

Seismitoad.overview: Seismitoad separates itself from other Ground-type Stealth Rock setters thanks to its additional Water typing and access to Water Absorb, which allows it to easily pivot into Pokemon such as Rotom-H, Rotom-W, and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro. These qualities also let Seismitoad threaten other entry hazard setters such as Krookodile, Rhyperior, and Jirachi. Seismitoad has a positive matchup against some of the entry hazard removers of the tier such as the aforementioned Rotom formes and Tentacruel. Seismitoad is a valuable asset on rain teams as a Stealth Rock setter and wallbreaker that does well against offensive threats such as Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D due to its defensive typing. However, Seismitoad's lack of reliable recovery outside of Leftovers makes it vulnerable to status effects and Knock Off. Seismitoad's crippling weakness to Grass-types gives Pokemon like Amoonguss and Zarude free entry and bad matchups against threats that carry Grass-type coverage moves such as Nihilego and Gyarados. Seismitoad also faces competition from Gastrodon, as it has access to Recover, though Seismitoad has important access to Stealth Rock and is less passive. Defensive Seismitoad also has to compete with other Stealth Rock setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile, which offer greater offensive presence.
Seismitoad.comments:
Other Options

A physical Seismitoad can open the door for teammates like Kingdra by blowing through Chansey, Salamence, and Gastrodon with Earthquake, Ice Punch, and Power Whip, respectively, though this gives Seismitoad a worse matchup against Buzzwole. Seismitoad can run more offensive EV spreads on its traditional Stealth Rock set with good coverage options such as Sludge Wave. However, this considerably cuts into Seismitoad's bulk, which is often less than ideal.

Checks and Counters

Grass-type Pokemon and Coverage Moves: Seismitoad's defensive set often invites in Pokemon like Tangrowth and Amoonguss, which are more difficult to outlast due to Regenerator. Zarude has Jungle Healing to remove status, and the Choice Scarf variant outspeeds Modest Seismitoad in rain. This weakness to Grass also means that Pokemon such as Gyarados and Nihilego can threaten Seismitoad with coverage moves like Power Whip and Grass Knot, respectively.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Pokemon like Nidoking, Mienshao, and Crawdaunt greatly hinder Seismitoad's ability to act as a pivot because of their powerful secondary STAB attacks, taking advantage of its passivity and lack of recovery. However, they do not appreciate switching into Seismitoad due to its STAB moves or fear of status.

Setup Sweepers: Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres and Kommo-o can force Seismitoad out or use it as setup fodder due to its relative passivity. However, they have to be weary of Toxic putting them on a timer or Scald crippling their offensive prowess.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Seismitoad can use Stealth Rock after pivoting into Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D and Celesteela. Seismitoad walls Defog Rotom-W and Rotom-H lacking status moves, so it is able to consistently keep Stealth Rock in front of teams relying on them for entry hazard removal. Scald gives Seismitoad a chance to burn switch-ins such as Kommo-o and Tapu Bulu. It also provides long-term chip damage on Amoonguss so it does not get the most out of Regenerator. Earthquake gives Seismitoad a better matchup against Calm Mind users like Keldeo and Galarian Slowbro at the cost of reducing Scald's damage output. Earth Power is usable to hit targets like Kommo-o harder but is generally not worth it, as Seismitoad now becomes setup fodder for the aforementioned Keldeo and Galarian Slowbro, and Earth Power fails to OHKO Nihilego. Toxic makes Seismitoad less passive against the likes of Tangrowth and Gastrodon switching in. It also helps Seismitoad outlast other Defoggers such as Salamence and Rotom-W. Knock Off is another option for crippling other switch-ins such as Amoonguss and Chansey, but it makes Seismitoad more passive against other Water-types such as Primarina and Gastrodon. 64 Speed EVs enable Seismitoad to outspeed Adamant Azumarill.

Seismitoad fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its defensive qualities and Stealth Rock support. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth are recommended because Seismitoad struggles to check Primarina, Keldeo, and Azumarill by itself, and they act as good Knock Off sponges for Seismitoad to maintain Leftovers. Wallbreakers that blow through Grass-types such as Salamence and Nasty Plot Rotom-H are appreciated. Defoggers such as Moltres and the aforementioned Salamence help keep entry hazards off the field to help maintain Seismitoad's longevity. Sylveon is also a good support teammate to keep Seismitoad healthy with Wish and Heal Bell while also checking Dragon-types like Kommo-o and Salamence that would otherwise give Seismitoad a more difficult time. The pair also provide a solid backbone against Keldeo. Togekiss can similarly play the role of a cleric and assist in pressuring Grass-types like Zarude and Tapu Bulu. In exchange, Seismitoad helps in wearing down Rotom-W, Rhyperior, and non-Grass Knot Nihilego.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Seismitoad has to be more cautious about finding opportunities to set up Stealth Rock, as it is no longer immune to Rotom-W's Hydro Pump, but it does help Seismitoad chip some other answers to rain teams like Amoonguss and Gastrodon. Under rain, Weather Ball comfortably OHKOes many neutral targets such as Conkeldurr and Thundurus-T and 2HKOes targets that resist it such as defensive Salamence after some chip damage. Hydro Pump is an alternative option to deal more damage against specially defensive Pokemon like Sylveon and Celesteela, but its accuracy makes it more unreliable overall. Earth Power 2HKOes threats such as Amoonguss and Gastrodon after some chip damage. Sludge Wave destroys Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude while also finishing off a weakened Salamence or Noivern. Power Whip is usable over Stealth Rock to muscle through other Water-types like Rotom-W and Primarina more easily. A Modest nature maximizes Seismitoad's damage output. Timid can be used to outspeed Choice Scarf Zarude, though the drop in power is less than ideal.

This Seismitoad set fits only on rain teams, and its teammates should be able to help break through Pokemon it cannot such as Milotic and Chansey. Pelipper is the best partner to set Drizzle for Seismitoad and can bring it in safely with U-turn against foes like Thundurus-T. Other Swift Swim users like Kingdra can help Seismitoad overwhelm walls such as Amoonguss and Celesteela. Crawdaunt is an excellent partner that lures in and destroys bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth with a Swords Dance-boosted Knock Off, and it has priority in Aqua Jet to hit faster foes. Thundurus-T provides a good backup check to a weakened Raikou that also rips through Celesteela while potentially breaking through Chansey with a Nasty Plot-boosted Focus Blast. Offensive Salamence can pressure the Grass-types of the tier, namely Amoonguss and Choice Scarf Zarude.

Scolipede.overview: Scolipede is a niche late-game cleaner thanks to its ability to boost both its Attack and Speed with Swords Dance and Speed Boost in one turn, giving it a good matchup against both offensive and defensive teams. Its decent STAB combination alongside Earthquake pressures a majority of the tier. Scolipede's typing also provides it with opportunities to set up against foes such as Tangrowth and prevents it from being crippled by Toxic. Unfortunately, Scolipede is very frail, which means it can struggle to set up a Swords Dance safely without being severely worn down. This can severely hinder its ability to clean late-game, especially when it continues to wear itself down from Life Orb recoil. The UU tier also has an abundance of priority users like Lycanroc-D, Azumarill, and Zygarde-10% that can easily pick off Scolipede. Albeit having a respectable Attack stat, Scolipede struggles to break through physically defensive walls such as Celesteela, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz even after a Swords Dance boost. Scolipede also has a crippling weakness to Stealth Rock, which limits how often it can switch in to find opportunities to set up and sweep. All of these factors cause Scolipede to face severe competition from other late-game sweepers like Nihilego and Gyarados.
Scolipede.comments:
Other Options

Rock Slide is an option to help break through Rotom-H, Moltres, and Salamence more easily; however, Poison Jab hits these targets hard enough and Earthquake is generally preferred for its ability to pressure Jirachi while still maintaining coverage for other Fire-types like Chandelure. Protect is an option over Earthquake to guarantee a Speed boost, but losing a coverage option greatly hinders its ability to break through a good amount of the tier.

Checks and Counters

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Mandibuzz can stomach a boosted hit from Scolipede and OHKO it in return. Swampert walls Scolipede after a Swords Dance boost and can easily beat it one-on-one. Celesteela and Skarmory indefinitely wall Scolipede, so unless they are removed, it will have a very hard time making any progress.

Priority: Lycanroc-D threatens to OHKO Scolipede with Accelerock, while other common priority users like Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Zygarde-10% can also pick off Scolipede if brought into range.

Stealth Rock: Stealth Rock hinders the number of times Scolipede can set up a Swords Dance and will bring it into range of priority users like Azumarill and Mamoswine.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Megahorn is a powerful STAB move that is necessary for Scolipede to muscle past foes like Amoonguss and Krookodile. Poison Jab provides Scolipede with strong neutral coverage to break through Pokemon like Salamence, Rotom-H, and Moltres. It also helps Scolipede beat Fairy-types like Primarina and Azumarill. Earthquake gives Scolipede super effective coverage to break through Pokemon like Excadrill, Tentacruel, and Aegislash. Aqua Tail can be considered to help break through foes like Rhyperior and Rotom-H better; however, it will have a harder time with foes like Tentacruel and Aegislash. Heavy-Duty Boots are an option over Life Orb to offset its weakness to Stealth Rock; however, you miss out on OHKOing Amoonguss after Stealth Rock with a Swords Dance-boosted Megahorn. Amoonguss could then retaliate with a powerful Foul Play as a result. A Jolly nature allows Scolipede to outspeed threats like Keldeo before a Speed Boost, as well as Choice Scarf users like Zarude after a Speed boost.

Scolipede should primarily be used on offense teams that can support it well enough to clean late-game. Entry hazards are key to bring foes like defensive Swampert and Rhyperior into range of a boosted attack, so entry hazard setters like Nihilego, Roserade, and Krookodile are appreciated. Krookodile can also help Scolipede set up a Swords Dance more easily thanks to Intimidate and help blanket check Lycanroc-D if holding a Chople Berry. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Excadrill, Rotom-W, and Salamence can help alleviate Scolipede's weakness to Stealth Rock. Rotom-W can also bring Scolipede in against Grass-types like Tangrowth to set up, while Salamence does a phenomenal job of wearing down Rhyperior into range of a Swords Dance-boosted Earthquake. Wallbreakers like Azumarill and Aegislash can help break through defensive foes like Mandibuzz and Celesteela for Scolipede to sweep more easily. Indeedee-F can provide Psychic Terrain support to prevent Scolipede from being revenge killed by common priority users such as Lycanroc-D and Azumarill. It can also provide Healing Wish support to give Scolipede another opportunity to sweep. Magneton can trap and remove Celesteela and Skarmory for Scolipede, allowing it to sweep more easily.

Krookodile.overview: Krookodile's high Attack, respectable Speed, and amazing offensive typing make it one of the best offensive checks to Pokemon like Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro. Few Pokemon resist the combination of Earthquake and Knock Off, which dents even neutral targets such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Amoonguss. Intimidate lets Krookodile switch into resisted and neutral hits such as Lycanroc-D's Stone Edge without getting too worn down. It also helps prevent late-game sweeps from Pokemon like Salamence. Moves like Stealth Rock and Taunt let Krookodile compress utility roles, and its ability to run a plethora of items, like Life Orb, Leftovers, Choice Scarf, Choice Band, and resist berries, makes for a key factor in its unpredictability and versatility. It's one of the best Choice Scarf users in UU, capable of revenge killing threats like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D. With Choice Band, it can remove common answers to it like Amoonguss more easily. However, Krookodile is threatened by physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10% even after Intimidate, and its special bulk leaves it vulnerable to special attackers like Nidoking and Aegislash. Weaknesses to common types like Grass, Water, and Fighting hinder its defensive utility and leave it helpless against common Pokemon like Tangrowth, Azumarill, and Conkeldurr. Coverage from Electric-types like Thundurus-T's Focus Blast prevents Krookodile from checking them despite its Electric immunity. Excadrill gives Krookodile immense competition as a utility Ground-type on teams, sporting a better defensive typing, having access to Rapid Spin, and being able to hit hard without investment in Attack. However, Krookodile's access to Knock Off, Intimidate, and a greater speed tier letting it threaten Moltres and opposing Excadrill gives it a niche on certain teams.
Krookodile.comments:
Other Options

Rindo Berry is an option to survive +1 Nihilego's Grass Knot and OHKO back with Earthquake. Meanwhile, Passho Berry gives Krookodile a chance to eliminate threats like Crawdaunt and Rotom-W. Life Orb lets Krookodile pressure Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Rotom-W more easily. Smack Down is an option on the Stealth Rock set to ground Skarmory and prevent it from taking advantage of Krookodile. Krookodile can opt for a more offensive Choice Scarf set with Moxie, letting it accumulate Attack boosts as it KOes enemies. However, the utility that Intimidate offers is more worth it to weaken Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, and Krookodile can't break past Grass-types and Buzzwole without enough boosts. Choice Band Assurance can nail Pokemon like Amoonguss as they switch in, but it requires specific conditions and good prediction

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tangrowth check Krookodile very well and are only bothered by Knock Off. Both cause big damage with Giga Drain and incapacitate a team member with Spore or Sleep Powder. However, Amoonguss has to wary of Choice Band Earthquake, as it is 2HKOed after Stealth Rock damage. Zarude and Tapu Bulu can also switch into Krookodile's STAB moves and can recover with Jungle Healing or Horn Leech.

Water-types: Rotom-W and Gyarados are immune to Ground and can take advantage of Krookodile being Choice-locked into Earthquake. The former can remove Stealth Rock with Defog, while the latter can get a free turn of setup. Krookodile also can't take any Water-type hits from Azumarill, Primarina, and Keldeo, but they don't like to switch in directly into its moves. Swampert and Slowking can take hits from Krookodile and threaten it back, though the latter doesn't like a Choice Band-boosted Knock Off.

Fighting-types: Mienshao, Keldeo, Cobalion, and Conkeldurr also threaten Krookodile greatly. The former three outspeed non-Choice Scarf sets, with Choice Scarf Mienshao outspeeding even those. Meanwhile, Conkeldurr has the bulk to take an Earthquake and recover its health with Drain Punch or just pick off Krookodile with Mach Punch. However, Mienshao and Cobalion should scout for Chople Berry and Choice Scarf sets.

Strong Wallbreakers: Despite its ability and good defensive typing, Krookodile has subpar bulk and lacks reliable recovery, meaning it gets worn down quite quickly switching into Pokemon such as Excadrill and Zygarde-10%. Pokemon like Aegislash and Nidoking hurt it very badly with even resisted special STAB moves due to its bad special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Krookodile's role compression and item versatility let it perform on both hyper offense teams and on more defensive ones, like balance and bulky offense. With Life Orb, this set fits on hyper offense teams as a great lead. If running Leftovers or a Berry, this set fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate Krookodile's utility and resistances. Knock Off is useful for checks like Amoonguss, Swampert, and Celesteela, crippling them for Krookodile's teammates. High Horsepower should be used in place of Earthquake if Tapu Bulu is on Krookodile's team, as Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake. Stealth Rock wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Tangrowth for teammates like Aegislash and Choice Specs Primarina. Toxic allows Krookodile to cripple checks such as Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu. Taunt prevents Stealth Rock and Defog from Pokemon like Excadrill, Swampert, Rotom-W, and Moltres. Leftovers offsets entry hazard damage and gives Krookodile longevity to keep threats like Nihilego, Excadrill, and Aegislash in check more easily. Chople Berry lets Krookodile take Lycanroc-D's Close Combat and KO back with Earthquake. It also helps Krookodile take Thundurus-T's Focus Blast to then weaken or KO it. Maximum investement in HP lets Krookodile better check Excadrill and Aegislash.

Setup sweepers such as Thundurus-T and Salamence work well with Krookodile, as it can set Stealth Rock up and weaken their checks such as Diancie and Primarina. Special attackers like Azelf and Nihilego appreciate Krookodile denting and crippling their checks in Chansey and Celesteela with Knock Off, paving their way to sweep. In return, they compensate for Krookodile's lower Speed tier and remove Pokemon like Conkeldurr, Zarude, and Tapu Bulu. Amoonguss can check Pokemonn like Primarina, Mienshao, and Zarude for Krookodile, and together they can keep Lycanroc-D in check. Salamence forms a double Intimidate core with Krookodile, weakening Pokemon like Zarude and stopping setup sweepers like Gyarados from getting out of control. Krookodile is vulnerable against Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Togekiss so partners like Aegislash, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel are valuable. Tapu Bulu threatens Azumarill and Primarina for Krookodile. It can also provide Grassy Terrain to give Krookodile more recovery.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Knock Off pressures walls that rely on their items, like Mandibuzz, Celesteela, and Chansey, and discourages Pokemon like Rotom-H and Salamence from switching in. Stone Edge threatens Pokemon immune to Ground like Gyarados, Moltres, and Rotom-H. Close Combat lets Krookodile hit targets such as Zarude, Hydreigon, Chansey, and opposing Krookodile harder. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but since others like Amoonguss and Zarude are immune or resilient to it, it's quite matchup reliant. Darkest Lariat is useful to hit Pokemon like Rotom-W harder after they've had their items removed. Stealth Rock can be used to take advantage of Krookodile's ability to force switches against Pokemon such as Azelf and Nihilego, but it should only be used when the role compression is necessary, and it requires very good prediction. Choice Scarf turns Krookodile into a solid revenge killer, outspeeding key Pokemon and sweepers such as Lycanroc-D, Azelf, and +1 Gyarados.

This set fits well on offense, bulky offense, and balance teams that need a fast revenge killer. These kinds of teams appreciate Krookodile's defensive utility in its two immunities and Intimidate. Even though Intimidate allows Krookodile to take on physical attacks a bit better, it shouldn't be relied on, so teammates like Aegislash and Tangrowth help it against wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D. Assault Vest Tangrowth takes on threatening Water-types such as Primarina, Rotom-W, and Keldeo well. Strong wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T and Nidoking can get past Krookodile's checks such as Slowking, Skarmory, and Tapu Bulu, allowing it to spam its STAB moves more freely. Krookodile is helpless against Grass-types, so partners that can pressure them like Nihilego and Mamoswine are great. Rotom-H is another good teammate that can scare away Grass-types and brings Krookodile in on checks like Nihilego. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Nihilego and Jirachi is key to weaken checks like Rotom-W and Primarina. Salamence and Moltres ensure Tapu Bulu is not given free turns to wallbreak, as it can freely come into Krookodile.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Earthquake and Knock Off threaten a large portion of the metagame and together have almost unresisted coverage, hitting even Amoonguss hard thanks to Choice Band. Stone Edge hits Pokemon immune to Ground like Salamence, Moltres, and Mandibuzz. Close Combat hits Zarude and Chansey harder. Toxic cripples common switch-ins, such as Swampert and Tapu Bulu. Darkest Lariat hits Rotom-W and Tangrowth harder after Knock Off. Choice Band gives Krookodile extra power to break through would-be checks like Amoonguss and defensive Primarina, notably 2HKOing the former with Earthquake.

Krookodile fits on bulky offense and balance teams, where it acts as a potent wallbreaker and clears the way for late-game sweepers like Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina and Azelf by removing threats like Amoonguss and Chansey. Due to its frailty, Krookodile loves VoltTurn support from teammates like Jirachi and Mienshao, which can bring it in safely against Pokemon such as Aegislash and Tentacruel to start wreaking havoc. Rotom-H is an especially great teammate, since it can bring in Krookodile with Volt Switch and scares out switch-ins like Tangrowth, Zarude, and Skarmory. Entry hazard support from allies like Nihilego and Skarmory is greatly appreciated to weaken checks like Tangrowth.
