Air Balloon is a very good alternative, making Aegislash even harder to revenge kill by hindering Pokemon like Diggersby and Rhyperior.

This set is an incredible fit on bulky offense and hyper offense teams looking for a strong priority-using sweeper. Aegislash appreciates pivots like Azelf and Rotom-W, which can bring it into the field safely; the latter can also give Aegislash even more setup opportunities with Trick + Choice Scarf. Other setup sweepers like Galarian Moltres and Thundurus-T pair really well with Aegislash, as they can overwhelm the opponent and open up holes for it to clean up. Quagsire is incredibly hard for this set to get past thanks to their high physical bulk, super effective moves, and Unaware in the former's case; all of this makes Gyarados an incredible partner, KOing both with Power Whip and Bounce, respectively. Strong special attackers like Primarina, which handles foes such as Quagsire, are also really good teammates. Entry hazard setters greatly benefit Aegislash; Ribombee and Shuckle provide Sticky Web, letting Aegislash overcome its low Speed, while Krookodile and Rhyperior provide Stealth Rock to soften up foes.

sets.name: Autotomize
sets.description:
Autotomize lets Aegislash bypass its low Speed and possibly clean up after the opposing team has been weakened. At +2, Aegislash outspeeds almost all of the entire unboosted metagame and other notable targets like Choice Scarf Krookodile. Shadow Ball and Flash Cannon are reliable STAB moves that give Aegislash ample coverage for almost the whole tier. Close Combat is needed to get past specially defensive walls like Chansey and Umbreon, which would otherwise wall Aegislash; it also hits Dark-types like Krookodile and Zarude super effectively. Weakness Policy takes advantage of the many super effective hits that aren't enough to KO Aegislash, like Azelf's Knock Off and Salamence's Flamethrower, to sweep more effectively.

This set is a good fit on bulky offense and other offense teams by virtue of being an effective cleaner. If Weakness Policy isn't triggered, Aegislash is fairly weak, so it greatly appreciates strong wallbreakers like Nidoking and Primarina opening up the path for it to clean up. Other setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Gyarados and Belly Drum Azumarill can help overwhelm the opponent or finish up Aegislash's job after it has weakened the opposing team. Even after Autotomize, Pokemon like Choice Scarf Zarude still outspeed Aegislash and can revenge kill it in its vulnerable Blade forme, which makes Sticky Web support from Shuckle or Araquanid incredibly valuable. Other entry hazards like Roserade's Spikes and Krookdile's Stealth Rock are very helpful after Weakness Policy to break through foes like Rhyperior and Krookodile more easily.

Noivern.overview: Noivern is notable for outspeeding the entire UU metagame, making it a naturally fast teammate without the use of a Choice Scarf. Its great STAB combination also makes Noivern a solid revenge killer. Furthermore, its defensive typing, access to reliable recovery, and decent bulk allow Noivern to reliably check threats like Keldeo and Zarude. Unfortunately, Noivern finds itself competing for a spot on teams with the tier's other Dragon / Flying type, Salamence. Salamence is much stronger and bulkier, which makes it a better wallbreaker and allows it to fulfill Noivern's defensive niche much more effectively than Noivern itself. However, Noivern's higher Speed, which is especially useful when dealing with massive threats like Keldeo, still makes it a solid option and a worthwhile pick over Salamence.
Noivern.comments:
Other Options

Super Fang can be used to weaken bulky walls like Chansey and Celesteela and make it easier for its teammates to revenge kill them while also pairing nicely with Taunt, but it's not very useful otherwise. Boomburst is another option for an attacking move, having an incredibly high Base Power without the drawbacks of Draco Meteor or Hurricane, but it is weaker and does not hit anything super effectively. Defog is a solid option, as Noivern is the fastest Defogger in the metagame and also checks common entry hazard setters like Jirachi and Kommo-o. However, Noivern struggles to fit Defog into its moveset, and if you want to run a Dragon / Flying Defogger, Salamence is a better option. Choice Specs is an option to make Noivern hit harder, but the lack of Heavy-Duty Boots makes Noivern incredibly susceptible to Stealth Rock, and thus it remains a very fringe option.

Checks and Counters

Special Walls: Chansey brushes off all of Noivern's moves and forces it to switch out, though it does have to worry about Taunt. Rhyperior can also easily sponge Noivern's attacks except for Draco Meteor. Finally, Celesteela is only 4HKOed by Noivern's Flamethrower, allowing it to serve as an occasional check.

Priority Users: Pokémon like Mamoswine and Lycanroc-D can use their super effective priority moves to bypass Noivern's blistering Speed and easily take it out.

Knock Off Users: Krookodile, Tangrowth, Conkeldurr, and other common Knock Off users can remove Noivern's Heavy-Duty Boots, which severely hampers its longevity and makes it unable to perform its role as a pivot as well as it could.

Fairy-types: Hatterene, Primarina, and Azumarill can take at least one hit and hit Noivern hard with their super effective STAB moves. However, these Pokemon generally don't like having to take more than one Hurricane.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Hurricane hits a wider amount of range than Draco Meteor, such as Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Conkeldurr, and allows Noivern to pressure Fairy types, like Togekiss and Azumarill. However, Draco Meteor is more reliable and spammable than Hurricane, allows Noivern to OHKO Salamence and potentially OHKO Kommo-o, and is useful for chipping Pokemon that would otherwise check Noivern, like Rhyperior, Rotom-H, and Rotom-W. Flamethrower prevents Noivern from being completely walled by Steel-types, such as Aegislash, Jirachi, and Celesteela. U-turn is an option over either STAB move that allows Noivern to pivot out of would-be checks and bring in teammates more safely. Noivern does prefer to run both STAB moves, however. Roost is necessary for longevity. Infiltrator is used to bypass Substitute, which is crucial for allowing Noivern to take out Pokemon that rely on it, like Keldeo and Aegislash.

Noivern is best used on teams that otherwise lack naturally fast Pokemon or Choice Scarf users. Electric-types like Raikou and Rotom-W are particularly good partners for Noivern, forming a fast VoltTurn core. Raikou can lure in Rhyperior and weaken it with Toxic or Scald, as well as pressure Pokemon like Primarina and Azumarill for Noivern. Rotom-W can check Mamoswine and deals with Ground-types like Krookodile and Rhyperior better than Noivern can. Grass-types, such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss, are able to come in on Pokemon like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D that threaten Noivern. Wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-D, Mamoswine, and Crawdaunt help make up for Noivern's lackluster offensive presence. These Pokemon can also remove special walls that Noivern otherwise struggles with, such as Chansey, Primarina, and Milotic. Nihilego and Krookodile can set up entry hazards, which allow Noivern to more easily KO foes.

Zygarde-10%.overview: Zygarde-10% is a solid offensive Pokemon in UU thanks to its nearly unmatched Speed, outspeeding most offensive threats in the tier like Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Lycanroc-D. Thousand Arrows separates Zygarde-10% from other offensive Ground-types like Excadrill and Mamoswine because it can hit Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres while ignoring Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain. Extreme Speed is useful for picking off weakened setup sweepers and other faster threats like Gyarados and Choice Scarf Diggersby, letting Zygarde-10% be a potent revenge killer and a powerful cleaner. Sadly, Zygarde-10% has awful bulk, making pivots necessary, as even neutral attacks wear it down easily. Its mediocre Attack also means that it relies on chip damage to wear down foes such as Primarina, Slowking, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Its reliance on Choice Band means the aformentioned threats can switch into it and scout what move Zygarde-10% is locked into, letting them switch into a teammate that can handle whatever move Zygarde-10% goes for. Being locked into Extreme Speed is also risky, since it makes Zygarde-10% setup fodder for its checks like Swords Dance Scizor.
Zygarde-10%.comments:
Other Options

Zygarde-10% can run a Dragon Dance + Life Orb set to sweep weakened teams without locking itself into moves, but Gyarados and Salamence can fulfill that role better with their superior bulk. Scale Shot gives it a secondary Dragon-type STAB move without having to lock into Outrage, but it’s inconsistency makes it not worth it most of the time. Iron Tail can hit Tapu Bulu and Hatterene super effectively, but it has poor accuracy and coverage compared to its other moves. A set with Coil and Thousand Waves can heavily punish teams that rely on Tangrowth and Hippowdon lacking Whirlwind to check it, but this set can struggle against teams without them.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Physically defensive Tangrowth can consistently tank all of Zygarde-10%'s attacks, though it doesn't like Toxic, and Assault Vest variants are 2HKOed by Outrage. Zarude can consistently switch into Thousand Arrows and outspeed if it carries a Choice Scarf, but it has to watch out for Superpower and Skitter Smack. Tapu Bulu resists Thousand Arrows and threatens Zygarde-10% with Horn Leech.

Fairy-types: Azumarill and Primarina switch into Zygarde-10% can punish Zygarde-10% locked into Outrage while easily OHKOing it with Play Rough and Moonblast. Hatterene is able to trade with Zygarde-10% and restore its health with Draining Kiss.

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users like Diggersby and Hydreigon outspeed and KO Zygarde-10% easily. Mamoswine OHKOes it with Ice Shard, while Conkeldurr can do big damage with Mach Punch, though they have to be wary of Extreme Speed due to its higher priority. Scizor resists Outrage and Extreme Speed and can KO Zygarde-10% with Bullet Punch. Noivern naturally outspeeds Zygarde-10% and OHKOes it with Draco Meteor.

Bulky Foes: Chansey, Slowking, Hippowdon, and Mandibuzz can tank Thousand Arrows and heal it off reliably, with the latter hitting Zygarde-10% hard with Foul Play. Salamence and Swampert can switch in as well, but they must watch out for Outrage.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Thousand Arrows is incredibly spammable and lets Zygarde-10% crush Rotom-W, Excadrill, and Cobalion. Extreme Speed lets it pick off some setup sweepers like Salamence and Azelf without having to rely on a Speed tie. Outrage lets Zygarde-10% sweep late-game against weakened teams by getting OHKOs and 2HKOs Thousand Arrows cannot, punishing threats like Chansey, Salamence, and even Tangrowth and Hippowdon with some prior chip damage. However, being locked into Outrage is risky if the opponent has a Fairy- or Steel-type on their team. Superpower hits Chansey, Cobalion, and Zarude while providing good coverage overall, Skitter Smack can guarantee an OHKO on Zarude and take out a weakened Tangrowth, and Toxic punishes bulky foes like Tangrowth, Hippowdon, and Mandibuzz.

Zygarde-10% best fits on balance and bulky offense as a potent revenge killer. Teammates like Chansey, Slowking, and Mandibuzz can deal with checks to Zygarde-10% like Primarina, Conkeldurr, and Zarude, and get it in safely with slow pivots. Zarude breaks though bulky Water-types like Swampert and Slowking, also bringing in Zygarde-10% on Skarmory and Aegislash to force them out. Moltres is an additional pivot that can deal with Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu, as well as bringing Zygarde-10% in against Tentacruel and Rotom-W. It also punishes Steel-types like Scizor coming in when Zygarde-10% is locked into Outrage or Extreme Speed. Nihilego handles Grass-types and sets up Stealth Rock to wear down teams so Zygarde-10% can sweep with Thousand Arrows or Outrage. Rotom-W covers Mamoswine well while appreciating Thousand Arrows wearing down Amoonguss. Other wallbreakers like Keldeo and Hydreigon appreciate Zygarde-10% wearing down foes like Slowking and Celesteela for them to overwhelm. Hippowdon can take any move that Zygarde-10% throws at it and heal itself with Slack Off, so Skarmory is a good partner to freely set up Spikes against it.

Primarina.overview: Few Pokemon resist Primarina's STAB combination of Water and Fairy, making it a massive threat capable of threatening defensive Pokemon such as Jirachi, Celesteela, and Kommo-o. Its typing also shines defensively, allowing it to face Pokemon such as Keldeo and Kommo-o. Psychic covers the only answers to its STAB combination in Amoonguss and Tentacruel, and Calm Mind allows it to more easily get past common checks such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Unfortunately, Primarina has very low Speed, often forcing it to take a hit from Pokemon it's supposed to answer, such as Keldeo, before KOing them back. Its similarly low Defense stat makes it 2HKOed by even resisted hits such as Choice Specs Keldeo's Secret Sword after Stealth Rock damage and Crawdaunt's Crabhammer, so it can't check them well despite having the type advantage. Primarina faces some competition from Azumarill as a Water- and Fairy-type wallbreaker, as Azumarill acts a physical wallbreaker, can pressure walls with Knock Off, and has priority in Aqua Jet to make up for the lack of Speed, letting it check Pokemon like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D a lot more comfortably.
Primarina.comments:
Other Options

A spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA gives Primarina more bulk to deal with physical attackers like Lycanroc-D, but it is generally worse because Primarina doesn't have a usable Defense stat to begin with. Even with maximum Defense investment, Primarina is still 2HKOed by Pokemon like Mamoswine and Azumarill. Sparkling Aria is stronger than Scald and bypasses Substitute, but Scald's burn chance is a big help against checks like Amoonguss and Tentacruel. A Calm Mind + 3 attacks set can be used to boost Primarina's special attack to bypass answers like Tangrowth and Amoonguss.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Primarina's best counter is Chansey, as it can stomach even a Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump with ease. Chansey also easily beats Substitute Primarina, as it can break the Substitute with Seismic Toss and scare Primarina away with Toxic. Primarina gives Chansey free turns to set up Stealth Rock, heal itself with Soft-Boiled, and bring in teammates with Teleport. It does have to be wary of Torrent-boosted Hydro Pump, though, as it 2HKOes after Stealth Rock damage.

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can cripple Primarina with Giga Drain, Sludge Bomb, and the former with Spore. Both can take on Primarina's STAB moves, but they have to scout for Choice Specs sets, as Psychic 2HKOes Amoonguss, while Moonblast 2HKOes Assault Vest Tangrowth after Stealth Rock damage. Tangrowth can, however, opt for Power Whip in place of Giga Drain to bypass Primarina's Special Defense boosts. Tapu Bulu outspeeds Primarina and can OHKO it with Horn Leech, but it doesn't like switching directly into Moonblast or risking Scald burns.

Water-types: Rotom-W can pivot into Primarina's Water-type moves and threaten it with Volt Switch in order to bring in a teammate like Tangrowth, but it is scared of Moonblast. Tentacruel eats any hit Primarina throws at it except Psychic. It also outspeeds Primarina and can pressure it with Sludge Bomb and Knock Off. Volcanion is only bothered by Psychic and can 2HKO Primarina with Sludge Bomb.

Faster Pokemon and Physical Attackers: Faster physical attackers such as Mamoswine, Lycanroc-D, and Zarude threaten Primarina with their powerful STAB moves. Other faster Pokemon such as Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Venusaur threaten Primarina with their strong STAB attacks despite its good Special Defense.

Electric-types: Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Raikou outspeed Primarina, 2HKO or OHKO it with their attacks, and generate momentum with Volt Switch.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Psychic does copious amounts of damage to would-be checks in Amoonguss and Tentacruel. After Stealth Rock, Amoonguss risks being OHKOed. Scald is used as a reliable Water-type move when risking Hydro Pump is unnecessary. It also has a 30% chance to burn switch-ins, making it so Primarina can take physical attacks a bit better and wear down Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Tentacruel. A Modest nature lets Primarina 2HKO Pokemon like Celesteela with Hydro Pump.

This set aims to punch holes through the raw power of Primarina's Choice Specs-boosted moves. Pivots such as Jirachi and Zarude can bring in Primarina safely with U-turn in front of Pokemon like Entei and Kommo-o, making up for its low Speed. Chandelure beats Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and some variants pressure Chansey for Primarina. Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Seismitoad handle Electric-types like Thundurus-T and set Stealth Rock up to help Primarina wallbreak. Chansey walls Primarina effortlessly, so Fighting-types such as Mienshao and Kommo-o can be used to threaten it. Primarina can be easily worn down by entry hazards, so a Wish passer like Jirachi can help it stay in the match for longer. In the same vein, entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H extend Primarina's longevity.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
Thanks to its bulk, Primarina continuously checks threats such as Keldeo and Salamence by healing itself with Rest while taking advantage of its excellent STAB combination with Sleep Talk. Rest allows it to not be ruined by status such as Toxic from Aegislash and Krookodile. Moonblast is great neutral coverage while also proving super effective damage on Kommo-o and Galarian Moltres. Scald allows Primarina to get a burn on switch-ins like Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Tentacruel, negating the recovery from their items. 124 Special Defense EVs and Leftovers allow Primarina to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball and 3HKO from Salamence's Hurricane from full HP without Stealth Rock, with the rest put into Defense to take on Dragon Dance Salamence and Keldeo's Secret Sword better. Leftovers is great, as it synergizes well with Rest + Sleep Talk, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to negate damage from entry hazards if the team has unreliable or no hazard removal.

RestTalk Primarina is mainly used on bulky teams that appreciate a status sponge and value the defensive qualities its typing provides. Necrozma is an excellent partner, as it can threaten Amoonguss and Tentacruel, that would otherwise counter Primarina. Zarude checks Rotom-W and Chansey while appreciating Primarina checking Keldeo and Kommo-o. Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Moltres can help check Grass-types such as Zarude and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and provide momentum with Volt Switch and U-turn. Hazard control is important for Primarina to not be chipped down easily and forced to use Rest if it is running Leftovers. Salamence removes entry hazards with Defog and checks Zarude well. Kommo-o, Rhyperior, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all form solid defensive cores with Primarina, as they are able to check Pokemon such as Volcanion, Thundurus, and Rotom-W nicely, while Primarina checks Salamence, Keldeo, and Moltres in return.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Substitute lets Primarina avoid sleep and poison, which would otherwise cripple it and prevent it from sweeping with Calm Mind. Common checks like Amoonguss can't deal with Primarina if it uses Substitute as they come in, as Primarina is faster and can set up with Calm Mind. Substitute also eases prediction when forcing switches from Pokemon like Salamence and Kommo-o. Draining Kiss aids Primarina in recovering HP, allowing it to take more hits and use Substitute if needed. However, Draining Kiss is a very weak move and will only pose a threat if Primarina has accumulated enough boosts. Moonblast, on the other hand, is powerful from the start and lets Primarina not rely too much on Calm Mind boosts to threaten Water-resistant Pokemon like Tangrowth and Rotom-W. Scald is a reliable Water-type move, capable of burning Pokemon trying to check it, like Tentacruel, Assault Vest Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Leftovers compensates the 25% loss in HP from Substitute. With the given EV spread Primarina is able to beat Amoonguss one-on-one, as it ensures Amoonguss can't break Primarina's Substitute after a Calm Mind.

Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as its ability to come in on moves like Draco Meteor from Salamence is greatly appreciated by other teammates. By switching on these moves, Primarina can either get a Substitute up or set up with Calm Mind if its checks have been eliminated or weakened. Strong wallbreakers like Mamoswine, Nidoking, and Aegislash can get past bulky Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Electric-types such as Raikou and Thundurus-T force Primarina out of the field if it doesn't have a Substitute up, so Pokemon like Rhyperior and Seismitoad take care of them. They can also set Stealth Rock to aid Primarina in its sweep. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can take on strong physical attackers such as Diggersby and Mamoswine for Primarina. Chansey is extremely annoying, as it can take boosted hits with ease and threaten Primarina back with Toxic and Seismic Toss. Conkeldurr, Lycanroc-D, and Swords Dance Diggersby are powerful wallbreakers that can muscle through Chansey and remove it for Primarina.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee is an effective Sticky Web setter thanks to its blistering Speed, decent offensive potential, and ability to threaten common Defoggers like Mandibuzz, Salamence and Rotom-W in addition to other leads like Cobalion. It's also immune to secondary effects thanks to Shield Dust; this makes it impossible for Pokemon like Choice Scarf Jirachi to antilead it, and its access to Skill Swap means that not even Hatterene can prevent it from getting its entry hazard up. As a result, Ribombee is a cornerstone on Sticky Web teams as the best available setter. It can struggle with certain hazard removers that resist Moonblast, though; examples include Excadrill, Moltres, and Tentacruel. It can also give free turns to the likes of Amoonguss, Scizor, and Autotomize Celesteela, though the latter dislikes being hit by Stun Spore.
Ribombee.comments:
Other Options

A Heavy-Duty Boots pivot set using Moonblast, Bug Buzz, Psychic, and U-turn can act as a passable threat that keeps Pokemon like Zygarde-10% and Keldeo in check, but it's too weak and frail to be worth it most of the time. Quiver Dance is an option, but Ribombee's inability to touch common Steel-types like Scizor and Celesteela makes it a hugely unreliable sweeper.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Scizor, Celesteela, and Jirachi wall Ribombee permanently and can KO it with their STAB attacks or use it as setup fodder, though they all hate Stun Spore barring Safety Goggles Scizor, particularly Choice Scarf variants of Jirachi. Excadrill is the most troublesome due to its ability to remove Sticky Web with Rapid Spin.

Poison-types: Nidoking, Amoonguss, and Tentacruel all take little damage from Moonblast and can slam Ribombee hard with their STAB moves. Tentacruel can also use Rapid Spin in Ribombee's face before KOing it with Sludge Bomb, making it impossible for Ribombee to get its entry hazard up.

Fire-types: Rotom-H, Moltres, and Entei take very little damage and can threaten Ribombee easily in return. The former two can clear its Sticky Web with Defog, while Entei poses a general threat to Sticky Web teams thanks to its powerful Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Moonblast is a powerful STAB attack that hits common entry hazard control options like Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Rotom-W quite hard. It also nails threats like Conkeldurr, Hydreigon, and Zarude. Stun Spore prevents Ribombee from being dead weight against Steel-types like Jirachi and Celesteela. It also cripples setup sweepers like Gyarados and Galarian Slowbro that try to take advantage of Ribombee while also paralyzing wallbreakers like Nihilego and Nidoking. U-turn can work well with Stun Spore to pivot out against threats who switch into Stun Spore like Excadrill, allowing Ribombee to bring in a teammate to pave the way for it to safely set up Sticky Web again. Skill Swap is primarily used to bypass Hatterene's Magic Bounce, but it can have bonus effects like removing Beast Boost from Nihilego or Sheer Force from Nidoking, opening up Ribombee's teammates a bit. Focus Sash is used to prevent Pokemon like Choice Scarf Jirachi and Lycanroc-D from OHKOing Ribombee immediately.

Thundurus-T is an exemplary Pokemon that takes full advantage of Sticky Web support—it's brutally powerful and very difficult to revenge kill outside of Lycanroc-D. Krookodile can provide an excellent Stealth Rock user to pair with Ribombee's Sticky Web, acting as a great check to the likes of Lycanroc-D and Nihilego when their Speed has been dropped. Necrozma is also a good option for a Stealth Rock setter that can pressure common Defoggers with its strong Meteor Beam and Photon Geyser, OHKOing the likes of Moltres and Tentacruel. Celesteela is an essential teammate that punishes threats to Sticky Web teams like Excadrill, Zarude, and Scizor. Keldeo becomes even scarier than usual when backed up by Sticky Web support, and its good defensive typing and generally solid bulk allow it to act as a soft check to Pokemon that typically annoy these teams like Nihilego and Mamoswine. Other generally good Pokemon that take advantage of Sticky Web include Gyarados, Azelf, and Nidoking, all of which can put huge pressure on the Steel-types that try to take advantage of Ribombee.

Lycanroc-Dusk.overview: Lycanroc-D is a decent revenge killer due to its strong Tough Claws-boosted priority move in Accelerock, which enables it to revenge kill weakened Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados, and high Speed, which lets it outspeed Thundurus-T and Nihilego. Access to strong coverage moves, such as Close Combat to break past Excadrill, Crunch to deal with Slowking, and Psychic Fangs to break past Amoonguss makes Lycanroc-D very unpredictable to defensively answer. However, Lycanroc-D struggles to break through teams that run physically bulky threats such as Tangrowth, Hippowdon, Swampert, and Skarmory. Its poor bulk also means it cannot come in on almost anything, so it requires pivot support to come in safely as well as occasional aggressive prediction on expected switches. Lycanroc-D is also very prone to wearing itself down between entry hazards and Life Orb recoil, limiting its staying presence on the field. The presence of priority attackers like Scizor and Azumarill can easily pick off Lycanroc-D. Zygarde-10% gives Lycanroc-D fierce competition as a fast physical wallbreaker due to a Stealth Rock resistance, higher Speed, and less prediction reliance.
Lycanroc-Dusk.comments:
Other Options

Sucker Punch can be used to deal more damage than Accelerock against neutral targets; however, it is only really useful for a better matchup against Choice Scarf Jirachi. Swords Dance is an option that allows Lycanroc-D to OHKO foes like Amoonguss and Tangrowth at +2; however, it can struggle to find many opportunities to set up safely. A Focus Sash lead Lycanroc-D is able to use Endeavor while setting up Stealth Rock, but this is generally not worth it in comparison to its other, much more dynamic sets.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu do not switch into Stone Edge well, but they resist Close Combat and threaten Lycanroc-D after switching in; the former also runs Rocky Helmet often, which punishes Lycanroc-D. Tangrowth is the biggest offender, since unboosted Close Combat damage is restored nearly completely by Regenerator, it commonly uses Rocky Helmet, and it can freely threaten Lycanroc-D's team in multiple ways after it comes in. Choice Scarf Zarude takes Accelrock well and can OHKO it with Power Whip.

Steel-types: Skarmory's excellent physical bulk and reliable recovery lets it effortlessly wall Lycanroc-D unless significantly chipped. It also can wear Lycanroc-D down with Rocky Helmet. Choice Scarf Jirachi resists Lycanroc-D's Accelrock and can revenge kill it with Iron Head, only having to fear the rare Sucker Punch. Scizor can revege kill Lycanroc-D easily with Bullet Punch.

Water-types: Foes like Slowking, Primarina, and Swampert that don't fall to one hit and are capable of firing back with super effective attacks pose problems for Lycanroc-D, which has to be kept in reserve while its teammates wear them down. Starmie naturally outspeeds and can threaten Lycanroc-D, though it must be wary of its health to avoid being taken out by Accelrock. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can take an Accelrock from Lycanroc-D unless they are severely weakened and revenge kill it with Aqua Jet in return.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf users that are not in range of its priority are able to revenge kill Lycanroc-D due to its frailty; Diggersby is notable for its resistance to Accelerock and ability to OHKO Lycanroc-D with Earthquake. Pokemon like Azumarill and Conkeldurr can revenge kill Lycanroc-D with their priority attacks.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Stone Edge is a very spammable STAB move that can OHKO Rotom-H and Salamence while dealing heavy damage to neutral targets like Primarina. Close Combat is a powerful coverage option that nails many Rock resistant Pokemon such as Keldeo, Cobalion, and Excadrill. It is also Lycanroc-D's best move for Hippowdon and Celesteela. Psychic Fangs inflicts heavy damage on the likes of Amoonguss, Tentacruel, and Keldeo. Crunch hits Slowking, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro harder, but these targets get musceled through by Stone Edge or Close Combat. Accelerock is useful against offense teams, specifically keeping threats such as Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados in check. It also makes Lycanroc-D more difficult to revenge kill with faster threats such as Venusaur in sun and Starmie. A Life Orb is used to guarantee feats such as 2HKOing defensive Celesteela with Close Combat and Amoonguss with Stone Edge on the switch with Stealth Rock up. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is needed to make Lycanroc-D outspeed and threaten as many foes as it can, particularly Keldeo.

Lycanroc-D fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to revenge kill common offensive threats such as Salamence without sacrificing its teammates' wallbreaking capabilities. As Lycanroc-D is unable to switch in on mostly anything, pivots are appreciated to give it opportunities to punch holes as often as possible and gain momentum; Moltres and Rotom-H are efficient at this and help pressure Skarmory and bulky Grass-types, which usually give Lycanroc-D grief. Swampert also acts as a pivot while providing entry hazard support to wear down Slowking, Tapu Bulu, and Tangrowth. Krookodile is another Stealth Rock setter that draws out Skarmory and Amoonguss to remove their Rocky Helmets with Knock Off. Special attackers such as Moltres and Primarina appreciate Lycanroc-D's ability to break through Chansey, and in return they can help wear down common physically defensive threats such as Skarmory for it. The Grass-types of the tier like Tangrowth and Zarude are excellent partners to handle threats such as Azumarill. Additionally, they also check faster Pokemon Lycanroc-D cannot threaten as much with its priority, such as Zygarde-10%. Early-game wallbreakers like Thundurus-T and Aegislash can pave the way for a Lycanroc-D sweep by weakening foes like Skarmory and Amoonguss for it.

Salazzle.overview: Salazzle's good Speed tier, ability in Corrosion, and solid offensive utility make it a decent support Pokemon in UU. It can outspeed many offensive threats such as Zarude and Azelf, and it takes advantage of defensive staples like Amoonguss and Skarmory. The combination of Knock Off and Toxic lets it outlast Pokemon that would otherwise counter it, such as Tentacruel and Nihilego, and open up counters like Hippowdon for teammates. However, due to its weakness to Stealth Rock, Salazzle is forced to run Heavy-Duty Boots as opposed to a power-boosting item, which makes it heavily reliant on chip damage to make an impact. Its poor bulk also leaves it unable to contribute defensively in most games, and its typing makes it susceptible to priority users like Azumarill and Lycanroc-D. Salazzle's frailty also makes it reliant on pivots to safely enter the battlefield. This frailty also deters it from switching directly into most Pokemon it would otherwise check, especially Scizor and Tangrowth, who both carry Knock Off and can remove its Heavy-Duty Boots. Therefore, it would rather be preserved as a secondary check to the aforementioned Pokemon. It is also extremely difficult for Salazzle to make progress against bulkier Pokemon like Slowking and Hippowdon, but its Toxic support and chip damage can help mid-game wallbreakers and offensive pivots like Mamoswine and Azelf, respectively, break through or pressure them.
Salazzle.comments:
Other Options

Dragon Pulse can OHKO Zygarde-10% but should only be used if your team is weak to it. Nasty Plot over Toxic can make Salazzle a threatening wallbreaker or cleaner, but due to its frailty, it struggles to set up because even resisted attacks sting. Substitute + Toxic Salazzle can be annoying, but Salazzle struggles to make an impact when lacking one of its STAB moves, leaving it to pick and choose its good matchups and lose out on valuable utility. Substitute + Toxic also requires very solid entry hazard control, if running Leftovers, and is still vulnerable to sand chip damage. A Choice Specs set has powerful wallbreaking potential, OHKOing threats like Conkeldurr and Thundurus-T from full health, but Salazzle can't follow up with Toxic and becomes weak to Stealth Rock, cutting into its longevity. It is also extremely prediction reliant, heavily limiting its wallbreaking potential against common defensive staples like Slowking and Hippowdon.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Pokemon that commonly run Choice Scarf, such as Hydreigon and Diggersby, take advantage of Salazzle's extreme frailty and revenge kill it with ease. Priority users like Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10% revenge kill Salazzle as well. Crobat and Noivern naturally outspeed and nail Salazzle for heavy damage.

Special Walls: Chansey can switch into Salazzle thanks to its reliable recovery and Natural Cure, proceeding to force Salazzle out. However, it hates taking Knock Off. Mandibuzz, specially defensive Hippowdon, and Nihilego are all able to switch in comfortably; however, they all hate Knock Off and Toxic.

Water-types: Water-types such as Slowking, Tentacruel, and Swampert can all switch into Salazzle multiple times but despise taking Toxic. Azumarill can KO Salazzle with Aqua Jet.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Salazzle's solid STAB combination lets it threaten common UU Pokemon including Amoonguss, Celesteela, Scizor, and Primarina. Knock Off makes Salazzle more difficult to pivot around with common checks such as Chansey, Mandibuzz, and Swampert. Toxic alongside Corrosion lets Salazzle cripple switch-ins like Nihilego, Tentacruel, Hippowdon, and Slowking, allowing itself or a teammate to overwhelm them and enhancing its offensive potential. Maximum Speed investment is needed to outspeed offensive threats like Azelf, Zarude, and Cobalion. Heavy-Duty Boots alleviates Salazzle's crippling Stealth Rock weakness and helps with its longevity, giving it more opportunities to enter the field safely.

Salazzle fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate it heavily chipping the opposing team, paving the way for teammates to break holes with ease. Mamoswine is an excellent partner for Salazzle, beating checks like Chansey and Mandibuzz and wearing down their shared answers in Swampert and Slowking. Chip damage from Stealth Rock setters, such as Nihilego, Cobalion, and Swampert, is valuable to make switching into Salazzle even more of a pain. Knock Off absorbers, such as the aforementioned Cobalion, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth, are all appreciated due to how punishing it is for Salazzle to lose Heavy-Duty Boots. Cobalion in particular can draw in Grass-types to give Salazzle entry points to fire off an attack. Meanwhile, Amoonguss and Tangrowth check Swampert and Azumarill. Thundurus-T and Zarude are great partners, as both offensively pressure Slowking and Swampert while pivoting on Amoonguss and Tangrowth, giving Salazzle safe entry points despite its frailty. Celesteela and Slowking both reliably check Nihilego and Zygarde-10% for Salazzle. Slowking is able to pivot out on Grass-types with Teleport to let Salazzle in. Checks to defensive Scizor like Celesteela, Cobalion, and Salamence all pair well with Salazzle, as it cannot function as the sole Scizor check on most teams. Salamence also appreciates Salazzle wearing down Hippowdon and Slowking through Knock Off + Toxic, as this makes it extremely difficult for them to switch into repeated Hurricanes.

Tapu Bulu.overview: Tapu Bulu is a decent wallbreaker that provides defensive utility to its team with passive recovery through its Grassy Surge. Tapu Bulu has a great movepool with coverage options like Close Combat, Zen Headbutt, and Stone Edge, which break through potential checks such as Celesteela, Amoonguss, and Moltres. Furthermore, its decent defensive typing, speed, and ability in Grassy Terrain allows it to distinguish itself from other bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth by being a more reliable check to Keldeo and Azumarill as well as enable threats like SubToxic Aegislash, though it does have to be wary of the former crippling it with a Scald burn and hitting it with Choice Specs-boosted Air Slash or Icy Wind. While Tapu Bulu's typing has many useful resistances, it comes at the cost of having a lot of weaknesses to common attacking types like Fire, Ice, and Poison, meaning it struggles against staples like Entei, Mamoswine, Nidoking, and even Kommo-o due to its tendency to run Poison Jab. The tier has an abundance of defensive checks to Tapu Bulu, such as Salamence, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which makes it difficult for Tapu Bulu to make much progress as a wallbreaker, especially when multiple of these checks are naturally found on the same team. Despite its positive traits compared to Amoonguss and Tangrowth, they still outclass it as a defensive Grass-type due to their access to Regenerator and less vulnerable typing. Furthermore, Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain also heals up the opponent's Pokemon as well, sometimes making it a hindrance to teams it is on.
Tapu Bulu.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an option that gives Tapu Bulu even more power; however, it requires a lot more prediction to break through its checks like Amoonguss, and Wood Hammer recoil can wear it down quickly. A Choice Scarf set can be used to revenge kill foes like Thundurus and Noivern; however, it primarily relies on surprise factor to do so. A specially defensive Tapu Bulu set with Horn Leech / Darkest Lariat / Synthesis and either Bulk Up or Swords Dance can be used as a better switch-in to foes like Keldeo and Thundurus-T. However, this set is a huge momentum drain against foes like Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Celesteela. An Assault Vest set improves its matchup against the aforementioned foes while retaining an offensive presence; however, it can be easily overwhelmed by special attackers such as Primarina.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Chandelure is a relatively safe switch-in to Tapu Bulu's most spammable moves and threatens to OHKO it. Rotom-H has to be wary of taking Close Combat; however, it can threaten to OHKO with Overheat and use Tapu Bulu as a free Volt Switch or Defog opportunity. Moltres has to be wary of Stone Edge but otherwise freely switches into Tapu Bulu and threatens to burn it with Flame Body or KO it with a STAB move.

Steel-types: Many of UU's more common Steel-types like Celesteela and Jirachi only take neutral damage from Close Combat and threaten to KO Tapu Bulu. Aegislash can comfortably stomach any hit in Shield forme and OHKO it in return.

Poison-types: Nihilego and Nidoking outspeed and OHKO Tapu Bulu with their Poison-type STAB. Without Darkest Lariat, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro sets up on it with ease. Amoonguss threatens to OHKO Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb, though it has to be wary of +2 Zen Headbutt.

Physical Walls: Physically defensive Tangrowth stomachs any attack barring a +2 Megahorm and OHKOes Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb. Salamence is a huge issue for Tapu Bulu, as it resists the coverage it commonly carries and pressures it with Flying-type attacks, though it has to be wary of Stone Edge. Intimidate makes it much easier for Salamence to stomach any hit from Tapu Bulu. Defensive Buzzwole can stomach any attack and KO Tapu Bulu with Poison Jab.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Horn Leech is the preferred STAB option thanks to its recovery and respectable damage. Stone Edge is crucial coverage to break past Pokemon like Chandelure, Moltres, and Salamence. Close Combat lets Tapu Bulu break through Cobalion and hit other Steel-types like Jirachi and Celesteela harder; however, dropping Stone Edge leaves it unable to punish the common Flying-types, particularly Moltres, which can fish for a burn with Flame Body. Zen Headbutt breaks through Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Buzzwole. Megahorn can help against Tangrowth; however, its coverage isn't very useful otherwise. Darkest Lariat can be used to hit Pokemon like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Chandelure harder. Life Orb with an Adamant nature gives +2 Tapu Bulu the extra power needed to KO foes like Tangrowth and Celesteela. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed Buzzwole and Timid Volcanion, though Adamant's power is generally valued more.

Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its combination of utility and wallbreaking potential. Rotom-W can lure in foes like Seismitoad, giving Tapu Bulu free opportunities to use Swords Dance. Rotom-W can also remove foes like Moltres and wear down Kommo-o and Amoonguss into KO range of Tapu Bulu's attacks. Other wallbreakers like Conkeldurr and Nidoking can help break through defensive cores that Tapu Bulu struggles with. Keldeo appreciates Tapu Bulu being able to lure in and remove bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tentacruel is appreciated as another Water-resistant Pokemon, as Tapu Bulu doesn't want to risk a burn from Keldeo's Scald, for example. Although Tapu Bulu is a Fairy-type, it struggles to consistently check a majority of Dragon-types, such as Salamence and Kommo-o, due to its lack of a good Fairy-type attack and its weakness to their common coverage. For this reason, partners like Celesteela and Aegislash are imperative.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Horn Leech allows Tapu Bulu to gain recovery while still having a strong move to hit Primarina, Crawdaunt, and Lycanroc-D. Dazzling Gleam is able to sometimes OHKO Kommo-o and deals good damage to Zarude and Buzzwole. Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Rotom-H and Salamence. Synthesis is reliable recovery, but it should only be used sparingly due to its low PP. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item, but Rocky Helmet can be used to punish contact moves from Zarude, Krookodile, and Gyarados. The EV spread is to outspeed Choice Specs Primarina while maximizing physical bulk to better check Buzzwole and Lycanroc-D.

Defensive Tapu Bulu is mainly found on stall and balance teams, as they appreciate it bringing Grassy Terrain for extra recovery. Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro and SubToxic Aegislash are great partners, as they can deal with Amoonguss and Togekiss, respectively. In return, Tapu Bulu is able to handle Krookodile, Rhyperior, Zarude, and Crawdaunt for these Pokemon. Chansey is able to check non-Dragon Dance Salamence and other special attackers such as Nidoking and Nihilego; Tapu Bulu beats Keldeo, one of the few special attackers that can break through Chansey. Umbreon provides Wish support so that Tapu Bulu does not have to use Synthesis often while also checking Salamence and Aegislash. Fire-types such as Entei and Moltres help deal with Jirachi, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which wall it.

Nihilego.overview: Nihilego stands out as a great utility Pokémon that also boasts high offensive stats. Its good STAB combination hits key Pokemon such as Thundurus-T, Salamence, Tangrowth, and Primarina super effectively. It has important resistances like Flying, Fairy, and Fire; its Flying resistance and high Special Defense in particular are appreciated by teams that struggle with Flying-types like Moltres and Galarian Moltres. Nihilego is an amazing Stealth Rock setter, as its resistances give very good matchups against Defoggers such as Salamence, Moltres, and Mandibuzz. Its Knock Off is useful for common switch-ins like Chansey, Aegislash, Excadrill, and Celesteela. It can use Meteor Beam as well to boost its Special Attack and become a fierce sweeper. Its unique Speed tier puts it ahead of Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Moltres, and after a Speed boost from Beast Boost, it only falls behind Choice Scarf Zarude. However, its weaknesses and horrid Defense stat leave it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Excadrill, Jirachi, and Keldeo, and priority from the likes of Conkeldurr, Azumarill, and Crawdaunt easily shuts it down. It lacks room for coverage for Pokemon like Nidoking, and it just cannot get past checks like Jirachi and Aegislash.
Nihilego.comments:
Other Options

Grass Knot can be used over Knock Off eliminate Pokemon that don't mind Power Gem + Sludge Bomb, like Swampert. However, the utility Knock Off provides is amazing, and it's only worth replacing if Nihilego's team has enough other Knock Off users. Protect scouts Choice-locked foes like Zygarde-10%, letting Nihilego switch to the appropriate teammate, but is hard to fit over the very valuable Knock Off. Toxic Spikes is a secondary entry hazard option that weakens defensive staples like Swampert and cripples Substitute users such as Primarina. However, Poison-types remove it and a large portion of the metagame is immune to it, like Rotom-H, Salamence, Celesteela, and Aegislash. A Choice Scarf set with Power Gem / Sludge Bomb / Thunderbolt / Grass Knot lets Nihilego clean through teams and revenge kill Pokemon like Keldeo and other Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, but Choice-locked Nihilego is vulnerable to Pokemon like Aegislash and Azumarill. Pain Split can be considered as a form of recovery on the utility set, but it is very unreliable due to Nihilego's high HP and can only be used against special attackers that can't hurt it much.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is Nihilego's best answer, capable of wearing it down with Seismic Toss and healing itself with Soft-Boiled. As long as Chansey doesn't let it accumulate several boosts, it can always beat Nihilego. Chansey hates having its Eviolite removed, though.

Ground-types: Krookodile, Nidoking, and Swampert don't care about Nihilego's STAB moves and can force it out of the field with their STAB Ground-type moves, but they have dislike getting hit with Knock Off. Zygarde-10% outspeeds Nihilego and can OHKO it with Thousand Arrows.

Steel-types: Excadrill and Jirachi wall Nihilego easily and can scare it out with their STAB attacks. The former is troublesome, since it can easily come in and remove Nihilego's Stealth Rock. Cobalion can pivot into Nihilego's attacks and exploit its weak physical defense. Celesteela is capable of taking +1 Thunderbolt and OHKOing Nihilego back with Heavy Slam. Aegislash easily switches into even boosted Nihilego and can KO it with its Steel-type STAB move or revenge kill it with Shadow Sneak.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: Faster threats like Lycanroc-D, Zarude, and Azelf all outspeed and threaten to OHKO Nihilego. However, these Pokemon must be wary of Nihilego getting a speed boost after getting a KO on its Meteor Beam set. Priority users like Azumarill, Conkeldurr, and Crawdaunt can OHKO Nihilego with their priority moves.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Utility
sets.description:
Nihilego's typing allows it to switch into a majority of the tier's Defoggers, including Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Moltres, and set Stealth Rock. Power Gem threatens many Defoggers and hits neutral targets Sludge Bomb can't, like Galarian Slowbro, Skarmory, and Celesteela. Sludge Bomb threatens Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Primarina. Sludge Bomb poisons are helpful for crippling checks like Swampert. Knock Off cripples checks to Nihilego like Aegislash, Chansey, and Celesteela. It's also great for removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Defoggers. Black Sludge mitigates entry hazards and chip damage. Nihilego can also run an EV spread of 80 Def / 176 SpA / 252 Spe, to get a Speed Boost with Beast Boost to be faster than revenge killers like Zarude.

This set fits on every playstyle except hyper offense. Nihilego's team appreciates its good defensive typing and Knock Off, and its offensive capabilities are valuable for removing threats like Primarina and Salamence. Stall in particular appreciates Nihilego's good matchup against Nasty Plot Togekiss and Thundurus-T. Skarmory is an amazing partner for Nihilego, forming an entry hazard stacking core with it and checking major threats like Excadrill and Zarude. In return, Nihilego beats threats to Skarmory like Moltres and Thundurus-T. Wallbreakers like Thundurus-T, Mamoswine, and Conkeldurr love Nihilego setting up Stealth Rock and weakening their checks like Assault Vest Tangrowth, Celesteela, and Amoonguss. Chansey completely walls this set even after having its Eviolite removed, so these wallbreakers can also take care of it. Pivots like Slowking, Azelf, and Zarude can bring in Nihilego to set Stealth Rock and wallbreak. Aegislash has notable defensive synergy with Nihilego, as it checks Pokemon like Galarian Slowbro, Lycanroc-D, and Slowking. Moltres and Rotom-H deal with Steel-types that wall Nihilego, like Aegislash and Jirachi. Nihilego in return can take out Thundurus-T and Salamence.

sets.name: Meteor Beam Sweeper
sets.description:
Meteor Beam is Nihilego's most important move, boosting Special Attack and muscling past checks like Celesteela once they're chipped. Sludge Wave hits tier staples like Primarina, Tangrowth, and Hydreigon. Thunderbolt allows Nihilego to hit Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash neutrally and other checks like Celesteela and Slowking super effectively. Power Gem can be used in place of Thunderbolt for a more reliable hit on Pokemon like Mandibuzz, Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Galarian Moltres. Grass Knot deals with Ground-types like Krookodile, Swampert, and Quagsire. Hex is an option to pressure Jirachi and Aegislash. Pain Split can be used to give Nihilego some recovery, though the lack of coverage creates more issues. Power Herb is required for Meteor Beam. The given EV spread and a Timid nature make Speed Nihilego's highest stat for Beast Boost, letting it outspeed revenge killers like Keldeo and Azelf.

This set fits on hyper offense teams, where Nihilego can KO weakened checks like Celesteela with Meteor Beam to boost both its Speed and Special Attack. Entry hazard setters like Krookodile, Scolipede, and Excadrill help Nihilego by weakening some of its checks, like Nidoking and Celesteela. Keldeo and Belly Drum Azumarill are extremely strong wallbreakers that can punch holes for Nihilego to sweep late-game, destroying Chansey, Celesteela, and Excadrill. Secondary sweepers like Gyarados and Galarian Moltres can break past or dent Nidoking and Steel-types like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Celesteela. In return, Nihilego can remove Thundurus-T.

Celesteela.overview: Celesteela's typing and defensive stats are both fantastic, allowing it to check a considerable portion of UU's top threats, including Salamence, Aegislash, Jirachi, Nihilego, and Excadrill. Thanks to its decent offensive stats, powerful STAB Heavy Slam, and access to Flamethrower to smack foes like Aegislash and Zarude, Celesteela can prevent itself from being too passive. Leech Seed is also an excellent tool, sustaining Celesteela's longevity and allowing it to significantly wear down its switch-ins, such as Rotom-H and Thundurus-T, potentially forcing them out. Autotomize sets are also a strong option, tapping into Celesteela's strong special coverage and the sweeping potential Beast Boost lends it. Despite its defensive potency, however, Celesteela suffers a bit from its lack of access to reliable recovery, which can prevent it from tanking strong neutral hits as consistently as it would like to and cause it to be overreliant on Leftovers. This can allow a few common Pokemon, such as Nihilego and Mamoswine, to muscle past Celesteela after relatively minimal chip damage. Celesteela also struggles to bypass popular Fire- and Electric-types such as Moltres and Thundurus-T on its own, as well as various defensive picks like Tentacruel and Slowking; Tentacruel can utilize Liquid Ooze to take advantage of Leech Seed, while Slowking doesn't take meaningful damage from any of Celesteela's attacks, can absorb Leech Seed and Teleport out, and can threaten to chip Celesteela down with burns from Scald.
Celesteela.comments:
Other Options

Celesteela's can utilize a mixed Assault Vest set to better answer Aegislash and Salamence, with its colorful movepool letting it surprise typical checks such as Slowking with Megahorn and Moltres with Stone Edge and potentially break large holes in the opposing team. Due to its selection of potent physical moves such as Earthquake and Stone Edge, Celesteela can also run a physically based Autotomize set, effectively luring checks like Tentacruel and Rotom-H. However, this generally isn't as effective due to Celesteela's middling immediate power and hardships breaking various Pokemon, such as Tangrowth and Krookodile. Earthquake is an option in the fourth slot of the defensive set to still hit Steel-types super effectively while also hitting Tentacruel hard. However, Flamethrower is usually way more valuable for its ability to pressure Zarude while still hitting Steel-types. Toxic cripples some of Celesteela's switch-ins on the defensive set, but it generally isn't as useful as its other options, and, due to foregoing either Protect, it notably makes Celesteela more susceptible to being worn down.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Moltres, Volcanion, Rotom-H, and Chandelure can pivot in on both Heavy Slam and Flamethrower and hit Celesteela hard with super effective STAB moves. They can also blanket check Celesteela's Autotomize set if it opts for Flash Cannon, though Meteor Beam can power through them. Moltres is particularly annoying, often being able to restore any chip damage it sustains from Leech Seed with Roost.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Toxtricity can tank hits from either of Celesteela's sets and proceed to break past it with super effective STAB attacks, though they all take fair damage from Meteor Beam.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Chansey doesn't take major damage from Celesteela's attacks and can whittle it down with Seismic Toss or bring in a teammate with Teleport. Tentacruel's Liquid Ooze punishes Leech Seed attempts and it doesn't take major damage from any attack Celesteela commonly runs. Slowking can pivot into Celesteela and Teleport out to stop Leech Seed or chip it with Scald.

Knock Off: Celesteela's defensive set becomes far easier to wear down if Leftovers, its most reliable means of passive recovery, has been removed. Knock Off users like Mamoswine, Azelf, and Nihilego can wear it down immensely as it tries potentially pivoting in on them. The Autotomize set is also often reliant on whichever item it is running to pose a significant offensive threat, which can prevent Celesteela from setting up on foes like Nihilego and Tangrowth as safely as it would like to at times.

Strong Wallbreakers: Celesteela's lack of reliable recovery allows particularly powerful wallbreakers, including Conkeldurr, Primarina, Mamoswine, and Aegislash, to quickly overwhelm it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Aegislash and Excadrill, preventing them from reliably setting up on Celesteela, while also hitting Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude, which are immune to Leech Seed. Leech Seed is important to wear down common switch-ins, including Moltres, Rotom-W, and Thundurus-T. It also prevents Pokemon like Gyarados and Dragon Dance Salamence from reliably setting up on Celesteela, chipping them down. Protect works well alongside Leech Seed, offering Celesteela a guaranteed opportunity to restore health with both Leftovers and Leech Seed. It can also help to scout moves from Choice-locked Pokemon, like Zygarde-10% and Primarina.

Celesteela is a solid fit on bulky offense and balance teams thanks to its ability to check several prominent threats like Galarian Moltres and Zarude, allowing offensive teammates to fall back on it upon losing momentum to foes like Salamence. Bulky Water-types often share strong synergy with Celesteela, checking the Fire-types that power through it, while Celesteela can handle Pokemon like Zarude and Tapu Bulu in return. Swampert and Slowking check both Rotom-H and Moltres, two of Celesteela's more effective answers, while also being helpful against Mamoswine. Slowking can also bring Celesteela in safely with Teleport against foes such as Tapu Bulu and Hydreigon. Nihilego is another good teammate, pivoting in on Pokemon like Moltres and Thundurus-T for Celesteela while appreciating its ability to deal with Ground-types such as Excadrill and Nidoking. Defensive Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can also make solid teammates, as they can pivot into threats to Celesteela like Keldeo and Azumarill. They both can absorb Knock Off for Celesteela, and the former can use Knock Off itself to cripple switch-ins to Celesteela like Moltres. Zarude is another phenomonal partner capable of offensively pressuring Slowking better and revenge killing Thundurus-T. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Tentacruel keep Celesteela from being worn down by Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Autotomize
sets.description:
Autotomize allows Celesteela to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and more easily snowball. It can find setup opportunities against a solid amount of common Pokemon that its defensive set forces out, including Zarude, Hatterene, and Nihilego. Fire Blast provides important coverage against Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. Flamethrower is an option over Fire Blast for its greater accuracy. However, Celesteela wants all the power it can get due to this set's nature as a sweeper. Meteor Beam grants Celesteela an opportunity to bypass Fire-types like Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure. It also deals massive damage to foes like Rotom-W, Thundurus-T, and Salamence, and the Special Attack boost it supplies is often extremely useful in boosting Celesteela's sweeping capabilities. Due to taking two turns, however, it must be used with Power Herb, and Celesteela must watch out for the opponent predicting the attack and bringing in a foe that resists it due to often being restricted to a one-time use. Flash Cannon is also an option in the fourth slot, offering more overall consistency and giving Celesteela a strong secondary STAB attack that deals decent neutral damage and hits Pokemon like Hatterene, Nihilego, and Rhyperior super effectively. Giga Drain is an option to bypass Quagsire, Swampert, and Rotom-W, which can otherwise tank various hits, though it generally doesn't provide too valuable of coverage otherwise. Beast Boost lets Celesteela boost its Special Attack upon netting KOs, giving it great sweeping potential. If Meteor Beam is not being run, Celesteela has no need for Power Herb and can then run Weakness Policy. This allows it to use its solid bulk to tank super effective hits, such as Fire-type moves from Salamence or opposing Celesteela, to gain a +2 boost in power, which heavily increases its threat level.

This set fits on offensive builds, acting as a late-game sweeper that cleans weakened teams. On hyper offense teams, leads like Excadrill and Scolipede can provide entry hazards to wear down checks like Rotom-W and Slowking. Powerful wallbreakers like Azumarill and Aegislash make strong teammates capable of removing foes such as Slowking and Chansey for Celesteela to sweep through late-game. Depending on the coverage it opts for, Celesteela will struggle to reliably break past various Pokemon. If it isn't running Meteor Beam, checks to Fire-types like the aformentioned Azumarill and Gyarados are great teammates, easily being able to pressure Rotom-H and Moltres. Without Flash Cannon, Celesteela can't hit Rock-types like Rhyperior and Nihilego super effectively, making Pokemon like Zygarde-10% and Mamoswine solid partners. Lastly, secondary sweepers like Thundurus-T and Nihilego often fit well with offensive Celesteela, helping pressure and overwhelm the likes of Chansey and Slowking.

Necrozma.overview: Necrozma is a solid sweeper in UU thanks to its offensive versatility, allowing it to bypass traditional answers like Chansey and Celesteela with its unpredictability. Its Dragon Dance set is a strong sweeper, powering through metagame staples like Slowking and Amoonguss. On the other hand, its Meteor Beam set is equally as potent, allowing it to lure in and slam answers to the Dragon Dance set like Celesteela and Mandibuzz. Necrozma's high natural bulk and Prism Armor allow it to set up on many Pokemon like Nihilego and take super effective hits from threats like Lycanroc-D and even Aegislash. Necrozma also has a solid matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Tentacruel, letting it act as an offensive Stealth Rock setter capable of supporting its team. However, Necrozma heavily dislikes status from threats like Chansey and Aegislash, which limits its chance to sweep. Necrozma is also limited by the number of Dark-types in the tier like Zarude, Mandibuzz, Hydreigon, and Galarian Moltres, which can all hinder at least one of its sets. Overreliance on Power Herb on Necrozma's Meteor Beam set makes it hard to pull off a sweep at times with Pokemon like Hydreigon and Slowking being common, while the Dragon Dance set can be worn down it accumulates multiple boosts.
Necrozma.comments:
Other Options

Necrozma can run a Calm Mind + Moonlight set thanks to its great bulk, allowing it to be a strong late-game sweeper. However, Necrozma is walled by Hydreigon, Mandibuzz, and Slowking who can all wear it down or pivot out into a strong revenge killer like Zarude. Necrozma can run Expanding Force over Photon Geyser on its Meteor Beam set on Psychic Terrain teams for more devastating damage, but the limited viability of the playstyle and reliance on Terrain being active make Photon Geyser the preferred option. A final option is a Stored Power set with Cosmic Power or Calm Mind to boost Necrozma's stats, but it lacks the dangerous immediate sweeping potential of Necrozma's other sets and can be inconsistent at times.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Zarude can easily revenge kill Necrozma, even at +1 Speed from Dragon Dance. However, if Necrozma uses Autotomize, it can threaten them before they attack. Still, Hydreigon forces Necrozma to conserve its Power Herb as it can take advantage of Meteor Beam requring two turns. Umbreon can tank hits from all sets and cripple it with Toxic. Although they must watch out for Meteor Beam, both Mandibuzz and Galarian Moltres can take on Necrozma.

Special Walls: Special walls like Chansey, Slowking, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can take on the Meteor Beam set with ease. However, they must watch out for the Dragon Dance set. Celesteela walls the Dragon Dance set and can take a boosted Heat Wave while wearing down Necrozma with Leech Seed, but it can get overwhelmed easily. Hatterene can take boosted attacks from Necrozma and lower its Special Attack with Mystical Fire.

Status: Status is detrimental to Necrozma's attempts to sweep, so moves like Thunder Wave from Togekiss, Scald from Slowking, and Toxic from Aegislash, Excadrill, and Chansey greatly hinder it.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance boosts Necrozma's Attack to incredible levels, letting it power through Pokemon like Swampert, Primarina, and Moltres. X-Scissor OHKOes Zarude and deals great damage to Krookodile, Slowking, and Tangrowth. Heat Wave prevents Celesteela and Skarmory from walling Necrozma and also hits Steel-types like Excadrill. Alternatively, Earthquake can be used to reliably beat other Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. Since Prism Armor lets Necrozma take weak super effective hits like Knock Off from Nihilego with ease, Necrozma can employ a Weakness Policy to get a huge boost to its Attack. Alternatively, with a Lum Berry, Necrozma can set up on Pokemon like Amoonguss, Rotom-W, and Slowking, which would normally stay in to cripple it with status. Naughty is the preferred nature, since Necrozma outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame barring Choice Scarf users like Mienshao after a Dragon Dance and prefers to not lower its Special Attack to boost the power of Heat Wave.

Necrozma best fits on offense teams as a late-game cleaner once its answers have been removed. Celesteela is problematic for this particular set, so powerful wallbreakers like Thundurus-T can remove it. Thundurus-T also beats Mandibuzz and helps wear down walls like Aegislash, Chansey, and Primarina for Necrozma to bypass them more easily. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude after a Dragon Dance. Other entry hazard support from Pokemon like Excadrill and Roserade wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene. Zarude and the aforementioned Excadrill can also check Aegislash, a Pokemon Necrozma struggles with if it is healthy. Dark-type checks like Primarina and Azumarill make great partners for Necrozma, beating threats like Umbreon, Krookodile, and Galarian Moltres. Psychic Terrain support from Indeedee-F allows Necrozma to boost its damage output without fearing priority from Azumarill or Lycanroc-D if weakened. It also can provide Healing Wish support to patch up Necrozma, allowing it to sweep later in the game.

sets.name: Meteor Beam
sets.description:
In conjunction with Power Herb, Meteor Beam is a powerful attack capable of wiping out Pokemon like Salamence, Galarian Moltres, and Thundurus-T while simultaneously giving Necrozma a boost to its Special Attack in one turn. Since Power Herb is single use, it should be saved until special walls like Chansey and Slowking are gone. Photon Geyser is Necrozma's primary move to power through many Pokemon like Keldeo and Amoonguss. It is also able to ignore abilities like Quagsire's Unaware. Heat Wave melts Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi as well as Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth. It is also Necrozma's most reliable option for damaging Krookodile and Hatterene. Autotomize lets Necrozma boost its Speed to outpace the fastest Choice Scarf users in Zarude and Mienshao. Alternatively, Necrozma can utilize Stealth Rock to act as an entry hazard setter for its team thanks to its good matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H. Modest is the preferred nature to maximize damage output, since after an Autotomize, Necrozma outspeeds the fastest Choice Scarf users. Even if Stealth Rock is chosen, Modest is still preferred, since Necrozma doesn't miss out on many important Speed tiers.

This set also fits on offense teams as a powerful late-game sweeper. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Excadrill wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene for Necrozma to break through them more easily and allows Necrozma to drop Stealth Rock for Autotomize. Excadrill can also beat special walls like Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and cripple Slowking and Mandibuzz with Toxic. Early-game wallbreakers like Belly Drum Azumarill, Swords Dance Aegislash, and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can muscle through special walls like Chansey and Slowking for Necrozma. Mienshao can bring in Necrozma on Pokemon it can set up on like Amoonguss and Galarian Weezing while also threatening Umbreon, Hydreigon, and Chansey for Necrozma. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to forego Autotomize for Stealth Rock if the team needs to as well as outspeed and remove threats like Keldeo and Lycanroc-D.

Toxtricity.overview: Toxtricity carries a unique niche in UU as a fearsome Electric-type wallbreaker that isn't shut down by the tier's Grass- and Ground-types. Thanks to Punk Rock and Boomburst, Toxtricity is able to deal heavy damage to walls like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Rhyperior and maintain pressure on Pokemon that resist its STAB combination, such as Nidoking and Swampert. In addition, Toxtricity has a relatively decent defensive typing, allowing it to come in on Iron Head from Jirachi and Close Combat from Cobalion and threaten to 2HKO them. It can also pivot into various passive Pokemon such as Togekiss and Amoonguss. Despite Toxtricity's middling Speed, Shift Gear can allow it to outpace foes like Keldeo, Salamence, and even Choice Scarf Krookodile, making it a great late-game cleaner on offensive teams. However, Toxtricity's STAB attacks and Boomburst have immunities, making it a prediction-reliant wallbreaker that struggles to break through cores like Aegislash + Excadrill. Although Toxtricity's base 75 Speed is enough to outspeed the bulkier threats it is able to deal with, its bulk leaves it prey to revenge killers such as Thundurus-T, Excadrill, and Krookodile. Additionally, priority users such as Azumarill, Lycanroc-D, and Mamoswine can all halt a sweep by KOing a chipped Toxtricity. Toxtricity faces stiff competition as an offensive Poison- or Electric-type with Nihilego and Thundurus-T, which offer better coverage and Speed.
Toxtricity.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf turns Toxtricity into a revenge killer that is able to outpace threats such as Keldeo and Azelf while still having a Special Attack-boosting nature. Throat Spray is an option on Shift Gear sets, as long as Sludge Bomb or Sludge Wave is used over Drain Punch.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Although it must be wary of Shift Gear sets with Drain Punch, Chansey can stand in the way of Toxtricity’s strongest offensive moves with ease. It can heal itself with Soft-Boiled as Toxtricty switches out, keep momentum with Teleport, and spread status with Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Psychic-types: Assault Vest Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro can directly counter Toxtricity, as they can comfortably switch into Boomburst and force Toxtricity to switch out. Furthermore, their ability Regenerator allows them to heal off most of Boomburst’s damage and lets them consistently switch into Toxtricity. Azelf is faster than Toxtricity and threatens to OHKO it with Psyshock.

Ground-types: Rhyperior, Excadrill, and Krookodile are immune to Overdrive and threaten to KO Toxtricity with their STAB attacks. The former two, though resistant to Boomburst, are easily worn down by it due to its lack of recovery, and the latter risks an OHKO from it.

Faster Pokemon: Although they must be careful around Shift Gear sets, Toxtricity's low Speed and poor natural bulk leave it prey to Pokemon that outspeed it naturally, such as Hydreigon, Keldeo, Salamence, and Lycanroc-D. The latter can even use Accelerock to stop a weakened Toxtricity from sweeping with Shift Gear.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Boomburst is the most powerful move on this set, heavily damaging Ground-types such as Quagsire, Swampert, and Krookodile for heavy damage and wearing down switch-ins without recovery like Excadrill. Despite not receiving the Punk Rock boost, Sludge Wave can still power through Fairy- and Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu, Primarina, and Tangrowth. Sludge Bomb is a viable alternative over Sludge Wave to poison and wear down switch-ins like Rhyperior and Swampert. Volt Switch is Toxtricity’s way of generating momentum against threats that Toxtricity cannot break through, like Chansey. Heavy-Duty Boots prevent Toxtricity from being worn down by entry hazards. A Life Orb can be used to increase its firepower but the recoil hinders its longevity. A Modest nature is preferred to guarantee the 2HKO on Amoonguss and pressure Aegislash better, but a Timid nature can be used to outpace Adamant Gyarados and Mamoswine.

Toxtricity fits on bulky offense teams as a potent wallbreaker and is most useful in the early- to mid-game, where it can force out bulky threats such as Mandibuzz, Celesteela, and Tangrowth and punch huge holes in the opposing team. Toxtricity appreciates entry hazard support from setters such as Jirachi and Roserade to punish and accumulate chip damage on vulnerable checks such as Excadrill. Toxtricity can compliment these entry hazard setters by threatening to 2HKO entry hazard removers like Tentacruel and Salamence. Additionally, Toxtricity appreciates Pokemon that can threaten to KO and force out specially defensive walls. Keldeo is a prime example of a wallbreaker that excels at dealing with Ground-types and forcing out Chansey thanks to Secret Sword. Pokemon that resist Ground-type attacks, such as Tangrowth and Zarude, make great partners. Zarude’s U-turn, combined with Toxtricity's ability to break its checks, yields another VoltTurn core that Toxtricity benefits from.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description:
Shift Gear grants Toxtricity the ability to contend with would-be threats that are faster than it, such as Keldeo and Choice Scarf Krookodile, after a boost. Boomburst 2HKOes Ground-types like Gastrodon and Nidoking and OHKOes Krookodile. Drain Punch allows Toxtricity to defeat its greatest counter in Chansey by healing enough to offset Seismic Toss damage. Drain Punch is also useful to pick off weakened foes and keep Toxtricity healthy. Life Orb gives Toxtricity the immediate damage it needs to secure 2HKOs on specially defensive Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth after entry hazard damage. A Rash nature is preferred to secure 2HKOs on the aforementioned Grass-types, but a Naive nature can be used to outspeed fast Choice Scarf users such as Jirachi and Mienshao.

Shift Gear turns Toxtricity into a terrifying late-game sweeper that fits best on hyper offense archetypes. Toxtricity appreciates help from wallbreakers such as Keldeo and Aegislash taking care of threats such as Rhyperior and Chansey to help it sweep late-game. Additionally, entry hazard setters such as Krookodile and Excadrill help to accumulate chip damage on its checks, allowing Toxtricity to secure KOs on Swampert, Hydreigon, and Necrozma. Dragon Dance Salamence appreciates Toxtricity's ability to break through Celesteela and Tangrowth and can sweep late-game once its checks are dealt with. In return it can switch into Ground-type attacks. Priority moves like Azumarill's Aqua Jet can heavily damage Toxtricity or halt a sweep, making Gyarados and Rotom-W useful to have alongside Toxtricity. Jirachi resists Psychic and has U-turn to get Toxtricity safely into battle on a forced switch and preserve its HP, which is valuable due to Life Orb recoil. Jirachi can also provide Healing Wish support to give Toxtricity another chance to clean.

Hatterene.overview: Hatterene is an imposing Calm Mind user for defensive teams to deal with because its ability Magic Bounce deflects status moves such as Toxic and Thunder Wave, as well as phazing attempts. Hatterene's STAB moves complement each other brilliantly and, alongside Mystical Fire, give it good matchups against entry hazard setters such as Swampert and Skarmory to block their hazards with Magic Bounce and keep pressure off of its teammates. Hatterene's typing, while offensively potent, makes it a Fairy-type that's hit neutrally by Dark-type moves and a Psychic-type weak to Poison. This greatly impedes Hatterene's ability to consistently handle Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon and makes it unreliable at pressuring Tentacruel and Nihilego. It also struggles to beat Steel-types such as Jirachi and Celesteela if it does not catch them with Mystical Fire on the switch. Without a Calm Mind boost, Hatterene noticeably lacks offensive presence, which can be taken advantage of by wallbreakers such as Diggersby and Choice Specs Primarina. While it does have some good matchups against some hazard setters, it also has poor ones, such as against Jirachi and Nidoqueen, so it can require prediction to make the most out of Magic Bounce. Excadrill is a hazard setter that not only forces out Hatterene but can completely ignore Magic Bounce thanks to Mold Breaker. Hatterene's dismal Speed tier greatly limits what it can accomplish against offensive teams.
Hatterene.comments:
Other Options

On Trick Room teams, Hatterene is an effective suicide lead with Focus Sash and Misty Explosion. Magic Bounce denies entry hazards from everything bar Excadrill, and using Misty Explosion right after Trick Room gives a safe entry point for teammates such as Crawdaunt with three turns of Trick Room still remaining. Hatterene can also be an offensive threat in Trick Room with Life Orb, but this sacrifices a lot of consistency in defensive utility because of its need for Special Attack investment and Life Orb recoil. Assault Vest alongside Nuzzle is an option to make Hatterene more bulky without a boost while still crippling the likes of Aegislash and Jirachi, but it faces stiff competition from Reuniclus, which has more consistent healing with Regenerator and better bulk to handle threats such as Keldeo.

Checks and Counters

Powerful Wallbreakers: Hatterene's poor Speed, lack of consistent recovery, and reliance on a Calm Mind boost to be a consistent threat makes it easy for Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Crawdaunt to revenge kill it.

Steel-types: Jirachi takes little damage from Hatterene's STAB moves and threatens it back with Iron Head, though it dislikes Mystical Fire. Aegislash is an especially detrimental offensive threat, because even if it takes Mystical Fire on the switch a weakened Shadow Ball still threatens substantial damage; the Swords Dance set can take a Mystical Fire and obliterate Hatterene with a STAB move. Celesteela does not take too much damage from Mystical Fire due to its massive special bulk, and it 2HKOes with Heavy Slam.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Hatterene has plenty of opportunities to gain a Calm Mind boost against various Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Hydreigon, though it does have to be wary of Flash Cannon from the latter. Calm Mind notably helps Hatterene stomach hits from strong attackers such as Choice Specs Keldeo better and retaliate with Draining Kiss. Draining Kiss is mandatory as a powerful recovery tool and is instrumental against Chansey; after three boosts, Draining Kiss + Leftovers will outheal Seismic Toss's damage. Psyshock is useful against opposing Calm Mind users, most notably Primarina, as well as a more immediate weapon against Chansey.
