Psychic is an alternative option because it OHKOes Amoonguss after one Calm Mind boost instead of two. It also helps Hatterene pressure Quagsire better with Special Defense drops. Mystical Fire is vital to deter Steel-types looking to come in on a Calm Mind or STAB move like Celesteela, Jirachi, and Aegislash. Leftovers augments the recovery from Draining Kiss and makes Hatterene harder for Pokemon such as Suicune to wear down. Hatterene needs 12 EVs in Speed to outrun Amoonguss and 56 EVs to outspeed Quagsire and help against stall, though Psychic is required for the latter Pokemon.

Hatterene fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its Magic Bounce relieving entry hazard pressure from Skarmory. Pokemon that handle hazard setters Hatterene cannot switch into well like Nidoqueen, Jirachi, and Nihilego are appreciated. Chansey and Celesteela are able to check them. Celesteela can also pivot into Excadrill. Hazard support from teammates such as Krookodile and Chansey wears down Hatterene checks such as Aegislash and Celesteela. Fire-types can blow through Steel-types that Hatterene has issues with; Rotom-H and Moltres are notably able to check Aegislash and take advantage of Celesteela. Amoonguss and Skarmory can act as secondary pivots into Mienshao and Conkeldurr as repeatedly taking hits from them and losing its Leftovers greatly diminishes its ability to clean with Calm Mind.

Obstagoon.overview: Obstagoon is the only Guts user with STAB Facade, allowing it to pressure physical walls such as Amoonguss with ease. Its solid bulk, decent Speed, and access to STAB Knock Off make it a unique offensive threat, being able to take out metagame staples like Rotom-W, Galarian Moltres, and most notably SubToxic Aegislash, who cannot touch Obstagoon due to its typing and status immunity. It also has an excellent matchup against slower bulkier teams because of its status immunity, ability to heal off chip damage with Rest, and high damage output with STAB Knock Off. Due to its poor defensive typing, Obstagoon is easily revenge killed by common threats like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D. The abundance of Fighting-types like Buzzwole, Keldeo, and Kommo-o is especially problematic for Obstagoon due to its 4x weakness to fighting moves. Also, it tends to have poorer matchups against hyper offense, as teams pack more faster threats that give Obstagoon few opportunities to wallbreak, although it still can potentially pick up a KO or two. Obstagoon hates Knock Off as it cannot activate Guts without its Flame Orb, severly limiting its threat level. Its overreliance on Sleep Talk isn't ideal, as it relies on RNG to click the correct move. Obstagoon is generally outclassed by other offensive Dark-types like Krookodile and Zarude due to their better defensive utility and less reliance on their item.
Obstagoon.comments:
Other Options

Bulk Up makes Obstagoon more difficult to revenge kill due to the increase in power and bulk, but its 4x weakness to Fighting still makes getting anywhere with setup difficult in the long term. Obstruct can stall a turn to activate Obstagoon's Flame Orb while also potentially halving the Defense of normal checks such as Buzzwole. Parting Shot allows it to pivot on switch-ins such as Buzzwole.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types Moves: Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Mienshao can outspeed Obstagoon and KO it with ease with their STAB moves. Conkeldurr can also KO it with Mach Punch. Faster Pokemon with Fighting-type coverage like Lycanroc-D and Thundurus-T can also threaten it out. All of these Pokemon struggle to pivot into Obstagoon.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Rhyperior, Buzzwole, and Diancie almost completely stonewall Obstagoon, though the former doesn't like Knock Off. Tangrowth can wear down Obstagoon with Rocky Helmet chip, forcing it to use Rest.

Residual Damage: Obstagoon puts itself on a timer as soon as it activates Flame Orb, so it can prematurely faint after a strong neutral hit. Entry hazards can chip it down a lot in conjunction with the burn damage. This residual damage also pressures Obstagoon to use Rest often, limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker.

sets.name: Guts
sets.description:
Facade combined with Knock Off gives Obstagoon excellent neutral coverage against the majority of the tier. Rest can patch up residual damage from Rocky Helmet users such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. It can also let Obstagoon completely wall SubToxic Aegislash and give Obstagoon longevity against bulkier teams. Sleep Talk lets Obstagoon be a potent wallbreaker while asleep thanks to Guts remaining active. Close Combat OHKOs the only Pokemon in the tier that resist Obstagoon's STAB combination, Cobalion, while also letting it hit foes like Krookodile harder. Switcheroo can be used alongside Close Combat to cripple some slower physical attackers like Azumarill, Crawdaunt, and Tapu Bulu. It can also mess with defensive Salamence and Buzzwole by adding chip damage and getting rid of the former's Heavy-Duty Boots.

Obstagoon fits well onto bulky offense and balance teams that can generate turns for it to break consistently with the right offensive and defensive pivots. Rotom-H can bring Obstagoon in safely and pressure Amoonguss, physically defensive Tangrowth, and Celesteela. Noivern can revenge kill threats to Obstagoon like Keldeo and Cobalion. Obstagoon can also fit well on Sticky Web teams with Ribombee and Shuckle to patch up its Speed a bit. It also appreciates entry hazard support from Roserade, Nidoqueen, and Nihilego to get KOs on threats like Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Tangrowth. Amoonguss and Primarina are great defensive pivots, using their Fighting resistance to check foes that would try to revenge kill Obstagoon like Keldeo.

Zarude.overview: Zarude's great Speed alongside U-turn allows it to be an excellent pivot and revenge killer. Its high Speed enables it to outspeed common Pokemon such as Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Excadrill, and its good bulk and defensive typing lets it check many dangerous threats such as Rotom-W, Slowking, and Hippowdon, while also discouraging Zygarde-10% from spamming Thousand Arrows. The ability to heal status conditions and HP with Jungle Healing can allow Zarude to consistently pivot around defensive Pokemon such as Swampert and Hippowdon. Zarude's ability to synergize with other common pivots like Thundurus-T, Slowking, and Moltres has made it one of the defining components of offensive teams. However, it often struggles to break defensive Pokemon, such as Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Salamence, due to them resisting Power Whip and taking minimal damage from Darkest Lariat. Many teams naturally fit multiple Grass-type resistant Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Cobalion, and Moltres, leaving Zarude with limited opportunities to use its strongest STAB attack. If it is running Choice Scarf, Zarude can risk being locked into an undesirable move, losing momentum. Flame Body from Moltres and Rocky Helmet from Amoonguss and Cobalion can punish U-turn, forcing momentum to be sacrificed to use Jungle Healing.
Zarude.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band allows Zarude to function as a powerful wallbreaker, suprising usual switch-ins like Crobat and Amoonguss with a 2HKO. However, the increased prediction-reliance is problematic, and it still struggles to break through Skarmory and Mandibuzz. A Bulk Up set with Jungle Healing, Acrobatics, and Darkest Lariat allows Zarude to deal heavy damage and potentially tank super effective hits. Taunt is an option that can completely shut down Chansey's recovery and prevent Roost from Salamence, but Zarude would have to give up Jungle Healing or valuable coverage.

Checks and Counters

Faster threats and Priority: Faster Pokemon such as Crobat, Noivern, Keldeo, Azelf, and Lycanroc-D are able to put Zarude in a tough spot, outspeeding and dealing heavy damage to it. However, the latter three must watch out to see if Zarude is running a Choice Scarf set. Priority from Mamoswine and Conkeldurr can pick off a chipped Zarude.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth take little damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, while Tapu Bulu resists both. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can threaten Zarude out with Sludge Bomb, with Tapu Bulu threatening it out with Close Combat, or set up on it with Swords Dance.

Flying-types: Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Togekiss can switch into Zarude's attacks easily. Salamence can weaken Zarude's hits with Intimidate, while Mandibuzz and Togekiss resist both STAB attacks. Moltres has to watch its health around Zarude but it can threaten a burn with Flame Body and KO Zarude.

Steel-types: Cobalion, Skarmory, and Celesteela all take minimal damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, with the former two being able to chip Zarude with Rocky Helmet. Bulky variants of Swords Dance Scizor can set up on Zarude and threaten it with Bullet Punch.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Zarude's STAB combination allows it to threaten many tier staples like Primarina, Excadrill, and Slowking. U-turn grabs momentum on usual switch-ins such as Celesteela and Salamence. Jungle Healing allows Zarude to remove status conditions from moves such as Toxic from Aegislash and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W, while restoring 25% of its health. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Zarude to not worry about entry hazards, letting it constantly pivot throughout the game. Jolly is the required nature on the set so that Zarude can outspeed Nihilego and Thundurus-T.

Zarude is commonly seen on balance and bulky offense due to the easy pivoting provided by Heavy-Duty Boots and its ability to act as a status sponge against Toxic from Hippowdon and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W. Secondary pivots like Moltres, Thundurus-T, and Swampert all form potent pivoting cores with Zarude. Moltres appreciates Zarude luring in Grass- and Steel-types like Amoonguss, Scizor, and Skarmory, while Thundurus-T heavily pressures Celesteela and Moltres. Swampert can pivot into attacks from Celesteela and set entry hazards for Zarude to soften up Pokemon like Amoonguss with Stealth Rock. Other entry hazard setters like Cobalion and Excadrill also set Stealth Rock and appreciate Zarude dealing with Water-types such as Slowking and Swampert, while Zarude appreciates them dealing with Scizor and Rotom-H. Slowking and Celesteela provide a strong defensive backbone to support Zarude, checking threats like Azelf, Salamence, and Cobalion that hinder it. Zygarde-10%, Mamoswine, and Azelf are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude bringing them in on Salamence, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss, as they often have trouble switching in safely due to their frailty.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Zarude's high Speed allows it to be a great user of Choice Scarf that can revenge kill Pokemon such as Keldeo and Azelf in addition to boosted sweepers such as Gyarados and Dragon Dance Necrozma. Power Whip OHKOes Lycanroc-D and Keldeo. Darkest Lariat is Zarude's strongest Dark-type STAB move and can hit Jirachi and Azelf for huge damage. U-turn allows Zarude to pivot out on potential switch-ins such as Tangrowth and Salamence, allowing it to gain momentum. Jungle Healing can get rid of status conditions such as a burn from Moltres's Flame Body and Slowking's Scald while regaining HP so that Zarude can be used in the long run in a battle but it is not ideal to lock into. It also allows Zarude to act as a reliable status sponge if it takes a Knock Off when Choice Scarf is not needed. Rock Slide allows Zarude to OHKO Moltres while also dealing good damage to Salamence. Close Combat is able to hit Cobalion, an otherwise easy switch-in, for heavy damage.

Choice Scarf Zarude is a solid pivot and revenge killer on bulky offense teams. It appreciates additional pivots such as Moltres, Slowking, and Thundurus-T that can form momentum cores and pivot out of unfavorable matchups. For example, Moltres can bring Zarude in on Water-types such as Slowking and Swampert. Entry hazard control from the likes of Salamence, Excadrill, and Mandibuzz allows Zarude to consistently pivot without worrying about hazard damage. They can also check threats like Scizor and Tapu Bulu. Thundurus-T, Keldeo, and Nidoking are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude's pivot support and its ability to check Pokemon such as Swampert, with the wallbreakers KOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Skarmory in return. Swampert is an entry hazard setter that appreciates Zarude dealing with Keldeo, Gyarados, and Hydreigon for it, while Swampert can set Stealth Rock in return and also help deal with Pokemon like Salamence. Primarina and Azumarill can help deal with some of Zarude's checks such as Salamence.
